#DYK that Shirley Chisholm was the first African-American woman elected to the U.S. Congress? She represented New Yorkâ€™s 12th congressional district from 1969 to 1983, and went on to serve 7ï¸âƒ£ terms, championing a platform of anti-poverty programs and educational reform. In 1972, Chisholm became the first woman to seek the presidential nomination from one of the United Statesâ€™ two major political parties. Although her bid was unsuccessful, her candidacy enabled her to raise issues of importance to African-Americans and women, enabling her to blaze a path for others who would subsequently follow in her footsteps.

A: If you are arriving on a direct flight to the US, your test must be done within the 3 calendar days before your flight departs. If you are arriving via one or more connecting flights, your test must be done in the 3 days before the first flight in your itinerary, but only if the connecting flights were booked as a single passenger booking with a final destination in the US and layovers are no longer than 24 hours. If your connecting flight to the US was booked separately, a layover in your itinerary lasts longer than 24 hours, or your travel is disrupted and you leave the airport, you will need to get tested within the 3 days before your flight that arrives in the US.

Born in Scranton, Pennsylvania, and raised in Delaware, Joseph R. Biden Jr. enters the White House with decades of experience on Capitol Hill. He spent 36 years representing Delaware as a senator and played an important role in shaping U.S. foreign policy. As chairman or ranking member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee for 12 years, Biden was at the forefront of issues and legislation involving terrorism, weapons of mass destruction, post-Cold War Europe, the Middle East, and Southwest Asia. In his victory speech as President-elect, he said, â€œLet us be the nation that we know we canâ€¦A nation united, a nation strengthened. A nation healed. The United States of America, ladies and gentlemen, thereâ€™s never, never been anything weâ€™ve tried weâ€™ve not been able to do.â€

ğŸ“£ #CGDamour delivered opening remarks and toured the 1995-2020 U.S. â€“ Vietnam Bilateral Relations Archives Exhibit co-organized by the State Records and Archives Department of Vietnam and the U.S. Consulate General Ho Chi Minh City on January 8. The exhibit, which is part of the 25th anniversary commemorating the re-establishment of U.S.-Vietnam diplomatic relations, showcases the highlights important milestones in the U.S-Vietnam relationship including progress in overcoming war legacies, and cooperation in expanding cultural, health, scientific, security, and people-to-people ties. The opening ceremony was well attended by government officials and university students, and covered by a dozen local media outlets. The exhibit will be up for two months and is open to public.

We have been heartened by notes from friends throughout Vietnam who share our dismay about the storming of the U.S. Capitol yesterday.  Lawlessness and rioting are always unacceptable. Our democracy has been tested in the past, and it will be tested in the future. These experiences make us stronger as we work to perfect our union and our democracy.

The Congress of the United States of America certified Joseph R. Biden as President-elect and Kamala D. Harris as Vice President-elect on January 6.  They will take the oath of office on January 20, 2021.

January is the National Slavery and Human Trafficking Awareness Month. Human trafficking is a crime in which force, fraud, or coercion is used to compel people to perform labor, services, or commercial sex. We all play a crucial role in ending this worldwide phenomenon, which is the world's third largest criminal enterprise. Learn how you can help: https://bit.ly/2WUIkK7.

ğŸ™Œ Deputy Chief of Mission Christopher Klein met with 50 students at the TuyÃªn Quang Ethnic Minority Boarding School who are current recipients of the U.S. Government's English Access Microscholarship Program. #CGDamour: I would like to express my special thanks to Danang Union of Friendship Organizations (DAFO) and the Danang University of Foreign Language Studies for organizing an outstanding event to celebrate the 25th anniversary of U.S.-Vietnam relations. The United States was the first country to establish a friendship organization with Vietnam, helping to lay the groundwork for the vibrant partnership we now enjoy. Events like this are a great example of how we continue to work every day towards our goal of shared prosperity and building a stronger partnership.

Yesterday #CGDamour and USAID Vietnam Mission Director Ann Marie Yastishock met with the Vice Chairman of the Quang Nam Provincial Peopleâ€™s Committee Há»“ Quang Bá»­u in Tam Ky city to express their sincere condolences for the loss of life, destruction of property, and displacement of people due to the recent flooding in the province during the devastating storm season. Consul General Damour and Mission Director Yastishock also visited families in Tam Thang Commune, Tam Ky city affected by the flooding. 

USAID has supported Vietnam with disaster risk reduction and disaster risk management activities since 2000. Building on this long term assistance, USAID has committed more than $2.3 million in disaster relief funds to Vietnam to address the immediate humanitarian needs of vulnerable communities in affected areas.

ğŸ¤ U.S. Mission Vietnam and the Ministry of Public Security conducted a Nov 17-19 training in HCMC on human trafficking and child exploitation for police officers from southern provinces. This followed a similar training for police from northern provinces in Halong City with U.S. Mission representatives from DHS Homeland Security Investigations, the Regional Security Office, and the Bureau of International Narcotics and Law Enforcement earlier this month. Combatting human trafficking and child exploitation is a top priority for U.S. Mission Vietnam and the Ministry of Public Security, and an area of expanding cooperation.

story: U.S. Consulate General - Ho Chi Minh City added an event.

message:
These are exciting times for architects and the public as architecture moves beyond modernism into the information age. This presentation focuses on the characteristics of this new architecture and shows how Vietnamese architects are leading the world in the design of houses and schools for the new reality of the information age.

About the speaker: American architect Mel Schenck is a long-term immigrant to Vietnam and has been studying Vietnamese modernist architecture since he was surprised by the extent and quality of this architecture in Saigon when he first lived here in 1971/72. He and photographer Alexandre Garel are the authors of the new book "Southern Vietnamese Modernist Architecture: Mid-Century Vernacular Modernism" published in Hanoi by Tháº¿ Giá»›i Publishers.

Today, during the #IndoPacificBizForum in Hanoi, USAID Vietnam Mission Director Ann Marie Yastishock announced the launch of the USAID Vietnam Low Emission Energy Program II. This 5-year, $36 million program will accelerate Vietnamâ€™s transition to a clean, secure, and market-driven energy system by improving government energy planning practices; increasing competition and private sector involvement in energy service provision; deploying advanced, clean energy systems; and improving grid planning to incorporate clean energy transmission.

#Live from the #IndoPacificBizForum: âœï¸ The AES Corporation  and #PetroVietnam Gas Joint Stock Company just signed a term sheet for their joint venture agreement to develop the Son My LNG Import Terminal Project in Binh Thuan province. With a total investment cost of US $1.4 billion, this project will play a major role in helping to diversify Vietnamâ€™s energy mix and meeting its increasing demand for sustainable and affordable electricity.

The vast quantity and quality of Vietnamese modernist buildings constructed throughout southern Vietnam between 1945 and 1975 made Vietnam an unrecognized center of modernism in the world. This presentation recognizes the accomplishment of the Vietnamese people in developing their own modernist architecture that reflects Vietnamese identity based upon their traditional architecture.

***About the speaker: American architect Mel Schenck is a long-term immigrant to Vietnam and has been studying Vietnamese modernist architecture since he was surprised by the extent and quality of this architecture in Saigon when he first lived here in 1971/72. He and photographer Alexandre Garel are the authors of the new book "Southern Vietnamese Modernist Architecture: Mid-Century Vernacular Modernism" published in Hanoi by Tháº¿ Giá»›i Publishers.

The 30,000 Vietnamese students studying in the United States are a testament to the strength and vitality of our friendship. We are also engaging with the 30,000+ YSEALI VIETNAM members who are next generation leaders working to bring solutions to some of our most pressing challenges. #SecretaryPompeo: The Government of the United States expresses its deepest condolences to the Government and people of Vietnam as they mourn those who perished due to significant flooding in the central region of Vietnam as a result of Tropical Storm Linfa.  The U.S. government stands ready to assist Vietnam in addressing the damage caused by the floods, and we send our deepest sympathies to all affected by this tragedy, including the many thousands who were displaced.

Join us @2pm on Oct 28 at the American Center HCMC for session 2 "Southern Vietnam as a Center of Modernist Architecture" of the Southern Vietnam Modernist Architecture series. This program will be in English and has limited seats. Please RSVP at https://ac-southern-vietnamese-modernist-architecture-oct.eventbrite.com

ğŸ”¸ About the event: The vast quantity and quality of Vietnamese modernist buildings constructed throughout southern Vietnam between 1945 and 1975 made Vietnam an unrecognized center of modernism in the world. This presentation recognizes the accomplishments of the Vietnamese people in developing their own modernist architecture that reflects Vietnamese identity based upon their traditional architecture. 

ğŸ”¸ About the speaker: American architect Mel Schenck is a long-term immigrant to Vietnam and has been studying Vietnamese modernist architecture since he was surprised by the extent and quality of this architecture in Saigon when he first lived here in 1971/72. He and photographer Alexandre Garel are the authors of the new book "Southern Vietnamese Modernist Architecture: Mid-Century Vernacular Modernism" published in Hanoi by Tháº¿ Giá»›i Publishers.

U.S. Navy Arleigh Burke-class guided-missile destroyer USS John S. McCain (DDG 56) joined Japanese Maritime Self-Defense Force (JMSDF) ship JS Kirisame (DD 104) and Royal Australian Navy ship HMAS Arunta (FFH 151) in the South China Sea for multinational exercises, October 19. These exercises marked the fifth time of 2020 that Australia, Japan, and the U.S. have conducted operations together in the 7th Fleet area of operations. Throughout the naval exercises, participants trained together and conducted trilateral operations designed to increase the alliesâ€™ collective ability to maintain maritime security and readiness to respond to any regional contingency.

Gender equity is associated with higher levels of economic development, peacefulness, and general well-being at all levels of society. In recognition of Vietnamese Womenâ€™s Day, the American Center would like to invite you to join a conversation with distinguished guests to learn how we can raise awareness among younger generations about how to narrow the gender gap and create a level playing field to reach greater potential for progress.
Moderator: U.S. Consulate General's Deputy Principal Officer Robert Greenan
Panelists:
- Felicity Brown, RMIT University's Career Consulting & Development Manager, Career Coach and Director at Maia Career Coaching
- Thai Van Linh, Entrepreneur and Investor on Shark Tank Vietnam, Lead Trainer of U.S. Governmentâ€™s funded Women Leadership Professional Development Series
- Ho Thai Binh, Director and Co-founder of Survival Skills Vietnam, YSEALI Professional Fellow Alumnus in Civic Engagement

 #DYK Ellen Ochoa, a Stanford Universityâ€“trained engineer from California, was selected for NASAâ€˜s astronaut program in 1990 and became the worldâ€™s first Hispanic woman astronaut in 1991. She is the first Hispanic woman to travel into space, serving aboard the Space Shuttle Discovery in 1993. A veteran of four space flights, she has logged nearly 1,000 hours in orbit. Ochoa served as director of NASAâ€™s Johnson Space Center from 2013 to 2018. Today, she is vice chair of the National Science Board and chairs its committee to evaluate nominations for the National Medal of Technology and Innovation.

The U.S. Mission in Vietnam expresses our deepest condolences to the people of Vietnam for the loss of life, destruction of property, and displacement of people due to the flooding in central Vietnam.  We stand together with the Government and the people of Vietnam as they mourn their loved ones, address the damage caused by this terrible flood, and move forward, as the people of Vietnam have always done.  We pledge to assist you in your work to rebuild.  With USAIDâ€™s leadership, the U.S. Mission in Vietnam continues to support Vietnamâ€™s disaster relief efforts and plans are underway to provide additional assistance.

Join us at the American Center HCMC for Session 1 - Modernist Architecture in Vietnam and the World
Modernist Architecture in the twentieth-century became the architecture of the Industrial Age. This presentation presents the characteristics of global modernist architecture and compares them with Vietnamese modernist architecture. While modernism has been declared dead many times since 1960, it continues to flourish today around the world.

#SecretaryPompeo: The launch of the Mekong-U.S. Partnership reflects the importance of the Mekong region to ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸. Our relationship with Mekong partner countries is an integral part of our Indo-Pacific vision and our strategic partnership with ASEAN. The Mekong-U.S. Partnership will also continue to strengthen water security and the work of the Mekong River Commission. In all our efforts, the United States intends to work closely with partners like Japan, Australia, South Korea, India, and other good friends of the Mekong. We need to be candid, however, about the challenges we face, including those from the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), which increasingly threatens the Mekongâ€™s natural environments and economic autonomy. The Foreign Ministers of Mekong countries, including Cambodia, Lao PDR, Myanmar, Thailand, and Vietnam and the Secretary of State of the United States of America, on September 11, 2020, launched the #MekongUSPartnership, building on the success of the Lower Mekong Initiative. The Foreign Ministers and the Secretary reaffirmed the strong friendship and successful collaboration between the United States and countries in the Mekong region. They also affirmed that the Mekong-U.S. Partnership will further strengthen transparency and good governance, and enhance connectivity, economic integration, inclusive, and sustainable development, and help narrow the development gap in the region.  The new Partnership will broaden and deepen our cooperation and allow for flexibility in addressing emerging issues. Read the entire statement here: https://www.state.gov/mekong-u-s-partnership-joint-ministerial-statement/

#CGDamour: I was excited to join Ho Chi Minh City leaders to participate in the Sourcing Fair Supporting Industries 2020 in Ho Chi Minh City today that attracted 15 lead firms and 50 supporting industry enterprises. The event, supported by USAID Linkages for Small and Medium Enterprises (LinkSME) project, serves as a platform for Vietnamese supporting industry enterprises to connect and build relationships with lead firms through business-to-business matching, displaying their products, and sharing their experiences in global supply chains.

ğŸš¨ Weather Alert â€“ Tropical Storm No.5 (aka Typhoon Noul) will land in central Vietnam as early as 9am tomorrow (Friday, September 18). Vietnamese authorities are instructing residents in Quang Binh, Thua Thien-Hue, and Da Nang to prepare for heavy rains, winds, and flooding with some possible evacuations. Mountainous areas may also experience landslides. Learn about resources and recommended precautions on our website at vn.usembassy.gov/weather-alert-typhoon-noul/

With the U.S. election season just around the corner, please join us to learn about Americaâ€™s voting history and the importance of your right to vote. Voting is one of America's most cherished democratic liberties. While the founding fathers saw voting as a fundamental component of the democracy and perfect union they sought to create, the right to vote was denied for many populations for centuries of U.S. history.

Are you interested in learning about how the Peopleâ€™s Republic of Chinaâ€™s (PRC ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡³) activities in the South China Sea (SCS) is impacting delicate marine ecosystems in the region? Please join us for a presentation and discussion related to environmental concerns in the SCS, which will feature Dr. John McManus of the University of Miamiâ€™s Rosenstiel School. The author of over 80 publications, Dr. McManus specializes in the
study of the impact of human activity on the SCSâ€™ threatened marine environment. In addition, he is known for his efforts to develop a large Spratly Island International Peace Park in the South China Sea, an idea often attributed to an early reef connectivity study he conducted.

In only a few months Americans will elect their next President of the United States. Americans will have a lot to consider when deciding who they want to support. Learn more about the methods Americans use when deciding who to give their vote. This lecture will outline the voting process and put a spotlight on why the 2020 election season could forever change how Americans vote.
About the author: Alexander Parini is an American Studies lecturer at Hoa Sen University. Before moving to Asia, he worked in US politics. He is the editor in chief at My Asia Connections.

Taste the 25th Anniversary Mooncakes!

On August 21, ABC Bakery, the California Milk Advisory Board, and the U.S. Consulate General in HCMC launched the 25th Anniversary mooncakes at the ABC Bakery mooncakes stand at the Saigon Centre. These mooncakes are a special and delicious way to highlight and celebrate the 25th Anniversary of normalization of the United States â€“ Vietnam relations.  They are made from combining high-quality U.S. ingredients, such as Californian cream cheese, wheat, and oats with traditional Vietnamese ingredients such as dragon fruit and coffee.  ABC Bakery has also made these mooncakes even more special by baking in the 25th Anniversary seal into the cakes.
Together we bake, together we create extraordinary things!

Incoming U.S. Consulate General - Ho Chi Minh City Consular Officer C.F. was an English teacher with the Peace Corps in rural Kyrgyzstan. â€œThe Peace Corps has three main goals: first, to provide community-level support to host countries. The second is to provide local people with insight into American culture and life, through building relationships with the organization's volunteers. Finally, after two years of service abroad, volunteers return to the United States and share with other Americans their understanding of the cultural and historical values of the countries where they have worked. When I think of my own experience as a Peace Corps volunteer, I most often think about the wonderful people I was lucky enough to meet, such as my students, host family, teachers and other volunteers -- who worked with me, laughed with me and shared their lives with me. I am forever grateful to them.â€

The U.S. government is deeply concerned about Vietnamâ€™s conviction and sentencing of eight members of the Hien Phap civil society organization in Vietnam to more than 40 years in prison. Peace Corps Volunteers bring innovative ideas and diverse experience to the classroom to encourage critical thinking and develop language skills. #DYK many U.S. diplomats at U.S. Consulate General - Ho Chi Minh City once served as Peace Corps volunteers? 

Consulate Management officer Gerry was a Peace Corps Volunteer in Cameroon from 2005-2007. Hear about his experience here:
â€œI was assigned to teach English and computer science to students aged 10-20 at a vocational school in Tiko, Cameroon, in West Africa.  Some of my colleagues and students had never met a U.S. citizen in their life. We all gained invaluable experience from each other. My Peace Corps experience was extremely rewarding. To this day, I am still in touch with students, friends, and colleagues from my two-year Peace Corps tour.â€

Please join the American Center on Tuesday, August 4 for an English Club discussion about one of Americaâ€™s most cherished and lesser-known National Parks: Acadia National Park.
Acadia National Park, which gets its name from the French word â€œAcadiaâ€ meaning â€˜heaven of Earth,â€™ was a turn-of-the-century playground for the rich and famous before being founded as the first National Park east of the Mississippi river. Join us as we explore the history, natural beauty, and significance of Acadia National Park through interactive activities, group discussions and a multimedia presentation by U.S. Consulate Officer Kara Eyrich. Although all levels are welcome, the discussion will be tailored to the Intermediate English speaker.

What actions can you take to help end human trafficking? 
Today marks the World Day against Trafficking in Persons (TIP). Trafficking in persons is a serious crime and a grave violation of human rights. Every year, thousands of men, women and children are exploited by traffickers, in their own countries and abroad. Human trafficking affects every country in the world, and we must take collective action to end forced labor, involuntary servitude, debt bondage, and sexual exploitation. EVERYONE plays a role in fighting against human trafficking. 

Here are 2ï¸âƒ£0ï¸âƒ£ ideas each of us can do to help end the scourge of human trafficking: https://bit.ly/2DfoX7M.

#AmbassadorKritenbrink and Mr. Le Chi Dung, Director General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Americas Department, witnessed the signing over of one set of remains thought to be associated with a U.S. service member still missing from the Vietnam War. Ambassador Kritenbrink thanked the Government and people of Vietnam, and remarked cooperation on this humanitarian issue made it possible to establish todayâ€™s strong partnership grounded in mutual respect and a shared commitment for peace and prosperity. 

The one set remains will be transferred to the DPAA Central Identification Laboratory in Hawaii for further review. The 153rd Repatriation Ceremony was the culmination of collaborative efforts of the U.S and Vietnam during the 139th Joint Field Activity, and the first time in the past three decades that simultaneously deployed 3 Vietnamese Recovery Teams in support of this humanitarian endeavor. Through a close partnership between the two countries, 727 Americans have been accounted for upholding the promise that â€œyou are not forgotten."

On 7 July 2020 the U.S. government and Quang Binh Province held an initial workshop for a $5.5 million dollar project to survey and clear unexploded bombs from the war era. This work will help decrease the impact of unexploded bombs on the people of Quang Binh. Since 1993, the United States and Vietnam have partnered to address explosive materials left from the war, part of our efforts to together build a new future dedicated to the peace and prosperity of our peoples. This would not be possible without the assistance of NGOs like Norwegian People's Aid Vietnam, Mine Action Group, and PeaceTrees Vietnam.

U.S. Department of State Secretary Mike Pompeo released a statement on the U.S. Position on Maritime Claims in the South China Sea: "The People's Republic of China has no legal grounds to unilaterally impose its will on the region," the Secretary stated. "Beijing has offered no coherent legal basis for its 'Nine-Dashed Line' claim in the South China Sea since formally announcing it in 2009." The Secretary also emphasized that "In a unanimous decision on July 12, 2016, an Arbitral Tribunal constituted under the 1982 Law of the Sea Convention â€“ to which the PRC is a state party â€“ rejected the PRCâ€™s maritime claims as having no basis in international law. The Tribunal sided squarely with the Philippines, which brought the arbitration case, on almost all claims." The Secretary concluded, "America stands with our Southeast Asian allies and partners in protecting their sovereign rights to offshore resources, consistent with their rights and obligations under international law." 

READ THE FULL STATEMENT: go.usa.gov/xfTx4

The U.S. Embassy in Hanoi and Consulate in HCMC are pleased to announce the resumption of visa processing for limited nonimmigrant visa categories, including student visas, beginning July 15. Applicants may apply in the following categories: F, M, certain J (alien physician, government visitor, international visitor, professor, research scholar, short-term scholar, specialist, secondary school student and college/university student), C1/D, E, I, O, and P.

On July 7, 1991 the U.S. Office for MIA Affairs opened in Hanoi, the first U.S. government agency to establish an official presence in Vietnam since 1975. The United States and Vietnam have cooperated for over three decades to fully account for those Americans still missing from the war in Vietnam. This humanitarian endeavor served as the â€œbridge to normalizationâ€, and through a close partnership between both countries, 727 Americans have been accounted for and returned home, upholding the promise "you are not forgotten."

â€œThe U.S. Department of Defense is concerned about the PRCâ€™s decision to conduct military exercises around the Paracel Islands in the South China Sea on July 1-5...

The military exercises are the latest in a long string of PRC actions to assert unlawful maritime claims and disadvantage its Southeast Asian neighbors in the South China Sea.  The PRCâ€™s actions stand in contrast to its pledge to not militarize the South China Sea and the United States' vision of a free and open Indo-Pacific region, in which all nations, large and small, are secure in their sovereignty, free from coercion, and able to pursue economic growth consistent with accepted international rules and norms.â€

ğŸ” Q&A with Consul General Marie Damour

Q: When will the Consulate in Ho Chi Minh City resume visa operations?

A: In response to significant worldwide challenges related to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Department of State temporarily suspended routine visa services at all U.S. Embassies and Consulates. Routine in-person visa services remain suspended at the Consulate General in HCMC until further notice. Limited services are available for mail-in visa renewals and emergencies, and I encourage you to check our website at bit.ly/nivvn to see if you qualify. For students, we will do all we can to accommodate your student visa applicants once we resume in-person visa services. Please be sure to check your school's information to see if they have opted for distance learning in the Fall semester. The U.S. Consulate General in HCMC looks forward to resuming visa services and will update our Consulate website and Facebook and Zalo pages as soon as we do. Please check our website for more information and updates:

The Honorable Sonia Sotomayor is the third woman to be appointed to the U.S. Supreme Court and the first Justice of Latin-American descent in the Courtâ€™s 231 years. Justice Sotomayor was born in the Bronx, New York to working-class parents with limited financial resources. Despite her familyâ€™s financial challenges, her parents placed great emphasis on the importance of education â€“ and it paid off. After having graduated summa cum laude from Princeton University in 1976, Sotomayor went on to secure a J.D. from Yale Law School. She held various important judicial positions before being confirmed by the U.S. Congress as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court in 2009. #HistoricAmericans

U.S. Army veteran Matt Keenan shared his experiences in Chu Lai and Danang in 1971-1972 with other U.S. and Vietnamese veterans aboard the USS Bunker Hill during the USS Theodore Roosevelt Carrier Strike Group visit to Danang in March this year. The U.S. Department of State has limited routine passport and citizenship services overseas as part of public health measures to prevent the spread of #COVID19. U.S. citizens who applied for passports before April 2 should receive their passports as scheduled. Passports for those who applied after April 2 will be significantly delayed. We do not have a timeline for when passport print centers will reopen and when routine processing can continue. U.S. Embassy in Hanoi and U.S. Consulate General - Ho Chi Minh City will contact affected applicants who applied for full-validity passports (valid for five or ten years) after April 2 to inform them of the delay and give them the option of requesting a locally issued emergency photo digitized passport (EPDP). 
 
U.S. Embassy Hanoi and Consulate General HCMC will continue to process locally issued emergency photo digitized passports (EPDPs) for applicants who need immediate access to a passport. U.S. citizens with questions about emergency passport services may contact us at: bit.ly/acsvn.

âš ï¸  FLIGHT FROM HANOI TO LONDON âš ï¸ 
âš ï¸ Interested U.S. citizens must register ASAP âš ï¸

The UK and Irish Embassies in Vietnam have secured an additional commercial flight to LONDON with Vietnam Airlines now open to citizens of all nationalities interested in departing from Vietnam and Cambodia.  This is a commercial flight scheduled to depart from HANOI on Tuesday, April 14, at 2:20 AM. Interested U.S. citizens must register as soon as possible at: bit.ly/2xfYkx5. Interested U.S. citizens are responsible for providing their own transportation to the airport in Hanoi, for all fees in advance of departure and, if applicable, any additional commercial transportation from LONDON to the United States or other country. This flight will only take place if there is enough interest to make it commercially viable. Please note that the flight interest registration form mentions potential repatriation loans from the British and Irish Embassies to their citizens. U.S. citizens are not eligible to request this assistance.
 
The U.S. Department of Homeland Security has specific information for U.S. citizens returning from the United Kingdom or any of the countries subject to one of the recent Presidential Proclamations in their DHS Response to COVID-19 page (bit.ly/2JQJQX0) including details on heightened screening procedures and home-quarantine requirements. U.S. citizens should also check the U.S. Embassy London webpage for information on transiting through or traveling to the UK (bit.ly/2JN0NSf). U.S. citizens are advised to consider all information regarding entry requirements to the UK and the United States in deciding whether to make use of this commercial flight option.
 
Continue checking Mission Vietnamâ€™s COVID-19 page (bit.ly/vncovid) daily for information, and register or update your information in the Department of Stateâ€™s Smart Traveler Enrollment Program (STEP) (step.state.gov) to stay informed.

As part of national #SocialDistancing efforts, Vietnamese  authorities in Hai Phong, Da Nang, and Hanoi are imposing additional movement restrictions on Vietnamese nationals and foreigners. 
â‡ï¸ Hai Phong and Da Nang announced that any travelers arriving from Hanoi and HCMC will be required to spend 14 days in centralized quarantine.  
â‡ï¸ Hanoi has requested that police check people on the streets of Hanoi and â€œimpose penalties for all cases of unexplained travelâ€ or for being outside for â€œunjustified reasonsâ€ until April 15.

â—IRS WARNING for AMERICANS 
The IRS urges taxpayers to be on the lookout for a surge of call and email phishing attempts about #COVID19, which could lead to tax-related fraud and identity theft.  U.S. citizens are warned not to respond to calls, text messages, websites, and social media inquiries or ads that request money or personal information with promises of receiving an economic impact payment or refund faster. U.S. citizens who receive unsolicited emails, text messages, or social media attempts to gather information that appear to be from the IRS or an organization closely linked to the IRS should forward the message to phishing@irs.gov.  For all information and updates about the economic impact payment, U.S. citizens should visit:  https://www.irs.gov/coronavirus
 
To stay informed, enroll in in the Smart Traveler Enrollment Program (STEP) at: https://step.state.gov. #ACSVietnam.

#USGAlumni are contributing to the fight against COVID-19. When Loc, a pharmacist and #YSEALI alumn, turned 28 last week, he chose to celebrate his birthday by asking friends to contribute to #200ChaiNuoCruaTay (200 bottles of hand sanitizer). Within one day, he raised 7.8 million VND, which he used to produce 21 liters of hand sanitizer, delivering 200 bottles to fish and meat vendors at Tam Ky market. The remaining money will go to the Vietnamese Ministry of Health campaign.

âš ï¸âœˆï¸ UPDATE ON FLIGHT AVAILABILITY: On March 31, U.S. Secretary of State Michael Pompeo urged U.S. citizens interested in returning to the United States during the outbreak of #COVID19 to make immediate use of available commercial flight options, as the number of locations in need of assistance around the world may not allow for a charter option: â€œWe do not know in some countries how long the continued commercial flights in your country may continue to operate. Commercial flight options are still available from Vietnam to the United States. As there are no direct flights to return to the United States, U.S. citizens may have to transit in another country where that countryâ€™s entry and exit laws may impact their itinerary. U.S. citizens overseas should immediately make use of all commercial options to return to the United States unless they are prepared to remain abroad indefinitely. A list of airlines with flights scheduled to depart Vietnam for onward connecting flights to the United States can be accessed here: https://vn.usembassy.gov/airline-departure-information/. The U.S. Government does not anticipate repatriation flights from Vietnam at this time.

On March 31, Vietnamese PM Nguyen Xuan Phuc issued a directive that calls for people to practice maximum social distancing for 15 days, starting nationwide at midnight on April 1. The directive announced strict nationwide #SocialDistancing rules and asks all residents and visitors to restrict their movements and only go out for necessities, including food, medicine, medical care, and work in locations designated as essential. No gathering of more than 2 people is allowed in public, except for in offices, schools, and hospitals. The U.S. Mission in Vietnam advises U.S. citizens to abide by Government of Vietnam regulations. The full directive is available here: bit.ly/2WZjXw2.

U.S. citizens currently under quarantine, in self-isolation or stranded in Vietnam can notify the U.S. Embassy of Hanoi or U.S. Consulate HCMC of their situation by submitting an online inquiry (https://bit.ly/2xuZqop). Note that those wishing the U.S. Embassy or Consulate share information about their situation with friends, family, and loved ones will need to attach a completed Privacy Act Waiver (https://bit.ly/2yeLe3a) to their inquiry.   

If you have been placed in mandatory 14-day quarantine by the Vietnamese government, please complete this mandatory quarantine requirement, even if you test negative for COVID-19. Please understand the U.S. Embassy and Consulate cannot intervene in the quarantine rules established by the Vietnamese government.

Travel Alert â€“ The Vietnamese government announced that starting at 12 p.m. (noon) on March 15, travelers from the 26 Schengen countries and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, or those who have visited or transited through these countries within 14 days preceding their expected entry into Vietnam, will not be issued visas or allowed entry into Vietnam. This also applies to those who currently possess visas or visa letters. Vietnam has also suspended visas on arrival for all foreign nationals. Travelers may be denied entry and returned to their point of embarkation, or may be sent to quarantine in Vietnam.

For further official Vietnamese government information in English, please visit the Vietnamese governmentâ€™s website here. Additional details may be found on Mission Vietnamâ€™s COVID-19 webpage. https://vn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

#AmbassadorKritenbrink: On behalf of the U.S. Mission in Vietnam, I would like to express our sincere condolences on the passing of The Venerable Thich Quang Do, Patriarch of the Unified Buddhist Church of Vietnam. Thich Quang Do was a tireless advocate for religious freedom and human rights, and he remained committed to the non-violent pursuit of justice. These peaceful efforts garnered him numerous international awards, and he was nominated several times for the Nobel Peace Prize. I had the honor of meeting Patriarch Thich Quang Do in 2018, and I was deeply impressed by his compassion and commitment to religious pluralism.

Since 1989, the U.S. government has contributed more than $125 million in assistance to persons with disabilities in Vietnam, benefiting hundreds of thousands of persons with disabilities. We also support local governments, implementing the national disability law and the International Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Together, we aim to help persons with disabilities fully integrate into the society and lead an independent and productive life.

#YSEALIAgriBiz

Can space help us understand earth? The NASA Land-Cover and Land-Use Change (LCLUC) satellite program uses images from space to help us observe changes on earth, including important data about natural disasters, the environmental changes, the effects of agriculture, and the health of forests and wetlands. Scientists use this data to inform decisionmakers about the possible effects of natural and manmade changes. 

Join us for a presentation by Dr. Garik Gutman, the LCLUC Program Manager at NASA Headquarters, on the programâ€™s achievements and   NASAâ€™s science collaboration with the Vietnam National Space Center (VNSC), followed by  a panel discussion about the challenges Vietnam is currently facing and how the United States and Vietnam are working together to learn more.

The ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ is mobilizing resources around the world to help fight #COVID19.  
â˜‘ï¸ During the first week of January, #CDC made an offer of assistance to China to help bolster response efforts. 
â˜‘ï¸ The  U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) provided the WHO a list of medical professionals ready to deploy their skills in China. 
â˜‘ï¸ HHS Secretary Azar offered U.S. assistance to Health Minister Ma Xiaowei; Secretary Pompeo did the same with Chinese State Councilor Yang Jiechi. We hope the mission will commence immediately. 
â˜‘ï¸ We facilitated the delivery of medical supplies to the Chinese people. Last week, the State Department helped transport 17.8 tons of relief supplies to Hubei. More assistance will be offered - the U.S. is prepared to spend up to $100 million to assist China and other impacted countries, including Vietnam, to contain and combat the virus.

Heightened tension in the Middle East may result in security risks to U.S. citizens abroad.  The Embassy will continue to review the security situation and will provide additional information as needed.  
  
Actions to Take: 
- Keep a low profile. 
- Be aware of your surroundings. 
- Stay alert in locations frequented by tourists. 
- Review your personal security plans.  
- Have travel documents up to date and easily accessible.

ğŸ“Œ Useful Tips for Travelers to the United States!

The Transportation Security Administration expects another high volume period for the upcoming holiday season. Between Dec. 19 and Jan. 5, TSA estimates 42 million passengers will travel through security screening checkpoints nationwide, an increase of 3.9% from 2018.

Travelers should plan to arrive early enough to allow time to check in and get through the security screening process. In addition to screening personal electronic devices separately, including laptops, tablets, e-readers and handheld game consoles, TSA officers may instruct travelers to separate other items from carry-on bags such as foods, powders, and any materials that can clutter bags and obstruct clear images on the X-ray machine. Keeping carry-on bags organized can ease the screening process and keep the lines moving.

For more holiday tips, see our holiday travel tips page: https://www.tsa.gov/travel/travel-tips/fly-rudolph-holiday-seaso

Have you ever admired the scenic terraced rice fields of northern Vietnam and wondered what it would be like to be a farmer there? Well, this week #AmbassadorKritenbrink found out when he visited beautiful HÃ  Giang Province! The Ambassador, who grew up on a farm in Nebraska, said the experience reminded him of his childhood. In addition to cutting and threshing rice, he had a chance to chat and interact with Dao farmers to learn about their lives and culture. He was treated to a mini-version of the Cáº¥p sáº¯c ritual to mark the coming of age of a young man. Ambassador Kritenbrink said it was one of the most memorable days of his life. Thank you HÃ  Giang for a wonderful visit!

When riding a motorbike in Vietnam, wear a helmet and always yield to larger vehicles. Motor bike accidents are a leading cause of death or serious injury among foreigners in Vietnam. Yesterday, we asked you if parent(s) at the student visa interview are expected to answer all questions about their studentâ€™s study abroad program in the U.S. 

The answer is false. When you and your parent(s) make the decision to study abroad in the U.S., the consular officers expect you to be fully informed about your study abroad program. You should be prepared to answer all of the questions during the interview. There is no visa category that allows parents to live with their child while they study in the U.S. You will need to show the consular officer that you are ready to independently study abroad in the U.S.

Yesterday, we asked if having family in the U.S. would automatically hurt your chances of getting a student visa.

The answer is FALSE. During the student visa interview, consular officers are considering all factors of your application, not just one. We need to see that you are a credible student with sufficient finances and the intent to return to Vietnam after the end of your studies. We know that sometimes having family members in the U.S. may decrease your living expenses. The most important factor in the interview is to be honest and genuine in your responses. Remember, when interviewing there are no right or wrong answers. #YouHocUSA

#CGTarnowka  Good-bye, Vietnam!  Thank you for an unforgettable three years.  I explored your beautiful country, tasted your delicious food, and experienced your amazing culture.  Most importantly, I made some lifelong friends here.  Vietnamese people truly are the best thing about Vietnam.  Thank you for your warmth, your hospitality, and your friendship.  I will never forget you.
 
I am proud of the work that we did together, making Vietnam stronger and more prosperous, and bringing Vietnam and the United States closer than ever.  Even though I am leaving Vietnam, our work is not done.  The new CG will be here soon, and continue the Consulateâ€™s engagement with the people of southern Vietnam.  I am optimistic about Vietnam: your future is bright.  I look forward to watching the friendship and partnership between our countries grow.

We know this time of year is peak season for student visa applicants. So we want to keep you informed on all things student visa related. Here's your first tip of the week! 

Whether you are applying for a student visa for the first time or reapplying for renewal, please keep in mind the three key factors that consular officers are looking for in your application. 1) Are you a credible student? 2) Do you have the finances to complete your studies in the U.S.? 3) Will you return to Vietnam at the end of your studies?  

Your study plan should be consistent with these three factors and show how it will contribute to your future career goals in Vietnam.

Are you overwhelmed by all of the fake news on social media? Are you tired of false information and rumors that are shared irresponsibly? Do you want to become a smarter reader and consumer of news?
Join our 12-week course "Intensive News Literacy 2019."  You will learn basic communication theory, practical skills to use tools to learn critical thinking skills for determining the truth of information, and how to evaluate news. Deadline for registration is 05:00 PM on 27/6/2019.  Register now:http://bit.ly/nli-2019-sign-up.

Wednesday we asked you if you need to be a US citizen before your child is born to transmit U.S. citizenship to your child. 

The correct answer is:  True.  In order to transmit U.S. citizenship to your child, you must be a U.S. citizen before the childâ€™s birth.  Detailed information is here: http://bit.ly/us-birth.  When you apply for your a CRBA at our office, please provide your U.S. Certificate of Naturalization or an expired U.S. passport issued before your child was born.  For more information, please visit: http://bit.ly/crba-vn.

Thank you for joining us these past few weeks for #ACSHCMC. If you still have questions, please contact us at: http://bit.ly/acsvn. Stay tuned next week when we will start posting more information about student visas!

Did you know #OurOcean covers more than 70% of the Earthâ€™s surface, supports billions of livelihoods worldwide, and provides more than half the oxygen we breathe through phytoplankton?  Unfortunately, the ocean is under tremendous pressure from illegal, unreported, and unregulated fishing and unsustainable fishing practices, marine debris, bycatch, and derelict fishing gear.  Here are 10 simple ways you can help our ocean!

We are pleased to announce the launch of the ASEAN Youth Social Journalism Contest 2019 exploring the theme of â€œthe importance of responsive and transparent government in their day-to-day lives, promoting the ideals of fairness, equity, and transparency in their communities and at the ASEAN regional levelâ€. 

Two members from each ASEAN country will be selected to travel to Brunei Darussalam, to attend a four-day workshop to develop and implement a social awareness activity in their respective countries. Attractive prizes await for the top three winners!

For more information: https://th.usembassy.gov/asean-youth-social-journalism-contest-2019/

story: U.S. Consulate General - Ho Chi Minh City updated their cover photo.

message:
Last week we asked you can U.S. citizens only receive their federal benefit payments via U.S. bank account or check. #ACSHCMC 

With 419 votes, 63% of you were right!  The correct answer is:  FALSE.  As of February 2018, International Direct Deposit (IDD) for U.S. payment of federal benefits is available in Vietnam.  With this method, your U.S. Social Security payments will be sent electronically to your Vietnamese bank account.  The U.S. Department of the Treasury can make payments to almost all banks in Vietnam, but only in Vietnamese Dong.  So please ensure that the payment account is in Vietnamese Dong and not in U.S. Dollars.  Any related questions should be directed to the Social Security Administration office in Manila at: http://bit.ly/ssamanila

Still have questions?  Contact us at: http://bit.ly/acsvn

#AmbassadorKritenbrink  I was honored to join a ground-breaking ceremony at Hoa My Elementary School in Phu Yen province.  This Pacific Partnership 2019 engineering project will add three classrooms to the school.  In addition to serving as classrooms for 75 students, they will also serve as shelters for 150 people during emergencies.  Through this project, our countries are working together, learning from each otherâ€™s experiences, and helping the people of Vietnam.

Yesterday, we asked you do immigrant visa applicants have to register their mailing address prior to the interview. #IVAndYou

To be able to receive their approved visa, each immigrant visa beneficiary that has been assigned a case number must visit: http://bit.ly/iv-register and follow the instructions to create their account and register their delivery address.  Otherwise, our office will NOT be able to deliver your visa to you.  #IVMonth

Success stories: Los Angeles.
Vehicle emissions are the #1 source of air pollution in Los Angeles, California. By requiring the use of catalytic converters, testing vehicle emissions, and establishing fuel-efficiency standards, the United States, and Los Angeles in particular, have much cleaner air now. Compared to 1960, average vehicle emissions have fallen by 99%!
#AirQualityAwarenessWeek

Yesterday we asked you if you should open the brown envelope with one corner cut to check the documents inside.

The correct answer is: FALSE.  All sealed brown envelopes must remain sealed and opened by the U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) officer at the port of entry.  If you attempt to enter the United States when these envelopes have been unsealed, you may have trouble at the port of entry.

If you accidentally open it, please contact our office immediately at: http://bit.ly/ivhcm

Thank you to everyone who participated in this week's quiz. We wish you all a great holiday! #IVMonth #IVAndYou

The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the U.S. Presidentâ€™s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR), and Vietnam celebrated the launch of pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) services at the Thuan An District Health Center outpatient clinic in Binh Duong and at the Pride Health Clinic in Ho Chi Minh City on April 18. #PrEP is a preventive medicine that, when taken daily, has been shown to reduce the risk of #HIV infection by up to 92%. CDC/PEPFAR is supporting Vietnam to scale up PrEP services to key populations in public and private settings.

The Consular Section is back this week for another round of Immigrant Visa tips and quizzes. Here is your #IVMONTH tip of the week: 

Many applicants wait until after their interview to check if their children are qualified under the Child Status Protection Act (CSPA). Donâ€™t let this be you!  Waiting to check CSPA can delay visa processing and provides no benefit to the applicant. If you have children who are over 21 years old, contact the Consulate AT LEAST 3 DAYS before your interview. #IVAndYou

Statement by Ambassador Kritenbrink on the Passing of Former President LÃª Äá»©c Anh:

The U.S. Mission in Vietnam expresses sincere condolences regarding the passing of LÃª Äá»©c Anh, former President of Vietnam. LÃª Äá»©c Anh served during normalization of bilateral relations between our two countries, leading to the deep partnership and friendship that our two nations enjoy today. We send our sympathies to LÃª Äá»©c Anhâ€™s family, his loved ones, and to the people of Vietnam.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Yesterday, we asked you is it true that you can bring your laptops or iPads with you to the Consulate

The correct answer is: FALSE.  Laptops, iPads, tablets, and other large devices are considered prohibited items and therefore they are NOT allowed inside the Embassy/Consulate premises.  In addition, we cannot store these items for you.   You may still bring smaller electronic devices, including mobile phones, but you will have to leave them at the security checkpoint before entering our offices.  Please plan accordingly!  Go retro for your entertainment needs and bring a book or magazine.

For more information, please visit our website at: http://bit.ly/no-items 

Thank you for participating! We hope to see you again next week for the Consular Updates. #IVAndYou and #IVMonth

Yesterday, we asked you is it true that if your Vietnamese name is â€œNguyen Thi Thu Trangâ€, the Given Name on your visa should be â€œTrang Thi Thuâ€.

The correct answer is: FALSE.  According to our regulations, we MUST print the visa based on the information on your Vietnamese passport.  If the Vietnamese passport shows the full name as: â€œNguyen Thi Thu Trangâ€, the visa will show â€œNguyenâ€ as Surname and â€œThi Thu Trangâ€ as Given name.  No adjustments can be made.  Other federal agencies, such as the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) and the Social Security Administration (SSA), are aware of this practice.  

Still have questions?  Contact us at: http://bit.ly/ivhcm
Thank you for participating! We hope to see you again next week for the Consular Updates. #IVAndYou and #IVMonth

This week, the U.S. Consulate Immigrant Visa (IV) Unit will be debunking common questions and misconceptions about the immigrant visa process. Stay tuned to find out tips on how to make your immigrant visa applicant process as smooth as possible! #IVMonth

Here is our first Tip of the Week  #IVandYou: 

Some applicants may now enjoy the convenience of electronic processing.  Just follow instructions you receive from the National Visa Center or the Consulate.  One useful tip: Look at your issued visa!  If thereâ€™s an annotation saying â€œIV DOCS IN CCDâ€, it means your visa was issued through the new electronic process, and you do not need to hand-carry a sealed envelope when you enter the United States.

Still confused?  Donâ€™t worry!  Contact us at http://bit.ly/ivhcm and weâ€™ll let you know what your next steps should be.

Our Maker Innovation Space made its debut at Can Tho University last Friday! USAID/Vietnam Mission Director Michael Greene, leaders of Can Tho University and guests from technology industries celebrated the inauguration of the Maker Innovation Space at the CTU campus.  The network of three BUILD IT Maker Innovation Spaces will help integrate project-based learning into the curriculum of Vietnamâ€™s technology and engineering university programs. The goal is to encourage the next generation of inventors and problem-solvers from the Mekong Delta region.

Register today for the FREE American English E-Teacher MOOC (Massive Open Online Course) on Teaching Grammar Communicatively. In this practice-oriented course, participants will explore how to adapt grammar instruction to meet their studentsâ€™ needs. This course will be offered between March 25 and June 17. Participants may log in and complete coursework at any time during this 12-week period. Visit https://www.aeeteacher.org/Self-paced_MOOCs to learn more.

Are you a CAT person? The U.S. Consulate General HCMC is urgently seeking eligible and qualified applicants for the position of Canine Awareness Technician (CAT).
Duties: 
- providing care and provisions to the U.S. Consulate General HCMC dog population.
- managing official trips for yearly vaccinations and check-ups. 
- creating viral dog-themed multimedia content for social media use and write songs to sing to the dogs.
Qualifications: 
- at least one year of progressively following and commenting on Vietnamâ€™s top dog-centric Facebook pages. 
- fluent in Vietnamese, English, and Dogspeak.
- ability to exercise judgment in dealing with spoiled puppies.
- ability to efficiently take photos of dogs for social media use.
-able to conduct taste tests to select the most delicious dog food.
Please submit a portfolio of your selfies with dogs and a recommendation letter from a dog (in English and Dogspeak) along with the application form. For more information, see https://vn.usembassy.gov/education-cuâ€¦/american-center-hcmc/
For more information, please note todayâ€™s date.

What can be better than enjoying coffee, donuts, and basketball on Friday morning? Come watch one of Americaâ€™s great annual sporting events, March Madness! Each year 68 U.S. universities compete for the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) basketball championship. The â€œSweet Sixteenâ€ is the quarter-final round. Deputy Public Affairs Officer, David Turnbull, will give a â€œMarch Madness 101â€ briefing starting at 9am.

Cherry Blossoms on National Mall with the D.C. Monument in view

The National Cherry Blossom Festival is a spring celebration in Washington, D.C., commemorating the March 27, 1912, gift of Japanese cherry trees from Mayor Yukio Ozaki of Tokyo City to the city of Washington, D.C. Mayor Ozaki donated the trees to enhance the growing friendship between the United States and Japan and also celebrate the continued close relationship between the two nations. Large and colorful helium balloons, floats, marching bands from across the country, music and showmanship are parts of the Festival's parade and other events.

The U.S. and Vietnamese governments, in partnership with the United States Institute of Peace, are holding a landmark event in Washington DC today at 8.30 pm (Vietnam Time) to examine the transformation from enemies into partners by the two countries since the end of the war in 1975. The Fubright Teaching Excellence and Achievement Program (Fulbright TEA) 2019
The U.S. Embassy Hanoi and the U.S. Consulate General Ho Chi Minh City are seeking qualified candidates for the Fulbright TEA program, including teachers of English, Social Studies, Mathematics, Science, or Special Education. Funded by the U.S. Department of State, Fulbright TEA provides secondary school teachers with unique opportunities to develop expertise in their subject areas, enhance their teaching skills, and increase their knowledge about the United States. Teachers who wish to apply for the program are invited to complete the application form and submit online by April 15, 2019. For full announcement, visit https://vn.usembassy.gov/education-culture/grants-and-scholarship-opportunities/

Applications are open until April 1, 2019.

Have you ever seen a Pangolin? Pangolins are the only mammals in the world with scales. When threatened, pangolins curl into a ball, shielding their body with their tough armor of scales. This behavior protects them from predators such as big cats. Unfortunately, it also makes it easier for humans to collect them, and pangolins are the most heavily trafficked mammals in the world. Vietnam banned pangolin trade in 2006, and since January 2017, all commercial trade in pangolins is banned worldwide. #SavePangolins #WorldPangolinDay

Happy #WorldPangolinDay!   Did you know this scaly animal is the most trafficked mammal on the planet?  All 8 species of pangolin, 4 in Asia and 4 in Africa, are at risk of extinction. Vietnam has two native types of pangolins: Manis Javanica and Manis Pentadactyla. The Manis Pentadactyla has almost disappeared in Vietnam. During the period of 2013-2016, more than 30 tonnes of pangolin scales and 2,600 pangolins were seized in Vietnam.  Pangolin scales are falsely believed to have medicinal value, and unfortunately their meat is considered a delicacy.  What can you do to help?  Donâ€™t eat pangolin or use pangolin products.  Learn and share more about this amazing animal and report wildlife crime! #We<3Pangolins https://bit.ly/2MQqUbD

Did you know that February is Black History Month in the U.S.? Dr. Carter G. Woodson, a Harvard University scholar, set this observance in motion many years ago -- in 1926. Denali ("The Great One") 

Denali, named Mount McKinley from 1917 until 2015, is the highest mountain peak in North America, with a summit elevation of 20,237 feet (6,168 m) above sea level. At some 18,000 ft (5,500 m), the base-to-peak rise is considered the largest of any mountain situated entirely above sea level.[7] Measured by topographic prominence, it is the third most prominent peak after Mount Everest and Aconcagua. Located in the Alaska Range in the interior of the U.S. state of Alaska, Denali is the centerpiece of Denali National Park and Preserve. (Wikipedia)

Whether you believe in Santa Claus or not, you can start tracking his path as he delivers gifts around the world thanks to the North American Aerospace Defense Command (NORAD).

NORAD is a United States and Canada bi-national organization that provides aerospace warning and aerospace control for North America, but for the past 64 years, every Christmas Eve, they track the purported route of Santa's sleigh as he delivers gifts around the world.

Follow Santa's route here: http://www.noradsanta.org.

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights proclaims 'everyone has the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion,' and the United States supports that belief throughout the world, including in Vietnam. I had the honor to visit Thich Nhat Hanh at the Tu Hieu Pagoda, and learn more about his teachings from his close followers. We discussed Thich Nhat Hanhâ€™s meditation 'Peace in Oneself, Peace in the World,' the importance of internal peace for outward reconciliation. Thanks also to Sister Chan Khong for spending time to talk with me and Consul General Mary Tarnowka at the Tu Hieu Pagoda.

The U.S. Consulate General in Ho Chi Minh City thanks AEON Vietnam for its collaboration in promoting U.S. fresh food products.  Vietnamese customers can buy varieties of fresh products from the U.S. such as fruits, meat and seafood at many supermarkets across the country.  Vietnamese consumers enjoy safe, high-quality food and beverage products from the United States. Some of the major items are tree nuts, dairy products, meat and poultry, seafood, fruits, prepared food and non-alcoholic beverages.

Would you be willing to risk your life to get an education?  Thatâ€™s what Malala did.  She advocated for educational opportunities for girls in Pakistan.  The Taliban tried to stop her, and shot her in the head.  Miraculously, she survived, and continues to promote education.  Read her inspiring story and understand the challenges that some girls must overcome as they strive for their right to an education.

Applications are now open for the 2019 #YSEALI Workshop on Eco & Sustainable Tourism! The Asia Foundation will be implementing this five-day workshop in the world heritage site of Luang Prabang, Laos, March 4-8, 2019. We are looking for actively engaged students, entrepreneurs and young professionals, age 18-35, from across ASEAN, who are interested in promoting ecotourism. Interested? You will learn best practices through a hands-on tour of eco projects in one of the worldâ€™s most beautiful boutique tourism cities. You will also learn from some of the best minds in the region, and network with other young leaders from across ASEAN. You wonâ€™t want to miss this opportunity! Deadline is December 15th. Click here to apply:https://bit.ly/2QqvilN #YSEALIecotourism

** If you have question(s) for speakers, please send your questions in the comment box below the Facebook post.

 

HÃ m Tráº§n is a Vietnamese American film writer, editor and director. Tran received his MFA in Directing from the UCLA School of Film and Television, where his short films won numerous accolades including the title of National Finalist for the Student Academy AwardsÂ® for his short films The Prescription (2000) and Pomegranate (2001). In the spring of 2006 Tran premiered his first feature film, Journey from the Fall, at the prestigeous Sundance Film Festival. This film went on to receive 16 international film festival awards for Best Feature Film. In 2012, Tran began to direct films in Vietnam. â€œAm Muu Giay Got Nhonâ€ (How to Fight In Six Inch Heels), received the Silver Kite award for Best Director in 2014 at the Golden Kite Awards in Hanoi, Vietnam. The success of â€œSix Inch Heelsâ€ was quickly followed by Tranâ€™s 2014 horror film, â€œÄoáº¡t Há»“nâ€ (Hollow). This film did so well in the box office that it paved the way for the horror film genre in Vietnam. Tran continues to pioneer new paths in 2015 with the release of â€œSieu Tromâ€ (The Bitcoin Heist), Vietnamâ€™s first heist film. This film was very well received by audiences and film critics, and has found an occult audience in Vietnam. In 2016, Tran remade Thailandâ€™s box office hit, â€œATM Errorâ€ for local Vietnamese audience, retitled â€œBan Gai Toi La Sepâ€ (Sheâ€™s the Boss).

 With many projects under his belt including a TV series, music videos and short films, viral concepts and commercials, Danny Do is becoming a sought-after visionary director in the Vietnamese entertainment industry. Since 2006, Danny has been heavily involved in the industry, directing and producing projects with successful viewer counts. He is known for his work on ChÃ­ PhÃ¨o Ngoáº¡i Truyá»‡n, Em cá»§a ngÃ y hÃ´m qua (SÆ¡n TÃ¹ng MTP), OST Em lÃ  bÃ  ná»™i cá»§a anh, Invincible by Há»“ Ngá»c HÃ , YÃªu Ä‘i Ä‘á»«ng sá»£ (Only C) and many more.

Vice President Pence met with Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc of Vietnam to reaffirm the United States-Vietnam Comprehensive Partnership. Noting the 25th anniversary of normalized diplomatic relations in 2020, they agreed to strengthen bilateral cooperation across economic and security realms, including by addressing barriers to trade and by enhancing maritime security cooperation in the South China Sea. The Vice President thanked Vietnam for its cooperation on recovery operations of missing U.S. personnel and for supporting the pressure campaign on North Korea. They agreed to work together to promote shared principles for a free and open Indo-Pacific. The Vice President appreciated the Prime Ministerâ€™s invitation to visit Vietnam in 2019.

Announcement for USDA's FY19 Borlaug Fellowship Program.

The Borlaug Fellowship was established in 2004 in honor of Norman E. Borlaug, the American agronomist, humanitarian, and Nobel laureate known as the "father of the Green Revolution."  The Fellowship provides early to mid-career agricultural economists, research scientists, faculty, and policymakers with one-on-one training opportunities at a university or research institute in the US on specific topics.

The application deadline is December 31, 2018.
More detail: https://goo.gl/ZdbNoy

A panel of experts will discuss a critical challenge that startups face across the globe - how to secure funding to sustain and scale their ventures on November 13, at 11 pm Vietnam time.  Throughout the life cycle of a startup, entrepreneurs need different kinds of funding, from different kinds of investors. Whether theyâ€™re just launching and need angel investors, or are preparing to raise their Series B round from growth investors, start-ups need to understand the differences between each type of investment to successfully raise money and ultimately achieve sustainability. Join our panel of expert, active investors as they dive into each form of investing, discuss strategies for engaging investors, and provide tips on how to close your investment round.

Americans in District 2, it's your turn! We are coming to Saigon Outcast at 6pm tonight. Join us in celebrating the greatest American tradition ahead of Election Day. Get a 10% off drink voucher when you submit your Absentee Ballot. #ProudOverseasVoter #Vote2018

The American Center will be closed on Tuesday, October 30 for internal events. The American Center will resume normal hours on Wednesday, October 31

Speaker: Alexandria Cahill and Hansali Alvarez, Fulbrighters 

There are 325 million Americans living in 50 states â€“ and every one of those states has different needs, each city and town approaches things in its own way. We have a panel with a variety of experience in the American Center on October 29th from 5:00-7:00 pm to discuss some of the issues Americans are considering in the mid-term election next month.

We are heading into the final countdown for US 2018 Election Day! We've got a lot of events this week to help make sure your #Vote2018 counts. First up in the line up of events: Last Call for Ballots Voting Party. 

Join us at Pasteur Street Brewing Company at 6pm tonight! Ask all your voting questions and do your civic duty, while enjoying some delicious brews.

I have long been impressed with the diversity of religion in Vietnam.  I have visited many of the religious sites across Vietnam, and enjoyed talking to people of many faiths.  Religion adds to the richness of Vietnamese culture.  Today we celebrate International Religious Freedom Day and reaffirm our belief that all people deserve to live according to their conscience: to be free to worship, practice, share, change, and express their beliefs as they see fit.  Thank you, Vietnam, for sharing your religious customs with me. #CGTarnowka

Statement from the U.S. Embassy on Vietnamâ€™s Conviction of Five Activists
We are deeply concerned that a Vietnamese court has convicted five Vietnamese activists, including Luu Van Vinh and Nguyen Van Duc Do to jail terms ranging from eight to 15 years under the vague charges of â€œattempting to overthrow the peopleâ€™s administration.â€

The trend of increased arrests and harsh sentences for peaceful activists since early 2016 is deeply troubling. Vietnam has convicted over 30 peaceful activists thus far in 2018, significantly above last yearâ€™s number.

The United States calls on Vietnam to release all prisoners of conscience, and to allow all individuals in Vietnam to express their views freely without fear of retribution.

We also urge the Vietnamese government to ensure its actions and laws, including the Penal Code, are consistent with the human rights provisions of Vietnamâ€™s constitution and its international obligations and commitments.

Statement from President Donald J. Trump on the Passing of President Tran Dai Quang of Vietnam

It was with sadness that I learned of the passing of President Tran Dai Quang. On behalf of the American people, I express my condolences to his family and the people of Vietnam.

President Quang was a great friend of the United States. He graciously hosted me during my historic state visit to Hanoi in November 2017, and I am grateful for his personal commitment to deepening the United States-Vietnam Comprehensive Partnership. We will not soon forget his contributions to peace, security, and prosperity in the Indo-Pacific region or his voice for Vietnam as a proud and independent nation on the world stage.

Daniel Kritenbrink

On behalf of the U.S. Mission in Vietnam, I would like to express our sincere condolences on the passing of President Tran Dai Quang. Our sympathies go out to his family and the people of Vietnam at this sad time. President Tran Dai Quang was a friend of the U.S.-Vietnam relationship. His hosting of President Donald J. Trumpâ€™s historic state visit to Hanoi in November 2017 helped advance the U.S.-Vietnam Comprehensive Partnership to new heights on the basis of mutual understanding, shared interests, and a common desire to promote peace, cooperation, prosperity, and security in the Indo-Pacific region.

We honor his legacy and mourn his loss alongside his family and our friends, the people of Vietnam.

Very truly yours,
Daniel Kritenbrink

Statement by HEATHER NAUERT, SPOKESPERSON
 
International Day of Democracy
 
On this International Day of Democracy, the United States reaffirms its unwavering belief in democracy as the form of government with the greatest capacity to advance peace, prosperity, and security, and to safeguard the universal human rights, fundamental freedoms, and dignity of every person.  Enshrined in our own Constitution are bedrock principles essential to the success of any democracy, including freedom of expression, the right to peaceful assembly, respect for the rule of law, and a commitment to the peaceful transfer of political power through free and fair elections.
 
Democratic ideals are at the core of our foreign policy.  Established democracies are our closest allies and our strongest partners in meeting global challenges.  We do not stand idly by when governments curtail the rights of their citizens and work to undermine public faith in democratic processes and institutions.  As history demonstrates, those who imperil the rights of their own people are prone to endanger the lives of other people.  That is why we stand with people everywhere who call upon their governments to respect individual rights and freedoms, strengthen the rule of law, prevent and combat corruption, and honor the will of the people as expressed at the ballot box.
 
On this day, and every day, we join like-minded governments, civil society, and ordinary people in our shared commitment to promote, protect, and advance democratic values around the world.

Statement from the U.S. Embassy on Vietnam's Conviction of Peaceful Activist Nguyen Trung Truc

We are deeply concerned that a Vietnamese court has convicted Nguyen Trung Truc to 12 years in prison and 5 yearsâ€™ probation under vague charges of â€œattempting to overthrow the peopleâ€™s administration.â€
The trend of increased arrests and harsh sentences for peaceful activists in Vietnam is troubling. We note that Vietnam has convicted some 25 peaceful activists in 2018 alone.
The United States calls on Vietnam to release all prisoners of conscience immediately and to allow all individuals in Vietnam to express their views freely and assemble peacefully without fear of retribution.
We also urge the Vietnamese government to ensure its actions and laws, including the Penal Code, are consistent with the human rights provisions of Vietnamâ€™s constitution and its international obligations and commitments.

Congratulations to members of the American Centerâ€™s Media Literacy Course for becoming experts in detecting disinformation.  Through eleven weeks of workshops, seminars, guest speakers, and group work, this group of Vietnamese students learned about bias in media: how to identify it, and how to counter it.  Everyone should use critical thinking to assess and evaluate what they read in the media, both in print and online.  Follow us to learn about upcoming media literacy events at the American Center.

If you didnâ€™t have any painful memories, would you be happier?  Would you like to be â€œfreeâ€ from bad feelings?  That sounds like a good idea, but the author of â€œThe Giverâ€ thinks that there would be some negative effects.  Lois Lowry imagines a world where people donâ€™t have the burden of enduring emotional pain.  That world is peaceful, but also lack any emotional depth.  When a book wins a prestigious award, but at the same time, some people want to ban it, you know that the book has power.  â€œThe Giverâ€ is easy to read, and also delivers a powerful message.
You can find this book at American Center Library with call number FLOW

Are you an entrepreneur who wants to leverage your profits and have a positive impact in your community? Do you have an idea for a tech startup you think could earn you money while helping others? Secretary of State Mike Pompeo:

On behalf of the Government of the United States of America, I am honored to congratulate the ten member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the ASEAN Secretariat on the organizationâ€™s 51st anniversary on August 8th. For over 40 years, U.S.-ASEAN engagement has helped foster a stable, prosperous, and peaceful Southeast Asia. I welcome ASEANâ€™s role as a centerpiece of the Indo-Pacificâ€™s regional architecture and its contributions to a free and open Indo-Pacific region. 

The United States is proud to support collaborative programs with ASEAN to advance the rules-based order and address shared concerns over the regionâ€™s most pressing challenges, including maritime security, terrorism, cybersecurity, and other transnational issues. Our U.S.-ASEAN Connect framework is a testament to our commitment to ASEANâ€™s economic integration and our cooperation in business, energy, and innovation remains expansive and mutually beneficial. Our ongoing support for the Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative (YSEALI) and other cultural, academic, and professional exchanges demonstrates the importance of building both local capacity and dynamic, meaningful people-to-people ties. 

I congratulate ASEAN once again on its 51st anniversary and anticipate many more years of friendship and collaboration with ASEAN and the peoples of Southeast Asia.

# EducationUSA 

Are you looking for ways to pay less for college in the United States? If yes, a high school completion program could be one of your options. Join us for an information session on July 19 to learn more about high school completion programs in the United States as well as various pathways that this program can lead you to.

Twenty-six nations, 46 surface ships, five submarines, 18 national land forces, and more than 200 aircraft and 25,000 personnel will participate in the biennial Rim of the Pacific (RIMPAC) exercise, the world's largest international maritime exercise, scheduled June 27 to Aug. 2, in and around the Hawaiian Islands and Southern California. This is the first time Vietnam is participating in RIMPAC. You can see a number of photos from RIMPAC in 2014 and 2016 here: #RIMPAC

"Together, we are going to make a difference in the lives of these young scientists that will have an impact throughout the entire Lower Mekong region for years to come." - Jose Quiroga, Associate Director, Global Outreach and Extended Education Arizona State University
Funded by the U.S. State Department, the Lower Mekong Initiative and implementing partner Arizona State University launched the LMI Young Scientist Exchange Program with 25 talented participants from 5 countries. The 2018 theme is Water, Energy, and Environmental Sustainability.  This is an exciting opportunity to collaborate with young scientists throughout the region and allow participants to apply the skills that they learn toward research initiatives and technology development. Stay tuned for further updates!

The U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) has just announced the funding for two more projects in combating ocean plastic pollution in Vietnam, which are under the USAIDâ€™s Municipal Waste Recycling Program (MWRP). The first project titled: â€œLessons learned from demonstrated municipal plastic waste management in World Heritage Site Ha Long Bay,â€ with a planned budget of $129,738, aims to address gaps in the existing municipal solid waste management system in the city, especially in the waste collection and disposal. The second one, themed â€œComparative pilot water-way municipal plastic waste management practices for reducing marine plastic pollution in coastal World Biosphere Reserve of Nam Dinh, has a planned budget of $249,995. The MWRP, being funded by the USAID in the 2016-2021 period, is designed to reduce land-based sources of marine plastic pollution in Sri Lanka, the Philippines, Vietnam, and Indonesia. So far, the MWRP has funded five projects in Vietnam.
