Applying for a U.S. student visa? Congratulations! Youâ€™re about to start a very rewarding experience! Here are some important things to remember for your interview. After you are admitted into a U.S. university program, you will receive a form I-20 or DS-2019 from the university; bring the originally signed form to your visa interview. Then at the interview you will be asked why you want to study at this university and how you plan to pay for your studies, so be ready. DONâ€™T FORGET: any false information on your application or using fake documents can result in permanent ineligibility for a U.S. visa. Check our website: http://www.ustraveldocs.com/vn/vn-niv-visaapply.asp , for information on how to apply.

â€#ConsulGeneralTarnowka On June 25, 2018, the United States presented a Disaster Management Coordination Center (DMCC) to the People's Committee of Khanh Hoa Province. The event was presided over by Ms. Mary Tarnowka, U.S. Consul General, and ÄÃ o CÃ´ng ThiÃªn, Vice Chairman. This is one of eleven coordination centers that the U.S. and Vietnam are building together to â€strengthen Vietnamâ€™s response and resilience to disasters in its coastal regions.  This center is a symbol of the close cooperation and support between the U.S. Mission, the U.S. Pacific Command, the Vietnamese government, and the Khanh Hoa Provincial Peopleâ€™s Committee.  Most importantly, this assistance reflects our commitment to supporting a strong, prosperous, and independent Vietnam and a free and open Indo-Pacific region.

The United States stands for the protection of fundamental freedoms and universal human rights. Our nation was founded on the bedrock principle that we are all created equal â€“ and that every person is entitled to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.

Around the world, far too many governments continue to arrest and abuse their citizens simply for being lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender or intersex (LGBTI). Fear and bigotry are enshrined in laws that criminalize LGBTI status or conduct in more than 70 countries. In some, being LGBTI is punishable by death.

The United States firmly opposes criminalization, violence and serious acts of discrimination such as in housing, employment and government services, directed against LGBTI persons. We use public and private diplomacy to raise human rights concerns, provide emergency assistance to people at risk, and impose visa restrictions and economic sanctions against those who persecute them.

On the International Day Against Homophobia, Transphobia, and Biphobia, the United States stands with people around the world in affirming the dignity and equality of all people regardless of sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, or sex characteristics. Human rights are universal, and LGBTI people are entitled to the same respect, freedoms, and protections as everyone else.

â€” Secretary of State Pompeo

message:
Funded by the U.S. State Department, the Lower Mekong Initiative and implementing partner Arizona State University are pleased to announce the LMI Young Scientist Exchange Program. The 2018 theme is Water, Energy, and Environmental Sustainability. If you are a Master's or PhD student in fields related to this year's theme, we invite you to apply today! 
 
This is an exciting opportunity to collaborate with young scientists throughout the region and learn skills you can apply toward research initiatives and technology development.
 
Learn more about #LMIYoungScientist and apply here: goo.gl/yYc2dy

Congratulations to Ngá»¥y Thá»‹ Khanh, founder of GreenID, on winning the 2018 Goldman Environmental Prize, the worldâ€™s largest award for grassroots environmental activists! Ms. Khanh earned this honor for advocating for sustainable energy projections and a reduction in coal power use in Vietnam. She is the first person from Vietnam to win this prize. 115 million tons of carbon dioxide emissions has been eliminated from Vietnam annually thanks to her efforts. Awarded annually to environmental heroes from around the world, the 2018 Goldman Environmental Prize honorees are from Colombia, France, Vietnam, the Philippines, South Africa, and the United States.

We all can be better stewards of our environment in three simple steps:  reduce, re-use, recycle.  We all use plastics every day, and so we all have a role to play in reducing our plastics use.  
â€¢ Do you need an extra plastic bag at the supermarket? Or can you bring your own? 
â€¢ Do you need a plastic cup and straw at the bubble tea shop?  Or can you bring your own mug?
â€¢ Do you reuse plastic bags or throw them away?
â€¢ Do you separate your food waste from the rest of your garbage?  What about other recyclables?

What else can we do?

The U.S. Mission in Vietnam is offering scholarships for 3-4 participants to attend the East-West Centerâ€™s 6th International Media Conference in Singapore from June 24-27, 2018. Applications due by noon on April 17.

The East-West Centerâ€™s International Media Conferences bring together exceptional keynote speaker and in-depth panels of journalists and experts to discuss issues in international media. This yearâ€™s theme is â€œWhat is News Nowâ€ â€“ a look at how of media, technology, and social change have disrupted the business of news and storytelling. Speakers will focus on forces that are re-shaping todayâ€™s world and the way we report it, such as artificial intelligence, digitalization, social media, â€œfake news,â€ attacks on the free press, bit data, and more. For more information, please see the conference website: https://www.ewcmedia.org/singapore2018/2018/02/06/registration-now-open/#more-248

The U.S. Mission in Vietnam will cover registration fees, lodging / breakfast, and flight to Singapore. (Note: Offers to cost-share flights will be received favorably.) All other costs will be borne by participant. 
Applicants must:
- Be a working-level reporter or editor at an established news outlet in Vietnam
- Have a minimum of 5 yearsâ€™ experience in Journalism
- Be a Vietnamese Citizen
- Be proficient in English
Applicants should send English-language CV and Statement of Interest (500 words or less) to HCMCPRESS@STATE.GOV no later than noon on Tuesday, April 17. Successful candidates may be subject to interview.

Statement by State Department Spokesperson Heather Nauert: The United States is deeply troubled that a Vietnamese court has convicted and sentenced peaceful activists Nguyen Van Dai, Le Thu Ha, Pham Van Troi, Nguyen Trung Ton, Nguyen Bac Truyen and Truong Minh Duc to harsh prison sentences under the vague charge of â€œactivities aimed at overthrowing the peopleâ€™s administration.â€ We note with concern that Vietnamese authorities held Nguyen Van Dai and Le Thu Ha in pre-trial detention for over two years.

Individuals have the right to the fundamental freedoms of expression, association, and peaceful assembly, both online and offline. The United States is deeply concerned by the Vietnamese governmentâ€™s efforts to restrict these rights, through a disturbing trend of increased arrests, convictions, and harsh sentences of peaceful activists.

The United States calls on Vietnam to release all prisoners of conscience immediately, and to allow all individuals in Vietnam to express their views freely and assemble peacefully without fear of retribution.

We also urge the Vietnamese government to ensure its actions and laws, including the Penal Code, are consistent with the human rights provisions of Vietnamâ€™s Constitution, and Vietnamâ€™s international obligations and commitments

The Student and Exchange Visitor Program (SEVP), part of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcementâ€™s (ICE) Homeland Security Investigations (HSI), launched a revamped Guide to Studying in the States. This updated educational tool allows users to create a customized guide with information on the international student life cycle specific to their visa type (F-1 or M-1) and education level. Each guide contains information about preparing to enter the United States, traveling, studying, student benefits, change of status and departing the United States. Users can skip directly to a specific section in each guide or print a custom guide based on their selections.

LUNAR NEW YEAR â€œTETâ€ 2018 HOLIDAY SCHEDULE

The Consulate Generalâ€™s Immigrant Visa Unit will be closed from Wednesday, February 14 through Tuesday, February 20 2018 for the Lunar New Year (Tet) holidays. IV applicants who have been asked to submit additional documents should not plan on returning to the Consulate to submit documents during this time. In addition, the IV Unit will not be open for document submission on the afternoon of Tuesday February 13. The Immigrant Visa Unit will resume normal business hours on Wednesday, February 21.

The Immigrant Visa Unit will continue conducting visa interviews until February 13, 2018. However, please expect a delay in the delivery of your visa due to the Tet closure.  If you have an urgent need to travel, please notify our office at the time of your interview.

We appreciate your understanding and wish you a happy lunar new year.

To ensure sufficient time to process services for U.S. citizens, especially processing and returning passports before Tet, we ask that you please follow the schedule below for submitting applications and picking up your new passports:

If you apply for a passport on or after February 05, 2018, please expect that your new passport will not be available until after the Tet holidays.

The Consular offices will continue accepting passport applications and will be open for passport pick up through February 12, 2018.

For Tet holidays, most Government of Vietnam offices, including city and provincial offices, will also be closed. Please note that we will be unable to provide non-emergency U.S. Citizen and visa services during this time.

If you are contacting us regarding a true emergency involving the safety or security of a U.S. citizen, please call:
The U.S. Embassy 24/7 switchboard at (84-24) 3850-5000 within Vietnam, or (011) (84-24) 3850-5000 from the U.S.

U.S. CONSULATE GENERAL HO CHI MINH CITY - NONIMMIGRANT VISA UNIT

LUNAR NEW YEAR â€œTETâ€ 2018 HOLIDAY SCHEDULE

The Nonimmigrant Visa Unit of the U.S. Consulate General Ho Chi Minh City will not be open to the public from Tuesday, February 13, 2018 through Tuesday, February 20, 2018 for the Lunar New Year (Tet) holidays.

The Nonimmigrant Visa Unit will reopen to the public on Wednesday, February 21, 2018.

The Nonimmigrant Visa Unit will continue processing visa renewals until February 13, 2018. However, if you applied for a visa on or after February 8, 2018, please expect that your passport will be delivered to you after the Tet holiday.

The U.S. Embassy in Vietnam announces the Fulbright Vietnamese Student Scholarship Program.  The scholarship will cover tuition and fees, monthly stipend, round-trip airfare to the United States and health insurance.

On the third Monday of January, Americans honor the life and achievements of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., (1929â€“1968), the 1964 Nobel Peace laureate and the individual most associated with the triumphs of the African-American civil rights movement during the 1950s and 1960s. As political organizer, supremely skilled orator and advocate of nonviolent protest, King was pivotal in persuading his fellow Americans to end the legal segregation that prevailed throughout the South and parts of other regions, and in sparking support for the civil rights legislation that established the legal framework for racial equality in the United States. Learn more here: https://share.america.gov/topics/martin-luther-king-jr/

Reduced Afternoon Schedule for Immigrant Visa Unit  - December 2017

For the remainder of December, the Immigrant Visa (IV) Unit will hold afternoon business hours only on December 14, 18, 19, 21, 26 and 28. Applicants who have already been interviewed and who have an official (blue) letter from the Consulate directing them to submit additional documents may submit them between 1:00 and 2:00 on these days. We regret any inconvenience caused. The IV Unit expects to return to its usual afternoon hours in January: 1:00 to 2:00 on every non-holiday weekday except Wednesday, unless otherwise noted.

Do you know that December 3, 2017 marks the 4th anniversary of Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative (YSEALI)? Each year the U.S. Mission to Vietnam nominates more than100 young people, like you, for the #YSEALI fellowships in the U.S. as well as regional workshops. #YSEALI builds the leadership capabilities of youth in the region and promotes cross-border cooperation to solve regional and global challenges and there are more than 21,000 members in Vietnam right now. Do you have great ideas to support the community? Join #YSEALI today! https://asean.usmission.gov/yseali/ 
#YSEALI

Ms. Ho is a social activist and an ally of the local LGBT community as well as people living with HIV. TG women are a new focus population in the HIV response in the country. Black Friday is on!
What is Black Friday? Black Friday refers to the day after Thanksgiving Day, and is traditionally the beginning of the Christmas shopping season. It is also a term to indicate that most retailers will begin to turn a profit because of heavy sales traffic - and hence are "in the black."

Consular Quiz of the Week: I have received my visitor B1/B2 visa. How soon can I travel to the United States?

The correct answer is: You may choose to visit the U.S. any time before your visa expires. A nonimmigrant visa grants permission to travel to a port of entry in the United States. For every trip to the United States, the U.S. Customs and Border Protection officer at the port of entry determines how long you can stay. Learn more about the visa application process here: http://www.ustraveldocs.com/vn_vn/index.html

Security Message for U.S. Citizens: Typhoon Damrey November 3, 2017

The U.S. Consulate Ho Chi Minh City cautions U.S. citizens that Typhoon Damrey is forecasted to make landfall Friday night into Saturday morning, November 3 or 4, between Nha Trang and Phan Rang-Thap Cham in the southern coastal region of Vietnam. The U.S. Navyâ€™s Joint Typhoon Warning Center forecasts that the storm will strengthen slightly as it approaches land before rapidly weakening as it passes over southern Vietnam, and central Cambodia by November 5.  Expect very high winds, dangerous storm tides, heavy rainfall, and possible flooding to occur.

All U.S. citizens living in or traveling to the area should monitor local weather reports, follow directions from local officials, and take other appropriate actions as needed.

The State of Alabama will conduct a special primary runoff election on Tuesday, September 26, 2017, for the office of U.S. Senator to replace Jeff Sessions. A special primary election was held on August 15, 2017. With no candidate receiving more than 50% of the vote, a special primary runoff election will now be held on September 26, 2017. If you are a resident of Alabama, register and request an absentee ballot today starting at www.FVAP.gov.

One of our YSEALI Academic Fellows, Pham Hoang Man, shared: â€œEvery moment passed in America, I found a lesson for my life. I have overcome myself to step on this miraculous country, gaining new experience from my beloved ASEAN fellows. There are many places awaiting me to discover, many people awaiting to teach me new lessons, and many challenges awaiting me to overcome.  YSEALI has taught me to be determined with the path I have chosen, to be brave when facing with difficulties and to be smart when solving any problem. YSEALI has endowed me once-in-a-lifetime opportunities to learn and grow as a prospective leader of my community. Thanks YSEALI for everything!!!â€ #ysealiexperience
Want to have this wonderful opportunity through a YSEALI Academic Fellowship in Spring 2018? APPLY NOW here: https://goo.gl/vnTRFU

Did you know that Vietnam, along with the United States, and 23 other countries voted to support a landmark United Nations resolution on human rights, sexual orientation and gender identity? The U.N. Human Rights Council Resolution, adopted by a vote of 25 in favor, 14 against and seven abstentions, marks another important chapter in United Nationsâ€™ efforts to stand united against the human rights abuses that LGBT individuals face around the world. Come learn about some the difficulties facing the LGBTI community in the U.S. and show your support for LGBTI individuals around the world.

Attention American Citizens!
Alabama Special General Election Scheduled for December 12

The State of Alabama will conduct a special general election on Tuesday, December 12, 2017, for the office of U.S. Senator to replace Jeff Sessions.

Service members, eligible family members and overseas citizens may use the Federal Post Card Application (FPCA), which is the registration and ballot request form accepted by all States and territories. Complete, sign and send the FPCA to your election office. If you are a resident of Alabama, register and request an absentee ballot today starting at FVAP.gov.

Each year, the number of immigrant visas in the family-sponsored preference (F1, F2, F3, and F4) and employment-based preference categories is limited. There are no more visas available in most of these categories until the new fiscal year. Applicants in these visa categories who have been told they will be issued a visa and have not yet received a visa may need to wait until the new fiscal year to receive their visa. The new fiscal year begins on October 1, 2017. For further information, please visit the Department of Stateâ€™s website.

Planning to #StudyInTheUS but apprehensive about making friends there? Youâ€™ll be happy to know that many colleges and universities across the U.S. have buddy programs that help international students settle in and connect with their peers. Whether itâ€™s finding the closest grocery store or a restaurant that serves the kind of food you love, your buddy will help you figure it all out. So the next time youâ€™re researching the American college of your dreams, check out its buddy program, too!

Have you filed a K-1 visa petition for your fiancÃ©/ fiancÃ©e? K-1 petitions are only valid for four months! The I-129F petition is valid for four months from the date of approval from USCIS. The validity of the I-129F petition will be routinely extended by consular officers to ensure that applicants have sufficient time to complete the processing of their case. For more information, visit:  http://www.ustraveldocs.com/vn/vn-iv-kvisa.asp

Did you know that Patriot Day , also known as National Day of Service and Remembrance, is observed every September 11th to honor the memory of those that lost their lives in the 2001 September 11th attacks? Americans typically mark this day by flying the U.S. flag at half-staff, observing a moment of silence at 8:46 a.m. Eastern Standard Time, and volunteering in their communities. Click here to see how this day has been marked in the past: https://www.flickr.com/photos/iip-photo-archive/sets/72157658069751802

In September, there will be a retrogression of cut-off dates in the family preference visa categories for Unmarried Sons and Daughters of U.S. Citizens (F-1) and Brothers and Sisters of Adult U.S. Citizens (F-4). Accordingly, in September, all F-1 petitions filed on or after May 1, 2010 and all F-4 petitions filed on or after January 1, 2002 will be considered non-current; a visa cannot be issued for these cases until the priority date becomes current again.

VOLUNTEERS RECRUITMENT

Calling all Volunteers in Ho Chi Minh City and Can Tho!  

An opportunity to practice your English with American university representatives and support educational opportunities for Vietnamese students.

EducationUSA Advising Center is seeking volunteers to help with EducationUSA Fairs in Fall 2017!

Date & Time:
Ho Chi Minh City:  Tuesday, October 3, 2017 * 15:00 â€“ 18:00 
Can Tho: Wednesday, October 4, 2017 * 15:00 â€“ 18:00

Requirements
- Current high school and university students in Ho Chi Minh city, and Can Tho. 
- Good command of spoken English
- Responsible, sociable and active 
- Experience in interpreting and/or a good understanding of U.S. higher education is preferred.

Responsibilities
- Assist with marketing for the event
- Work as interpreters for higher education representatives
- Assist at check-in desk

Volunteers will be trained and receive a stipend. 

Apply
Send your cover letter and CV to HCMCEDUSA@state.gov by September 4, 2017. 
Only short-listed applicants will be contacted.

On August 26, 1920, the 19th Amendment was certified, securing for women the fundamental right to vote.  The product of decades spent organizing, protesting, and agitating, it was a turning point on the long march toward equality for all, and it inspired generations of courageous women who took up this unfinished struggle in their own time.

In September, there will be a retrogression of cut-off dates in the family preference visa categories for Unmarried Sons and Daughters of U.S. Citizens (F-1) and Brothers and Sisters of Adult U.S. Citizens (F-4). Accordingly, in September, all F-1 petitions filed on or after May 1, 2010 and all F-4 petitions filed on or after January 1, 2002 will be considered non-current; a visa cannot be issued for these cases until the priority date becomes current again.

#VISAMYTHBUSTER: I have to be able to speak English well to study English in the United States.

FACT: Every applicant must be able to speak enough English to complete their planned course of study. We expect that many English as a Second Language (ESL) students will not be able to speak English well, and we do issue visas to such students. Like other student visa applicants, ESL students must demonstrate that they are credible students with sufficient finances and a plan to return to Vietnam after their studies are completed. Many of the most successful ESL students have completed English language courses in Vietnam before applying for a U.S. visa.

Training in HCMC:  Aug 7 â€“ 10, 2017
Training in Danang: Aug 14 â€“ 17, 2017
 
The U.S Consulate General in HCMC is proud to organize a Sound & Light training program for Vietnamese sound and light technicians who have at least two years experience and are eager to develop their skills in live sound & lighting engineering. The training will be led by three American Arts Envoys: Stephanie Mulligan â€“ Lighting Designer, Sharath Patel â€“ Sound Designer and DJ Verseatile.
 
The program not only aims at building capacity for the Vietnamese sound/light technicians but also create an opportunity for DJs to learn more about how sound and lighting can enhance music experience. The four-day training course is a combination of essential theory and hands-on practice where participants will be operating the latest sound & light equipment.
 
The U.S Consulate will recruit the participants based on their job knowledge, skills, experience, and interest and ability to work with the United States. Participants are required to fill out the application form by July 21.
Link to application: https://goo.gl/forms/nGERMg2giQMzEmYG3
 
The program will wrap up by a DJ performance featuring DJ Verseatile and local bands with light and sound designed by American experts promising to give audience a fun and enjoyable music experience. The performance will be on Aug 11 in HCMC and Aug 18 in Danang.  Stay tune!

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) expects five to eight tropical cyclones to affect the central Pacific this season.  If you are a U.S. Citizen traveling or residing in Vietnam, you may enroll in the Smart Traveler Enrollment Program (STEP) to receive safety messages and other travel information.  You should also have an emergency plan as even areas far from the coastline can experience dangerous winds, tornadoes, mudslides, and floods.  For more information on how to prepare for Vietnamâ€™s typhoon season, please visit the State Departmentâ€™s Natural Disaster webpage.

HÃ nh trÃ¬nh phi thÆ°á»ng cá»§a Solomon minh chá»©ng ráº±ng niá»m hy vá»ng vÃ  tinh tháº§n kiÃªn cÆ°á»ng con ngÆ°á»i sáº½ cÃ³ thá»ƒ vÆ°á»£t qua nhá»¯ng hoÃ n cáº£nh kiá»‡t quá»‡ vÃ  kinh khá»§ng nháº¥t. #ACBookoftheWeek

Perhaps the best written of all the slave narratives, 12 Years a Slave is a harrowing memoir about one of the darkest periods in American history. It recounts how Solomon Northup, born a free man in New York, was lured to Washington, D.C., in 1841 with the promise of fast money, then drugged and beaten and sold into slavery. He spent the next twelve years of his life in captivity on a series of Louisiana plantations. His extraordinary journey proves the resiliency of hope and the human spirit despite the most grueling and formidable of circumstances. #ACBookoftheWeek

On June 28, the Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor, in collaboration with IIP, will host a LGBTI Pride Month interactive webchat to discuss violence and discrimination targeting vulnerable groups, including LGBTI persons.
The panel discussion will also highlight best practices from law enforcement agencies and civil society groups, and strategies to respond to and prevent hate crimes. Audiences at post and American Spaces viewing groups, as well as online viewers around the world, will be able to ask the experts questions live on the streaming page: Share.America.gov/Pride-Month-Webchat.

California Special General Election Scheduled for June 6
The State of California will conduct a special general election on Tuesday, June 6, 2017, for the 34th Congressional District to replace Xavier Becerra who was confirmed as Attorney General of California.  This district consists of part of Los Angeles County. A primary election was held on April 4, 2017, with no candidate receiving more than 50% of the vote. Service members, eligible family members and overseas citizens may use the Federal Post Card Application (FPCA), which is the registration and ballot request form accepted by all States and territories. Complete, sign and send the FPCA to your election office. If you are a California resident from the 34th Congressional District, register and request an absentee ballot today starting at www.FVAP.gov.

Please remember that all U.S. consular officers make visa adjudication decisions based on the same rules and regulations, so if you apply again with the same information, you are likely to get the same result. However, if you have additional information or significant changes in your circumstances since your last interview, you may reapply for a visa. To reapply, you must complete a new application form, pay the application fee, and schedule an appointment for a new interview.  Additionally, advocacy and support by third parties, including employers, family, relatives, or any other individuals, companies, or organizations is not a consideration in the visa adjudication process.

The final panel in our series of Vietnamese-Americans living in HCMC will discuss the paths that led them to moving to Vietnam and their experiences living here. #VISAMYTHBUSTER: Working with a visa agent can increase your likelihood of getting a visa. WRONG! All adjudication decisions are made according to U.S. immigration laws and regulations. To ensure accuracy, we strongly recommend that people apply for a visa, including completing their visa application, on their own.

APPLY NOW: YSEALI GENERATION: ECOMMUNITY! - Workshop on Economic Engagement in ASEAN.

From August 1-4, 2017, 80 YSEALI members (aged 18-25) will come together to explore the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) and its impact on trade and sustainable growth. An exciting lineup of expert speakers will detail the key concepts and intricacies of the ASEAN economy, and participants will apply what they learn through a series of hands-on activities, including case studies, a model ASEAN Summit, and dialogues with business leaders, social entrepreneurs, and policymakers.
The YSEALI Generation: ECommunity! workshop is a tremendous opportunity for youth who have an economic or business background and desire to be at the forefront of economic development and social change to hone their ability to impact not only their communities but also ASEAN as a region.
Selected participants will be offered an all-expense-paid trip to join the four-day workshop in Hanoi, Vietnam. Visit the www.yseali-aec.org/ website for more information on the workshop and details on how to apply.

#VISAMYTHBUSTER: I can renew my U.S. visa via the Interview Waiver Program (IWP) when I am not in Vietnam. ANSWER: You must be present in Vietnam to renew at the U.S. Embassy in Hanoi or the U.S. Consulate General in HCMC. If you reside in another country, visit the U.S. Embassy/Consulate there. You can also wait to apply for a visa on your next trip to Vietnam.

message: The National Weather Service and EPA have designated May 1st to 5th, 2017 as Air Quality Awareness Week in the United States. This week serves to remind all of us the importance air quality and the significance of air quality forecasts in our daily lives.  Join us to learn how air quality affects your health during Air Quality Awareness Week.

Before appearing for your J-1 exchange visitor visa interview, you must pay your SEVIS (Student and Exchange Visitor Information System) fee. This is NOT a visa fee and the applicant should bring their SEVIS fee receipt with them for their interview.  SEVIS is a system which keeps record of all the foreign students currently studying in the United States. For more information, check out: https://www.ice.gov/sevis

#EducationUSAHoChiMinhCity The American Association for University Women recently reported that 53% of women have high student loan debt just one year after graduation, compared to 39% of men. Many women also face the added difficulties of trying to go to college for the first time later in life, returning to school after long gaps of time, and attaining a degree while being a single parent.

To help make college more accessible for them, college planning experts at OEDB.org developed two holistic financial aid guides specifically for women. It breaks down available grants, scholarships, and fellowships, along with useful tips and tricks: #
http://oedb.org/scholarships/women/
http://oedb.org/single-mother-grant/

Join a webchat to learn about different ways of seeing and thinking about our planet. Celebrate Earth Day 2017 by joining a discussion with people who capture data and images of our planet  that both astound and move people to protect the environment: https://goo.gl/h84Z8U

On April 21 at 3 p.m. EDT, a panel of experts will answer your questions on photographing our planet from satellites in space, drones in the air and pristine places on land. They will discuss the impact, both personal and societal, of seeing our planet from new perspectives.

ÄÃ¢y lÃ  cuá»‘n sÃ¡ch tÃ´i yÃªu thÃ­ch nháº¥t vÃ¬ nÃ³ Ä‘an xen lá»‹ch sá»­ Ä‘á»‹a phÆ°Æ¡ng vá»›i nhá»¯ng cÃ¢u chuyá»‡n hay vÃ  miá»‡u táº£ thiÃªn nhiÃªn tuyá»‡t Ä‘áº¹p.

John Graves takes a nostalgic canoe trip down the Brazos River, which starts in the plains of North Texas, runs through the cedar breaks and rolling hills of Central Texas, verdant pastures and farmland of Southeast Texas and finally into the Gulf of Mexico. He relives the history of Texas as it was shaped by the Brazos before it lost its continuity to a series of dams and man-made reservoirs. This is my favorite book because it weaves together local history with good story telling and beautiful nature writing.

Visa MythBuster: During the visitor (B1/B2) visa interview, itâ€™s better not to mention that you have close family members who reside in the United States. Answer: Thatâ€™s a MYTH! Some applicants think that having a family member in the United States will cause their U.S. visitor visa to be denied. However, visiting family is common and certainly one of the many reasons for legitimate travel. If you are planning to visit family or relatives, tell us! #USvisa

Former president Barack Obama wrote this book as a letter of encouragement and love for his two daughters. In it, he tells the stories of several important historical figures, focusing on the personal traits that allowed them to distinguish themselves, and explaining that those traits are also present in his children. Each time I read this book I rediscover my patriotism and am reminded that with each new generation America truly does become a more perfect union.

I remember at first resisting the novel, trying to find a way to dislike it.  But by the time Starks hit Janie, I found myself empathizing with Janieâ€™s plightâ€”and connecting the underlying social, racial, and gender problems of the 20th century to the present day. The poignancy of this novel and its setting in my native Florida left an impression not reduced by time.

Montana Special Election Scheduled for May 25
The State of Montana will conduct a special election on Thursday, May 25, 2017, for its at-large Congressional District to replace Ryan Zinke who was confirmed as the U.S. Secretary of the Interior.  This district represents all counties in Montana.

Service members, eligible family members and overseas citizens may use the Federal Post Card Application (FPCA), the registration and ballot request form accepted by all States and territories. Complete, sign and send the FPCA to your election office. If you are a Montana resident, register and request an absentee ballot today starting at FVAP.gov.

#VISAMYTH BUSTER: Myth: Once you enter the U.S. on a fiancÃ© (e) visa, you will immediately become a Legal Permanent Resident. FACT: If you enter the U.S. on a fiancÃ© (e) visa, you must marry within 90 days. If you do not, you must leave the United States. After your marriage, you must file Form I-485 with U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services and pay an additional fee to apply for Lawful Permanent Residence. https://www.uscis.gov/i-485.

South Carolina Special Primary Election Scheduled for May 2
The State of South Carolina will conduct a special primary election on Tuesday, May 2, 2017, for the 5th Congressional District to replace Mick Mulvaney who was confirmed as the Director of the U.S. Office of Management and Budget. This district consists of Cherokee, Chester, Fairfield, Kershaw, Lancaster, Lee, Union, and York counties, and portions of Newberry, Spartanburg, and Sumter counties.

The special general election will be held on June 20.

Service members, eligible family members and overseas citizens may use the Federal Post Card Application (FPCA), which is the registration and ballot request form accepted by all States and territories. Complete, sign and send the FPCA to your election office. If you are a South Carolina resident from the 5th Congressional District, register and request an absentee ballot today starting at FVAP.gov.

It is always a pleasure to welcome Ambassador Ted Osius to Ho Chi Minh City, and last weekâ€™s trip was no exception! The Ambassador dropped by the Consular Section, where he helped our Consulate team provide services to U.S. Citizens.

Today, 2 billion people â€“ one fourth of the worldâ€™s population â€“ are infected with TB worldwide, with more than 10 million becoming ill and at risk for transmitting TB to others. In Vietnam over 140,000 people develop TB annually and there are almost 20,000 deaths. Vietnam is considered one of 30 high burden TB countries that together contribute to over 85% of the global TB burden. 
Please join us today for an informal discussion about TB and ways to prevent and reduce its spread. Dr. Van Anh will also share information on Vietnamâ€™s national TB strategy and what CDC is doing to support reduction of TB in Vietnam.
The event will start from 2:00PM THIS AFTERNOON.

Announcement - The Teaching Excellence and Achievement Program (TEA) 2018
The U.S. Embassy Hanoi and the U.S. Consulate General Ho Chi Minh City are seeking three qualified candidates for the 2018 Teaching Excellence and Achievement (TEA) Program, including teachers of English, Social Studies, Mathematics, Science, or Special Education. Funded by the U.S. Department of State, TEA provides high school teachers with unique opportunities to develop expertise in their subject areas, enhance their teaching skills, and increase their knowledge about the United States. Teachers who wish to apply for the program are invited to complete the application form and submit it online to the Public Affairs Section (PAS) by Saturday, April 15, 2017.
More information: https://vn.usembassy.gov/education-culture/grant-and-scholarship-opportunities/

Did you know U.S. Citizens are eligible to use Vietnamâ€™s new electronic visa (e-visa) program? The Government of Vietnamâ€™s program uses an official e-visa process to issue 30-day, one-entry e-visas for $25, which can be paid online. The Vietnamese e-visa instructions and application are available online at the Vietnamese governmentâ€™s official websites, https://www.immigration.gov.vn/ and https://www.xuatnhapcanh.gov.vn.

2018 FULBRIGHT VIETNAMESE SCHOLAR PROGRAM 

The U.S. Mission in Vietnam is seeking qualified candidates for the 2018 Fulbright Vietnamese Scholar Program (VSP). The VSP provides grants to Vietnamese scholars to lecture and/or conduct research at American institutions or universities for three to nine months. 

Further details on application are available at https://vn.usembassy.gov/education-culture/fulbright-program-vietnam/. The deadline of application submission is 5:00 p.m., October 15, 2017 by Vietnam time zone.

Information sessions will be held in major cities/provinces to guide the prospective candidates through the application process. Details can be found on the Fulbright website at: https://vn.usembassy.gov/education-culture/fulbright-program-vietnam/. 

https://vn.usembassy.gov/20170313-media-release-2018-fulbright-vietnamese-scholar-program/

Are you a U.S. citizen who voted in November? Still traveling or living overseas? You may wish to register and request your absentee ballot to vote again in 2017 to ensure your election office knows where to send your ballot for upcoming special elections for congressional elections. Some states will also hold gubernatorial or other statewide elections this year. If you'd like more information on the Federal Voting Assistance Program or need help with the absentee voting process, visit  FVAP.gov or call FVAP at +1-703-588-1584 (toll free 1-800-438-VOTE)) or email vote@fvap.gov.

#EducationUSAHCMC INTEL VIETNAM MASTERS SCHOLARSHIPS FOR ENGINEERING STUDENTS

Intel Products Vietnam in partnership with Arizona State University (ASU) via HEEAP will offer up to 19 Vietnam Grand Challenges Masters Fellowships to Arizona State University for high performing senior undergraduate students who will be completed with their Bachelor of Science degree in Spring 2017

Selected students will take part in a one-year, U.S. education experience at Arizona State University (ASU) in Tempe, Arizona in Fall 2017 while engaging with a mentor within Vietnam. As a component of these masterâ€™s programs students will focus on research and project based solutions (including Internet of Things solutions) geared towards developing a smart city, a priority focus for Ho Chi Minh City. The full cost of one full academic year (fall, spring, summer) of tuition and a living stipend will be awarded. 

https://heeap.org/fellowship/intel-products-vietnam-grand-challenges-masters-student-fellowship

Join us with this special screening this month and Q& A with Janet Grillo, filmmaker and award-winning producer , director of Jack of the Red Hearts. The film centers on the issues of orphans, family, autism, exclusion and inclusion.  It also tackles the parenting experience of coping with an autistic child from the sincere point of view of the director, who is a mother of a child with autism.  The event starts at 16:30 on 14 Mar 2017.  Please click https://afs-screening-achcmc.eventbrite.com for registrationâ€.

On March 3, The State Department released its annual Country Reports on Human Rights Practices that documents the human rights situation in 199 countries and territories around the world.  As mandated by Congress, the U.S. government uses the Human Rights Reports as part of our foreign policy formulation, including our decision making on foreign assistance.  The Human Rights Reports are also used by asylum judges and lawyers in the United States, and are a reference for governments, civil society, scholars, journalists, and others around the world.  
 
Click https://vn.usembassy.gov/our-relationship/official-reports/ to read the English version of the report. We will share the Vietnamese-language version later this month.

THE 2017 ALUMNI ENGAGEMENT INNOVATION FUND (#AEIF2017) HAS BEGUN!

Want to give back to your community? #AEIF2017 grants for #ExchangeAlumni public service projects can help! 

AEIF public service projects are awarded grants of up to $25,000. Alumni submit proposals under one of five themes, including these options: business development, civic participation, education, cooperation in science, and empowerment of women and girls.

The AEIF competition ends on March 30th, so gather your alumni teams and apply for funding today: alumni.state.gov/aeif.

Georgia Special Election Scheduled for April 18
The State of Georgia will conduct a special election on Tuesday, April 18, 2017, for the 6th Congressional District to replace U.S. Representative Tom Price who was confirmed as the U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary. This district consists of parts of northern Atlanta and parts of surrounding counties such as Cobb, Fulton, and Dekalb.

U.S. citizens overseas may use the Federal Post Card Application (FPCA), the official registration and ballot request form accepted by all States and territories. Complete, sign and send the FPCA to your election office. If you are a Georgia resident from the 6th Congressional District, register and request an absentee ballot today starting at FVAP.gov.

Today is World Wildlife Day! Did you know that rhino horn is made of keratin, the same material as human hair and fingernails, and has absolutely no medical benefits? U.S. Consulate Officers Chelsea Bergesen and Alena Joseph met with representatives from the organization CHANGE and local artists to learn more about how to combat rhino horn trafficking in Vietnam, the worldâ€™s top consumer of the illegal substance. Be part of the solution! Speak up against wildlife trafficking! #savetherhinos

On February 24, CG Tarnowka welcomed Consular Wardens from across the Consular district participating in our annual warden meeting. Wardens spent the afternoon engaging in discussions on topics such as assisting U.S. citizens in emergencies, federal benefits, security and safety concerns, the use of social media in emergency situations, and stress management in a crisis situation.  The highlight of the meeting was the remarks by CG Tarnowka on the invaluable service rendered by wardens and the value they bring to our bilateral relationship. Our American Citizens Services chief also provided certificates of appreciation to all of our American wardens for their hard work and dedication in volunteering to help us serve U.S. citizens abroad.

The United Statesâ€™ top Consular Officer in Vietnam spoke with Thanh Nien Media, noting that Vietnamese citizens will be largely unaffected by recent U.S. immigration policy changes. He encouraged Vietnamese students and tourists to continue with their plans to travel to the United States. He also advised U.S. Legal Permanent Residents (LPRs, or green card holders) from Vietnam that they can travel to and from the United States without a problem. Watch the video here: http://video.thanhnien.vn/thoi-su/sac-lenh-cam-nhap-cu-o-my-anh-huong-den-nguoi-viet-nam-nhu-the-nao-80829.html, and for more information check out our website at https://vn.usembassy.gov/

message: This Sunday, 100 million Americans will watch the #SuperBowl. Ever wondered why it's such a big deal in the U.S.? https://goo.gl/4TeQy7

For the first time in the history of U.S. currency, the United States will make a special gold coin featuring Lady Liberty as an African-American woman. The 2017 American Liberty 225th Anniversary Gold Coin will be made of 24-karat gold and will go on sale in April. Hereâ€™s what we know about the coin: https://goo.gl/uvJXDB

Black History Month was the inspiration of Carter G. Woodson, a noted scholar and historian, who instituted Negro History Week in 1926. He chose the second week of February to coincide with the birthdays of President Abraham Lincoln and the abolitionist Frederick Douglass. The celebration was expanded to a month in 1976, the nationâ€™s bicentennial. Each February, Black History Month honors the struggles and triumphs of millions of American citizens over the most devastating obstacles: slavery, prejudice, poverty as well as their contributions to the nationâ€™s cultural and political life.
(Graphic by United States Mission Geneva)

Grants Program 2017

The U.S. Consulate in Ho Chi Minh City, Public Affairs Section (PAS) is pleased to announce that funding is available through the Consulateâ€™s Public Diplomacy Grants Program for awards up to $50,000. Full tuition scholarship for law programs at Pepperdine University: 

Pepperdine has partnered with JAMS and the Seegmiller Law Firm to provide full-tuition scholarships for students in Pepperdine's LLM programs.  These scholarships are available for the following programs:
â€¢ LLM in International Commercial Arbitration (ICA)
â€¢ LLM in International Commercial Law and Arbitration (ICLA)
â€¢ LLM in International Commercial Law and Dispute Resolution (ICLDR)
â€¢ LLM in US Law and Dispute Resolution (USLDR)
â€¢ LLM in Dispute Resolution

Applications for the 2017 - 2018 academic year are now available.  Scholarship applicants need to have a completed LLM application and submit a two page essay by the March 3rd deadline.  Details on the scholarship can be found on the Full Tuition Scholarship webpage. Visit the Masters of Law (LLM) program page to learn more.
http://law.pepperdine.edu/admissions/master-of-laws/financial-assistance/scholarships/ica-scholarships.htm

VOLUNTEER RECRUITMENT

Calling all Volunteers! An opportunity to practice your English with American university representatives and support educational opportunities for Vietnamese students.

EducationUSA Advising Center is seeking volunteers to help with EducationUSA Fair in Spring 2017!

Date & Time:
Thursday, March 2, 2017 * 13:00 â€“ 18:00 p.m.

Requirements
- Current high school and university students in Ho Chi Minh city
- Good command of spoken English
- Responsible, sociable and active 
- Experience in interpreting and/or a good understanding of U.S. higher education is preferred.

Responsibilities
- Assist with marketing for the event
- Work as interpreters for higher education representatives
- Assist at check-in desk

Volunteers will be trained and receive a stipend of 400,000 VND.

Apply
Send your cover letter and CV to HCMCEDUSA@state.gov by January 2, 2017. 
Only short-listed applicants will be contacted.

The Public Affairs Section (PAS) of the U.S. Mission in Vietnam is seeking qualified candidates for the Study of the United States Institutes (SUSI) programs for scholars in 2017.  SUSI programs are intensive post-graduate level academic programs with integrated study tours that aim to provide foreign university faculty and scholars the opportunity to deepen their understanding of American society, culture, and institutions. University lecturers, researchers, and secondary school educators who wish to apply for the programs are invited to complete the application form and submit online to PAS by midnight Tuesday, January 3, 2017. 
For more information:  http://photos.state.gov/libraries/vietnam/8621/scholarships/2017-susi-scholars-teacher-announcement.pdf

message:
The first Thanksgiving 1621
 
Thanksgiving events have been held in the United States since colonial times. This 20th century artistâ€™s rendering depicts a feast of Thanksgiving that is commonly believed to have been celebrated between English settlers and Native Americans in 1621. President George Washington proclaimed the first nation-wide Thanksgiving on November 27, 1789. Today in the U.S. Thanksgiving is celebrated on the fourth Thursday of November. [Painting by JLG Ferris, 1932 / Library of Congress.]

Next week is International Education Week (IEW). IEW is a joint initiative of the U.S. Department of State and U.S. Department of Education that provides an opportunity to celebrate the benefits of international education and exchange worldwide. Please join our events at the American Center during the week of November 14-18 in honor of IEW 2016:

Succeeding with Standardized Tests: TOEFL iBT, SAT, GRE, GMAT
Monday, November 14, 3:30 - 5:00 p.m.

Study English in the U.S.
Tuesday, November 15, 2:30 - 4:00 p.m.

Student Visas for U.S - Vietnam Joint Programs
Wednesday, November 16, 2:30 - 4:00 p.m.

U.S. Exchanges Celebrate Teachers 
Thursday, November 17, 2:30 - 4:00 p.m.

U.S. Education System Key Values - Challenges & Opportunities for International Students
Friday, November 18, 2:30 - 4:00 p.m.

The Regional English Language Office (RELO), U.S. Embassy Hanoi, Vietnam, is pleased offer travel grants for outstanding Vietnamese English language teaching (ELT) professionals to attend either ThaiTESOL 2017 Conference or CamTESOL 2017 Conferences. The application deadline is November 30, 2016.

The 2017 Global Undergraduate Exchange Scholarship Program is now open! Submit your application until January 1, 2017 to have the chance to receive a one-semester scholarship at accredited four-year U.S. institutions of higher education, where you will engage in community service, professional development workshops, and cultural enrichment activities. 
For more information, please go to http://photos.state.gov/libraries/vietnam/8621/scholarships/2017-UGRAD-program-announcement.pdf

â€œI had the time of my life with UGRAD. There is a lot I could say about this amazing program - powerful, empowering, eye-opening, life-changing and mind-blowing, just to name a few. You have the opportunity to immerse yourself in every aspect of the beautiful life in the U.S. To begin with, U.S. education is definitely the best: fascinating, intriguing and engaging. However, there is much more to the program than just studying. College life in the U.S. also offers an extensive variety of activities, clubs and communities, just waiting for you to join. On top of that, you have an awesome team of program coordinators, who make sure that you make the most of your experience in the program. UGRAD is definitely one of the biggest milestones in my life.â€ 

Tran Quy Duy, UGRAD alum 2014-2015, California State University-San Marcos

LIBERAL ARTS COLLEGE FAIR 
Wednesday, October 5 - 2:30-6:00pm

The U.S. Consulate General in Ho Chi Minh City will organize the very first Liberal Arts College Fair on  October 5th, from 15:00-18:00, at the American Center in Ho Chi Minh City on the 8th floor of Diamond Plaza (34 Le Duan, District 1). Attached are the fair poster and list of participating institutions. 

19 American universities and colleges will be represented at the fair. This is a very good opportunity for Vietnamese students to learn about Liberal Arts education system in the United States and talk directly with school representatives about the possibility of achieving their higher educational goals through quality program. Attendees will also receive updated information about the U.S. student visa procedures from a U.S. Consulate Officer, scholarship opportunities from EducationUSA Advisors. Consul General Mary Tarnowka will deliver the opening remarks at the fair.

The EducationUSA fair is free and open to the public.  Please note that photo IDs are required for entry. 

List of participating institutions:

1.         Whitworth University
2.         Coe College
3.         Drew University
4.         St. Mary's University
5.         Regis College
6.         Ohio Wesleyan University
7.         Truman State University
8.         Randolph-Macon College
9.         Saint Leo University
10.       Benedictine College
11.       University of San Francsico
12.       Benedictine University
13.       Otterbein University
14.       Luther College
15.       Muhlenberg College
16.       Wesleyan University
17.       Baldwin Wallace University
18.       La Salle University
19.       St. Norbert College

Register online at https://goo.gl/LAUnP3

Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Pride Month (LGBT Pride Month) is currently celebrated each year in the month of June to honor the 1969 Stonewall riots in Manhattan. The Stonewall riots were a tipping point for the Gay Liberation Movement in the United States. In the United States the last Sunday in June was initially celebrated as â€œGay Pride Day,â€ but the actual day was flexible. In major cities across the nation the â€œdayâ€ soon grew to encompass a month-long series of events. Today, celebrations include pride parades, picnics, parties, workshops, symposia and concerts, and LGBT Pride Month events attract millions of participants around the world. Memorials are held during this month for those members of the community who have been lost to hate crimes or HIV/AIDS. The purpose of the commemorative month is to recognize the impact that lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender individuals have had on history locally, nationally, and internationally. Read more https://www.loc.gov/lgbt/about.html

So excited that the pre-TOM (Tikkun Olam Maker) Makers with Disabilities event was a success, with teams working on ideas and prototypes to help children with disabilities! 

Now we're looking forward to the official TOM event, a 72-hour makeathon, which will be held on June 3-5, 2016! This event - co-organized and sponsored by the U.S. Consulate in Ho Chi Minh City, the Embassy of Israel in Vietnam, UNICEF, Fab Lab Saigon, the Vietnamese-German University and DRD - connects children who are living with disabilities with multi-disciplinary teams of experts and volunteers in order to design and prototype solutions for pre-defined daily challenges. Stay tuned for more information!

The Public Affairs Section (PAS) seeks candidates for the 2016 â€œBuilding Think Tank Influence and Effectiveness,â€ a Professional Fellows On-Demand Exchange Program funded by the U.S. Department of State and implemented by World Learning.  This exchange program encourages the study of existing and emerging international bodies in Asia and their efforts to address national, regional, and global challenges. The application deadline is May 31, 2016. http://hochiminh.usconsulate.gov/yseali-professional-fellows-on-demand.html

Statement by the Press Secretary on the Presidentâ€™s Travel to Vietnam and Japan
The President will travel to Vietnam and Japan May 21-28, on what will be his tenth trip to Asia. This trip will highlight the Presidentâ€™s ongoing commitment to the U.S. Rebalance to Asia and the Pacific, designed to increase U.S. diplomatic, economic, and security engagement with the countries and peoples of the region.
The President will first visit Vietnam, where he will hold official meetings with Vietnam's leadership to discuss ways for the U.S.-Vietnam Comprehensive Partnership to advance cooperation across a wide range of areas, including economic, people-to-people, security, human rights, and global and regional issues. In Hanoi, the President will deliver a speech on U.S.-Vietnam relations. During meetings and events in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, the President will discuss the importance of approving the Trans-Pacific Partnership this year. The President also will meet with members of civil society, the Young Southeast Asian Leadership Initiative, entrepreneurs, and the business community.

Do you want to get the chance to participate in a five-week program in the U.S. with other fellows from Southeast Asia? The YSEALI Academic Fellows Program is now open! Submit your application no later than May 23, 2016!!! http://hochiminh.usconsulate.gov/yseali_academic_fellowship_fall_2016.html

â€œYSEALI Academic Fellows Program, one of the most significant milestones of my twenty-one, brought me many opportunities to discover the world and especially explore my potentials by myself as well. It is not merely an exchange program, for me, it is truly a fascinating journey of cultural understanding, friendship, solidarity and people-to-people connection. We are the young leaders and pioneers from Southeast Asia with different backgrounds of culture, religion, education and gender, but we did unite in the same place because of our shared and common goals of development. During the five-week program, the professors at Kennesaw State University and guest speakers from many NGOs in America, taught me plenty of professional and insightful knowledge throughout their own lectures and inspirational stories. I was impressed by not only their brilliance but more importantly their inspiration and enthusiasm which will be certainly my motivation later on.â€ â€“ Nguyen Van Tay

Calling #YSEALI youth to submit innovative #technology ideas to improve agriculture, aquaculture and fisheries in #ASEAN! Compete in the YSEALI Innovation Challenge powered by USAID - US Agency for International Development for a chance to join other young leaders on a weeklong training in Singapore and to participate in a 10-day study tour of Silicon Valley and Washington, DC!
Get more details at www.YSEALI.state.gov or www.MekongSkills2Work.org and apply by May 1!

Calling all volunteers! Are you looking for an opportunity to participate in and lead innovative educational activities, practice your English, meet new people and support U.S.-Vietnam relations? Well, hereâ€™s your chance! The American Center Ho Chi Minh City is seeking volunteers to help staff a booth at the Ho Chi Minh City Book Fair 2016, one of the largest book fairs in the city.

Date: March 21-27, 2016
Location: Le Van Tam Park, Hai Ba Trung Street, District 1, Ho Chi Minh City
Shift Schedule: 8:00-12:00, 12:00-16:00 or 16:00-20:00

Requirements:
- Current high school and university students in Ho Chi Minh City
- Good command of spoken English
- Responsible, sociable and proactive 

Responsibilities:
- Assist with event promotion
- Work as interpreters, event leaders, and assist with other activities at the fair

Volunteers will be trained and will receive letters of recognition.
Click the link to register: https://creator.zoho.com/achcmc1/book-fair-2016/#Form:Book_Fair_2016

The American Center launched a video contest on February 4, 2016 to encourage Vietnamese youth to explore the meaning of diversity and explain it in a two-minute video.  Diversity is defined in its broadest context and can include: equality, workplace diversity, social inclusion and LGBTI rights. The contest is open to anyone with a Vietnamese ID, living in Vietnam and between the age of 18 and 35. The contest closes at midnight on March 18, 2016. Please visit http://hochiminh.usconsulate.gov/pr-022416.html for more information

The U.S. Consulate General - Ho Chi Minh City is pleased to announce the FY2016 Teaching Excellence and Achievement Program (TEA). Funded by the U.S. Department of State, TEA provides high school teachers with unique opportunities to develop expertise in their subject areas, enhance their teaching skills, and increase their knowledge about the United States. Complete applications must be submitted ONLINE no later than March 21, 2016. 
http://photos.state.gov/libraries/hochiminh/1045241/pdf/TEA%20Program%202016%20Announcement.pdf

message:
Did you miss the chance to apply for the 2016 Global Entrepreneurship Summit (GES) in Silicon Valley?  Well, youâ€™re in luck! The deadline was extended through today, so submit your application now! http://www.ges2016.org/

GES 2016 aims to showcase inspiring entrepreneurs and investors from around the world creating new opportunities for investment, partnership, and collaboration; connect American entrepreneurs and investors with international counterparts to form lasting relationships; and highlight entrepreneurship as means to address some of the most intractable global challenges.

message:
VOLUNTEER RECRUITMENT

Calling all Volunteers! Do you want a chance to practice your English? Do you want to meet American university representatives? Do you want to support educational opportunities for Vietnamese students? EducationUSA Advising Center is seeking volunteers to help with EducationUSA Fair in Spring 2016!

Date: Friday, March 18
Time: 13:00 â€“ 16:00 p.m.
Location: GEM Center 8 Nguyen Binh Khiem District 1, Ho Chi Minh City

Requirements:
- Current high school and university students in Ho Chi Minh city
- Good command of spoken English
- Responsible, sociable and active 
- Experience in interpreting and/or a good understanding of U.S. higher education is preferred.

Responsibilities:
- Assist with marketing for the event
- Work as interpreters for higher education representatives
- Assist at check-in desk
Volunteers will be trained and receive a stipend of 400,000 VND.

Apply: 
Send your cover letter and CV to HCMCEDUSA@state.gov by January 26, 2016. 
Only short-listed applicants will be contacted for interviews.

The GIST Tech-I Competition is an annual competition for science and technology entrepreneurs from emerging economies worldwide. Up to thirty finalists will receive a trip to the Global Entrepreneurship Summit (GES), this year in Silicon Valley, to showcase their ventures and to receive intensive training. Participate now to share your amazing ideas with the world! The GIST Tech-I 2016 application deadline is January 22, 2016! (Apply at www.gistnetwork.org/tech-i)

Photo by: U.S. Department of State (IIP Bureau)
 
The Martin Luther King, Jr. Memorial is located in West Potomac Park in Washington, D.C., southwest of the National Mall (but within the larger area commonly referred to as the "National Mall"). The national memorial is America's 395th unit in the national park service. The monumental memorial is located at the northwest corner of the Tidal Basin near the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial, on a sightline linking the Lincoln Memorial to the northwest and the Jefferson Memorial to the southeast. The official address of the monument, 1964 Independence Avenue, S.W., commemorates the year the Civil Rights Act of 1964 became law.

message: Graphic novels, also known as comics, have grown in popularity and have taken a more serious tone by presenting hard-hitting subjects.  What do you think makes them so popular? https://goo.gl/EUj9O4

Big brands are making major changes to the way they do business from incorporating smart technology to conserve water to investing in environmental research and development. What is a company near you that has made sustainability a part of their business practice? https://goo.gl/ozBEMd

The cost of many renewable energy sources has dropped from 29-65% lower than fossil fuels.
With these resources becoming more affordable, how quickly do you think more people will use this kind of energy?

Don't miss your chance to meet the U.S. Science Envoy

The Unexpected Challenges, Opportunities and Rewards of a Career in Science
Time: Friday, December 4, 5 p.m.
Speaker: Geri Richmond, U.S. Science Envoy for the Lower Mekong River Countries

Why choose science or engineering as a career? There are many good reasons that range from satisfying your curiosity to saving the planet to educating the next generation. In this interactive presentation, Professor Richmond will discuss the many exciting possibilities ahead for those that choose a career in technical fields.

message: The Public Affairs Section (PAS) of the U.S. Embassy in Hanoi and Consulate General in Ho Chi Minh City are pleased to announce the Study of the United States Institutes (SUSI) programs for Vietnamese scholars in 2016. We seek qualified candidates for these programs. University lecturers and researchers who wish to apply for the programs are invited to complete the application form and submit online to PAS by Monday, December 14, 2015. Selections will be announced in early April 2016. http://hochiminh.usconsulate.gov/susi-2016.html

The 2016 Global Undergraduate Exchange Scholarship Program is now open! Submit your application until January 1, 2016 to have the chance to receive a one-semester scholarship at accredited four-year U.S. institutions of higher education, where you will engage in community service, professional development workshops, and cultural enrichment activities. http://hochiminh.usconsulate.gov/ugrad-2016.html

â€œI had the time of my life with UGRAD. There is a lot I could say about this amazing program - powerful, empowering, eye-opening, life-changing and mind-blowing, just to name a few. You have the opportunity to immerse yourself in every aspect of the beautiful life in the U.S. To begin with, U.S. education is definitely the best: fascinating, intriguing and engaging. However, there is much more to the program than just studying. College life in the U.S. also offers an extensive variety of activities, clubs and communities, just waiting for you to join. On top of that, you have an awesome team of program coordinators, who make sure that you make the most of your experience in the program. UGRAD is definitely one of the biggest milestones in my life.â€  - Tran Quy Duy, UGRAD alum 2014-2015, California State University-San Marcos

message:
International Education Week is an opportunity to celebrate the benefits of international education and exchange worldwide. This joint initiative of the U.S. Department of State and the U.S. Department of Education is part of efforts to promote programs that prepare Americans for a global environment and attract future leaders from abroad to study, learn, and exchange experiences in the United States.

This year the dates for IEW 2015 are November 16-20, 2015.

- See more at: http://eca.state.gov/programs-initiatives/international-education-week#sthash.krzoId1I.dpuf

message:
Ngan Dang (YSEALI Professional Fellow on Education at the University of Montana, 2015), says: â€œYSEALI is a life-changing experience. It is not just about knowledge and experience sharing but networking opportunities and friendship with young professionals all around the world. I learnt about American culture, people and many countries from other fellows. Being a part of this young powerful network, I feel much honorable, responsible and motivated to strive every single day to drive changes, one by one, in my community.â€

If you want to have a life-changing experience like Ngan, apply here! http://photos.state.gov/libraries/vietnam/8621/scholarships/yseali_professional_fellows_ngodevelopment.pdf

Date: Saturday, Oct. 10, 2015
Time: 19:30 - 21:30
Venue: Trung tam Van hoa Thong tin Hue
41A Hung Vuong, Hue City

- Education USA Fair, Hue University, 3 Le Loi Street, Hue City. October 9 (from 09:30 to 11:30)

#USAinHue

The U.S. Mission to Vietnam seeks candidates for the 2016 Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative (YSEALI) Academic Fellowship on Civic Engagement, and Social Entrepreneurship & Economic Development.  Vietnamese citizens between the ages 18 and 25, full-time undergraduate students or those who have graduated from college, university, or other institutions of higher learning, who demonstrate strong leadership qualities and potential in their university, place of work, an interest in community service and volunteerism, and have a good command of English, are invited to apply for the program. The application deadline is 5:00 PM, Monday, October 26th, 2015. Apply now!!! http://hochiminh.usconsulate.gov/2016-yseali-academic-fellowship.html

message:
On November 19-23, 500 young leaders from ASEAN will convene in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia for the Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative (YSEALI) Summit. 

There are currently 10 spots available for â€œYSEALI Digital Delegatesâ€ at the YSEALI Summit. YSEALI Digital Delegates will be responsible for sharing â€œreal-timeâ€ information about whatâ€™s happening at all times during the event via social media channels such as Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube. 

Applications are now open for 10 YSEALI members to join the YSEALI Summit as a Digital Delegate. One person from each of the 10 ASEAN member countries will be selected.

For more information about the YSEALI Summit or to read more about the criteria to apply to be one of ten YSEALI Digital Delegates, visit http://bit.ly/YSEALIDD.

message: On August 12, Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg visited the American Center to talk with 80 participants of the 2015 Fulbright YSEALI Summer School.  The students, who are from all over Vietnam, shared their concerns with Justice Ginsburg about issues impacting the country, like education. She encouraged them to continue to work to address these challenges, saying â€œSmart and enthusiastic young people like you will turn what you wish to change into reality.â€  The Fulbright YSEALI Summer School concludes today.  To stay informed and get involved with YSEALI, sign up for free to become a member! https://youngsoutheastasianleaders.state.gov/

Time: Tuesday, August 11, 2:00 â€“ 4:00pm
Speaker: Stephanie Thompson, Department of State Intern

Exploring America Series #2: New York and the East Coast
Time: Tuesday, August 11, 5:30 â€“ 7:00pm
Speaker: Susan Wong, Management Officer

New York City, Boston, Philadelphia and Washington, D.C. are several of the oldest cities along the East Coast, each holding a unique historical and cultural heritage. Come explore this region with Susan Wong, who will share her experience living, traveling, and working on the East Coast. 

Exploring America Series #3: Michigan and the Great Lakes Region
Time: Wednesday, August 12, 5:30 â€“ 7:00pm
Speaker: Cameron Thomas-Shah, Consulate Officer

Michigan is the birthplace of the U.S. auto industry, and home of Motown Records in Detroit. Meanwhile, the Great Lakes offer outstanding tourism and recreation opportunities, from wilderness activities to waterfront beaches. Come join Cameron Thomas-Shah, who will help you discover the beauty, as well as the historical and cultural heritage of Michigan and the Great Lakes Region. 

Exploring America Series #4: Texas 
Time: Thursday, August 13, 2:00 â€“ 4:00pm
Speaker: Ben West, Guest Speaker

Texas is a big place with many different types of landscapes and people. While some try to reduce the state to stereotypes, Ben will portray the state's diversity and idiosyncrasies. After all, Texas isn't just about cowboys and horses. Ben will share stories about his experiences growing up in Texas: his grandfather's cattle ranch, living in the live music capital of the world, and the differences between the piney woods of East Texas and the wide open plain of West Texas. Come learn about the history, geography, and people that make up the state of Texas.

#ExploringAmerica at The American Center HCMC

The United States Capitol, atop Capitol Hill at the eastern end of the National Mall in Washington, D.C., is the seat of the United States Congress, the legislative branch of the U.S. federal government, completed in the year 1800. Though not at the geographic center of the Federal District, the Capitol is the origin point at which the District's four quadrants meet, and around which the city was laid out.

- Paraguay celebrated its 200th anniversary with the longest hot dog ever at   204 meters.
- â€œHot dogsâ€ were the first words ever said by Mickey Mouse in a cartoon.
- The â€œChicago-styleâ€ hot dog normally has the most toppings.

The American Center Ho Chi Minh City is pleased to announce the Spelling Bee Contest for 2015!  Contestants must be between 15 and 21 years old currently residing in Vietnam. This yearâ€™s contest celebrates the 20th anniversary of the normalization of U.S. â€“ Vietnam relations, featuring words related to diplomacy and bilateral relations. Compete in this contest, test your English vocabulary and spelling skills, and win great prizes. We will start at 2:00pm sharp. Latecomers will not be admitted.

Antigone Rising, a well-known all-female, alt-country rock band from New York, will perform and talk about LGBT rights, especially marriage equality. Come see the performance and engage in an interactive talk about these female artistsâ€™ life stories.

Speakers: Liz Pinedo and Conor Hassett

Are you familiar with the U.S. college application process? What are the differences between the SAT and SAT Subject Tests? Come enjoy a fun game and learn about higher education in the U.S. at the same time. Win cool prizes for correct answers!

Happy 4th of July!
The Fourth of July has been recognized as Independence Day in the United States ever since the countryâ€™s Founding Fathers signed the Declaration of Independence on July 4, 1776. To mark the occasion, Americans celebrate with parades, fireworks, concerts and other festive activities. Read more at https://share.america.gov/celebrating-u-s-independence-day/

In celebration of the 20th anniversary of the normalization of diplomatic relations between the U.S. and Vietnam, the U.S. Consulate General in Ho Chi Minh City is pleased to announce the 20th Anniversary Pitch Contest.

The contest is open for all Vietnamese high school and university students (15-22 years old) currently residing in Vietnam. Contestants will have the opportunity to articulate how Vietnam has changed since the normalization of diplomatic relations with the U.S. in 1995. They will also have the opportunity to showcase knowledge and pitch skills. Finally, contestants will connect with Department of State program alumni, who will serve as mentors for shortlisted contestants in the semi-final and final rounds.

Interested participants should submit a short essay in English of no more than 500 words explaining how Vietnam has changed after 20 years of diplomatic relations with the U.S. in either (a) education, (b) culture, (c) economy, (d) technology. The essay must be submitted at https://goo.gl/CAkzue by 11:59pm on July 14, 2015.

First place will receive an iPad mini; second place will receive a Nokia Lumia; and third place will receive a Fujifilm instant camera.

message: Tomorrow at  The American Center - Ho Chi Minh City: If you are heading to the U.S. to study in the fall, check out this great event weâ€™re hosting to help you prepare.  Create a network of contacts while enjoying some coffee! Useful guide books and cool door prizes are available on a first-come, first-served basis.  Don't miss!

Are you beginning your studies at an American university this fall? Join us to learn how to best prepare for your departure. Consular Officers, EducationUSA Advisors, American students and local alumni will discuss travel planning, adjusting to life in the U.S., F1 visa rules, and American social and academic culture. This interactive session will also provide you an opportunity to meet other students travelling to various universities in the U.S. Create a network of contacts while enjoying some coffee! Useful guide books and cool door prizes are available on a first-come, first-served basis.
 
The event is free of charge. Prior registration is strongly advised. Email HCMCEDUSA@state.gov.

As part of World Environmental Day activities, the U.S. Consulate General in HCMC in partnership with Intel Vietnam, AmCham, and the World Wide Fund will co-organize the Green Bike 2015 event with the theme â€œLove our Forest, Love our Planetâ€. Finding good mentors is key to an early-stage entrepreneurâ€™s success. On May 27, 60 young entrepreneurs from ASEAN will land in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam for the 5-day  #YSEALI Generation: Power of Entrepreneurship regional exchange. Each participant will be connected with an experienced mentor who has a wealth of resources, connections and experience to share. A big thank you to our mentors, Hilary Blair, Fiona Macaulay, Pat Cuartero, Douglas Ma, Ellyne Lamin, Sarah Green, David Gardner and Lillian Diaz for their commitment to developing the next generation of successful entrepreneurs.

On May 12, Ambassador Osius visited Le Hong Phong High School for the Gifted and led a conversation about the various areas in which Vietnam and the U.S. have cooperated over the past 20 years.  The students had exciting opinions to share about how Vietnam and the U.S. can help each other grow even further in the next 20 years.  Which school should the Ambassador visit next time heâ€™s in town?

Learn how to spot fast-changing trends and the consequences they can have for markets, businesses, and society with the new MOOC Camp: â€œAnalyzing Global Trends for Business and Societyâ€. Starting on May 4, 2015 and running for seven weeks, this course is offered by the University of Pennsylvania and taught by Professor Mauro GuillÃ©n. Participants need to create a Coursera account and register for the course online at: https://www.coursera.org/course/globaltrends.

Participants who send proof of online course completion to achcmc@state.gov by July 5 and attend six out of seven weekly discussions at the American Center will receive a certificate of completion.

message: Young entrepreneurs from across ASEAN are getting ready for the May 27 kick-off of #YSEALI Generation: Power of Entrepreneurship in Ho Chi Minh City. From more than 1,400 applications, the final 60 participants will come together for a 5-day workshop develop their venture ideas and build a network of peers and mentors that spans the region.

We are excited to announce that the application period for the 2015 YSEALI Professional Fellows Program is now open! You can get the program details and apply here http://hochiminh.usconsulate.gov/2015-yseali-professional-fellows-program.html

The YSEALI Professional Fellows Program is a professional development exchange program for the best and brightest community leaders from all across the ASEAN region. If selected as a Fellow, you have the opportunity to participate in a month-long program at a U.S.-based local government office, business, non-profit organization or legislative office. Fellows also work with community leaders to enhance their practical expertise, leadership skills and professional contacts to address issues in their home communities.

Special Advisor on Disability Rights Judy Heumann, a longstanding leader in the fight for equal rights, led a discussion on the film "Lives Worth Living." What can you do to help make your communities more accessible for everyone? Let us know in the comments!

message:
America's Race: The Kentucky Derby

The Kentucky Derby is a Grade I stakes race for three year-old Thoroughbred horses, held annually in Louisville, Kentucky, on the first Saturday in May. At Louisvilleâ€™s Churchill Downs, the world's fastest thoroughbred horses have competed on the first Saturday of every May since 1875. Known as the Kentucky Derby, this race is the oldest continuously held sporting event in the United States and one of the most prestigious in the world. Read more: http://goo.gl/krItrz

This time-lapse map makes it clear that our planet is rapidly getting warmer. Nine of the Earthâ€™s warmest years since 1880 have occurred after 2000. (The 10th warmest year? 1998.) Scientists from NASAâ€™s Goddard Institute for Space Studies, who released this analysis, warn that record-breaking temperatures could occur over the next two to three years.
