https://share.america.gov/less-arctic-ice-less-arctic-life/

Participants who complete the online course and attend 7 out of 8 weekly discussions will receive a certificate of completion.

Every year, thousands of animal species become extinct. Animals that once roamed the Earth in abundance are permanently disappearing from our planet at a heart-stopping pace. Scientists estimate that the current rate of extinction is 1,000 times greater than it would normally be because of one factor: humans.

[Women's History Month] Building self-confidence for women
Time: Monday, March 23, 2:00 p.m.
Speaker: Caroline Nabors, English Language Fellow 

This is a great opportunity for tips to enhance your confidence in public and professional settings. Come join Ms. Caroline Nabors in her discussion about what women can do to empower themselves.

Public Speaking Skills: Conquer Fear, Conquer English
Time: Monday, March 23, 5:00 p.m.
Speaker: Tony Ngo, E2 Co-founder and Chairman

Do you get nervous speaking English? Do you feel embarrassed before you open your mouth? Do you ever freeze up in front of a group? We'll introduce and practice techniques that can help you express your ideas confidently and persuasively, This is intended for anyone who wants to become better at English, from grade school students to adults. 

Food and You: You are more powerful than you think
Time: Tuesday, Mach 24, 2:00 p.m.
Speaker: Robert Lucius, Asia Pacific Programs, Humane Society International 

In this presentation, we will discuss relationships between personal food choices, national and global food trends, and their dietary implications for public health, climate change, the environment, animal welfare and global food security. Youâ€™ll learn why the food you eat matters in more ways that you realize, and how you can change the world with your chopsticks.

[MOOC Camp â€“ How to Learn] Discussion Session 2 â€“ How to Learn: Powerful Mental Tools to Help You Master Tough Subjects
Time: Tuesday, March 24, 5:30 p.m.
Speaker: Tuan Anh, facilitator 

[Womenâ€™s History Month] Reflection on Gender: Letâ€™s Talk about You
Time: Wednesday, March 25, 2:00 p.m.
Speaker: Ms. Marianne Oehlers, UNICEF

Have you ever thought or asked yourself â€œWhat does equality mean?â€, â€œWhat are the roles of men and women in society?â€, or â€œWhy can my sibling do things I canâ€™t?, then this is the event for you. During this presentation, we will ask you to be the leader. We will spend time exploring what is understood about gender, what it means to you, your peers, and your community. The goal is to start a thought-provoking and open conversation between young people to see what we can do together in 2015.

[Soft Skills Training Series] Session 4: Negotiating for salaries
Time: Wednesday, March 25, 5:00 p.m.
Speaker: Minh Do, Editor at Tech In Asia

Need tips on how to discuss your salary with an employer? This session with Mr. Minh Do will help you learn how to do it right when negotiating.

[Women's History Month] Healthy Eating and Life Balance for Women (women only)
Date: Tuesday, March 17, 2:00 p.m.
Speaker: Tran Lan Huong, Health Coach 

If you care about your health, mind, and body, join coach Tran Lan Huong for an open discussion about strategies to help women stay healthy and active. After the talk, coach Huong will introduce you to some quick yoga exercises which you can practice before and after work. Participate for a more healthy life!

MOOC Camp â€“ How to Learn: Powerful Mental Tools to Help You Master Tough Subjects
Time: Tuesday, March 17, 5:30 â€“ 7:00 p.m.
Speaker: Tuan Anh, facilitator

This course gives you easy access to  invaluable learning techniques used by experts in art, music, math, science, sports, and other disciplines. Weâ€™ll learn about the how the brain uses two very different learning modes and how it encapsulates (â€œchunksâ€) information. Weâ€™ll also cover illusions of learning, memory techniques, dealing with procrastination, and best practices shown by research to be the most effective in helping you master tough subjects.

This MOOC Camp includes five sessions on Tuesdays, from March 17 to April 14. Participants are required to register for the MOOC course on Coursera https://www.coursera.org/learn/learning-how-to-learn, review materials and lessons before each MOOC Discussion meeting, complete all quizzes and final test, and attend at least four discussion meetings, in order to receive a certificate of completion.

[Soft Skills Training Series] Session 3: Interviewing Skills
Time: Wednesday, March 18, 5:00 â€“ 6:30 p.m.
Speaker: Bennett Lowenthal, Consulate Officer 

Dealing with questions at a job interview can be nerve-wracking. This session will discuss what you need to prepare, and how to successfully tackle employersâ€™ questions, as well as how to raise smart questions. This series consists of 4 sessions and one team project.  Participants who attend all sessions and join the team project will receive a certificate of completion. 

Completing an Internship in the U.S.: Curricular Practical Training (CPT) and Optional Practical Training (OPT)
Date: Thursday, March 19, 2:00 â€“ 4:00 p.m.
Speaker: Vickie Kuester, University of Wisconsin-Stout 

This presentation will introduce young people to the American polytechnic model of education. A polytechnic education in the States is an engaging, active, applied learning experience that incorporates both theory and research. American polytechnic universities focus on professional, career-oriented programs in a wide range of disciplines from the fine arts to engineering. Graduates of polytechnics enjoy an extremely high employment rate, so this presentation will conclude with an exploration of some of the unique majors that polytechnic institutions offer.

[Women's History Month] A Male Perspective
Date: Thursday, March 19, 5:30pm
Speaker: Abraham Lee, Consulate Officer 

Hear an Asian-American view on the different roles of men and women in both domestic and professional settings. This informal and interactive discussion with Consulate Officer Abraham Lee will cover women, roles, dating, family and more. Bring questions if you have any!

Hangout Participants: 
Catherine A. Novelli, Under Secretary for Economic Growth, Energy, and the Environment at the U.S. Department of State
Mr. Peter Knights, Executive Director at WildAid
Ms. Paula Kahumbu, Executive Director of Wildlife Direct

Life in Small Town America 
Time: Monday, March 2, 2:00 - 4:00 p.m.
Speaker: Karie Ennis, Guest Speaker

If the only cities you know in America are Los Angeles and New York, it's time for you to join Karie Ennis to discover the treasures and luxuries that only life in a small town can offer. You will also be surprised how small towns have made significant contributions to the American culture.

World Wildlife Day
Time: Tuesday, March 3, 2:00 â€“ 4:00 p.m.
Speaker: Nguyen Van Quan, Guest Speaker from Education of Nature Vietnam (ENV)

March 3rd marks World Wildlife Day â€“ a day which celebrates the intrinsic value of nature and reminds us of the urgent need to stop wildlife trafficking and other related crimes. Come learn from expert Nguyen Van Quan about current local and global wildlife issues and discuss what actions you can take to secure the future for wild plants, animals, and even yourself! 

Soft Skills Training Series: Job Searching Skills
Session 1: Building a Foundation with Entry Level Jobs
Time: Wednesday, March 4, 5:00 p.m.
Speaker: Chris Helmkamp, Consulate Officer

Are you a job seeker? Are you new to the employment world? Don't know where to start, or how to write an effective resume? Don't worry! The Soft Skills Training Series is back! This time, we offer four sessions providing students and graduates with skills, tips and knowledge for success. Join our first session on how to start your career with entry level jobs.

MOOC Camp: College Writing 2.2x â€“ Principles of Written English, Part 2
Time: Wednesday, March 4, 5:00 p.m.
Speaker: Joe Freeman, Consulate Officer

A great opportunity for students to engage in an informal discussion on how to be a better writer. This is our last session. Don't miss it!

How the Lotus Flower Blossoms: An American's Study Abroad Experience in Vietnam
Time: Thursday, March 5, 2:00 p.m.
Speaker: Cayla Turain, American Student

Want to know about what Vietnam can offer to an American student? Come for a conversation with Cayla Turain, who will share her stories and experiences in Vietnam, and how the journey has changed her perspective about life, people, and culture.  

MOOC Camp: Growth to Greatness, Part 2
Time: Thursday, March 5, 5:30 p.m.
Speaker: Ted Nuyen, Guest Speaker

Engage in an informal discussion with Ted Nuyen and other participants. You won't want to miss the last session! Remember to send your final test results to AC by March 4. (achcmc@state.gov)

The Myth and the Magic: Black History Month in America

Date: Wednesday, February 25, 2:00 - 4:00 p.m.
Speakers: Malikat Rufai and Cameron Thomas-Shah, Consulate Officers

Youâ€™ve probably heard of Dr. Martin Luther King, Michael Jordan, or Oprah, but how much do you really know about African-Americans? Come test your knowledge and find out more with consulate officers Malikat Rufai and Cameron Thomas-Shah, who will discuss the great contributions of African-Americans in fields such as technology, literature or music, and introduce you to examples like Charles Drew, inventor of the blood bank; the Tuskegee Airmen; or the iconic music of Motown. This event is being held in honor of Black History Month.  Get ready for a unique time at the new AC, and compete for prizes!

February is #BlackHistoryMonth in the United States! The diverse contributions of all Americans have been invaluable in helping the U.S. grow and develop. As former President Jimmy Carter said: "We have become not a melting pot but a beautiful mosaic. Different people, different beliefs, different yearnings,different hopes, different dreams." During this month we want to highlight some of the many contributions of African-Americans to the U.S. Do you know any of them?

Today is Presidents Day in the U.S. It is a U.S. federal holiday celebrated on the third Monday of February in honor of George Washington, the first president of the United States. We now also commemorate Abraham Lincoln on this holiday. Learn more about this holiday in our free resource on the #AmericanEnglish website > http://1.usa.gov/1L2xylK Do you know the names of the four presidents in the photo below? (photo courtesy of Wikipedia).

message: World Wetlands Day is February 2. Wetlands are home to rich biodiversity and serve important ecological functions, such as absorbing floodwaters and filtering pollutants. But according to the World Wildlife Fund, half of all wetlands have disappeared since 1900.

Each February, Black History Month honors the struggles and triumphs of millions of American citizens over the most devastating obstacles â€” slavery, prejudice, poverty â€” as well as their contributions to the nationâ€™s cultural and political life.

Thank you for joining the webchat! We hope you found it helpful. For further information about educational opportunities in the U.S., come talk to us at our EducationUSA Fair on January 29th! The fair will be held at the U.S. Consulate General at 7 Mac Dinh Chi in District 1. You will be able to talk directly with representatives from 45 accredited U.S. universities and colleges, Consular Officers and Advisors. The fair will highlight the diverse range of education options available in the United States, from public and private universities, to four-year schools and community colleges. The EducationUSA fair is free and open to the public. However, space is limited. Pre-registration by hour is required and can be made via eventbrite: http://hcmcedusafair2015-usconsulate.eventbrite.com. We look forward to seeing you there!

Welcome to todayâ€™s webchat. We will cover a wide variety of topics, all related to studying in the United States. Do you have your questions ready? 
We will talk about topics like: U.S. Higher Education System, Different types of schools, Accreditation, Admissions, Scholarships/Financial Aid, Standardized Tests, Student Visas, Find-a-School Search Engine, Student Life, Available resources/services at the American Centers in Ho Chi Minh City and Hanoi. Many of you may also have questions about visas. 

Today we can only answer questions about visas and study in the U.S. If you have other questions, please wait for our upcoming consular webchat, which will cover many other types of questions about visas. OK, letâ€™s start!

Reminder: LAST WEEK TO APPLY FOR THE EDUCATION FAIR VOLUNTEER POSITION!!!

Email your cover letter and CV to HCMCEDUSA@state.gov by this Friday for a chance to volunteer for the U.S. Consulate. Click on the picture for more information.
Calling all Volunteers! Do you want a chance to practice your English? Do you want to meet American university representatives? Do you want to support educational opportunities for Vietnamese students? EducationUSA at the U.S. Consulate is seeking volunteers to help with the University Fair in Spring 2015!

Date: Thursday, January 29.
Time: 13:00 â€“ 18:00
Location: U.S. Consulate General â€“ 4 Le Duan District 1, Ho Chi Minh City.

Requirements:
- Current high school and university students in Ho Chi Minh city
- Good command of spoken English
- Responsible, sociable and active 
- Experience in interpreting and/or a good understanding of U.S. higher education is preferred.

Responsibilities:
- Assist with marketing for the event
- Work as interpreters for higher education representatives
- Assist at check-in desk
Volunteers will be trained and receive a stipend of 400,000 VND.

MOOC Camp HCMC is coming back with "Grow to Greatness: Smart Growth for Private Businesses, Part 2" starting on January 12. While you complete the course requirements on your own time, Mr. Ted Nuyen, mentor from HCMC SME Networking and Mentoring will facilitate weekly discussions at the American Center to help you understand and apply materials, as well as get the most out of this course. We will have the Vietnamese translation for all videos of the course.

By passing the online course final exam and attending all of the discussions, you will receive a certificate of participation from the U.S. Consulate Ho Chi Minh City. Remember to register for both the course and discussion sessions.
Register for the course at https://www.coursera.org/course/GTG
Register for group discussion sessions at: http://goo.gl/5o9Yaq

Schedule:
Week 1: Thursday, January 15, 5:30 p.m.: The Entrepreneur Must Grow, Too! 
Week 2: Thursday, January 22, 5:30 p.m.: The â€œSecretâ€ of High Performance is High Employee Engagement
Week 3: Thursday, January 29, 5:30 p.m.: Growth Is Much More Than a Strategyâ€”It Requires a SYSTEM
Week 4: Thursday, February 5, 5:30 p.m.: The Surprising Difficulties in Building a Senior Management Team

March 5, 5:30 p.m.: Closing Ceremony

From December 15, 2014, the American Center will be closed for renovation. During this time, patrons who return books, still can contact the guards at the entrance. Normal hours will tentatively be resumed in early March. Please follow us on Facebook for updated information.

During AC renovation time, EducationUSA will provide one-on-one advising services during the following hours: Monday, Wednesday: 2 pm â€“ 4 pm, Friday: 9 am â€“ 11 am. To make an appointment, please call (08) 3520.4685 or (08) 3520.4625 during the mornings of Monday and Wednesday, Friday afternoons, and all day Tuesday and Thursday (office hours). In addition, you can also email your questions directly to hcmcedusa@state.gov. EducationUSA will temporarily halt phone advising during the above time period.

We are excited to announce that Willamette MBA has a new scholarship program available for international students:

The Willamette MBA Global Diversity Scholarship program is for international students who completed their bachelor degree in any of the following countries**: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Brazil, Bulgaria, Chile, China, Colombia, Egypt, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Iraq, Israel, Jordan, Kazakhstan, Kuwait, Lebanon, Philippines, Qatar, Romania, Taiwan, Thailand, Turkey, United Arab Emirates, and VIETNAM.

Applicants selected for this scholarship will receive a $5,000 Global Diversity scholarship and an Atkinson School Scholarship of at least $16,000. Thus, the total scholarship award for an applicant who receives a Global Diversity Scholarship and an Atkinson School Scholarship will range from $21,000 (57% of tuition) to approximately $37,000 (100% of tuition).

For more information about the requirements for this scholarship visit: http://www.willamette.edu/mba/full-time/financial_aid/scholarships/index.html

**Even applicants who do not qualify for a Global Diversity Scholarship will still receive full consideration for merit-based scholarships, based on eligibility. We encourage applicants from all over the world to apply!

Willamette MBA was recently ranked as a top MBA program in the U.S. by Businessweek and is specifically designed for students who are early in their career (no work experience required) or for those seeking a significant career change.

Climate change negotiators from all over the world are gathering for the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) Conference of the Parties (COP-20) in Lima, Peru. The United States is committed to combating global climate change and is working with international partners to forge an international agreement to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, accelerate clean energy innovations, and help the most vulnerable cope with the effects of climate change. #ActOnClimate
Learn more at http://www.state.gov/e/oes/climate/cop20/index.htm

Hi all, don'f forget the Native American Heritage Month Talk Series, Part 2: Tribes of the Midwest today, at 3:00 p.m.  See you all there!

November Talk Series: Native American Heritage Month
Session 2: Tribes of the Midwest
Time: Friday, November 21, 3:00 p.m.
Speaker: Joe Freeman, Consulate Officer

The Sioux are an iconic group, living in the central states of the US. Their story and history is long, sometimes joyful, sometimes tragic. Other tribes in regions have also preserved their languages, ways of life, and unique cultures. Come find out more about their stories at this talk.

Just one more day before the EducationUSA fair opens in District 1! Organized in cooperation with the Southeast Asian Minister of Education Organization (SEAMEO) Regional Training Center, the education fair will feature 24 American universities and institutions of higher learning who are visiting Vietnam. Take this chance to speak directly with representatives of schools from across the United States! The fair will take place from 2:00 - 5:30 pm (November 19th, tomorrow!) at 35 Le Thanh Ton (SEAMEO RETRAC) in central Ho Chi Minh City. See you there!

EducationUSA is organizing a fair in Ho Chi Minh City on November 19th from 2:00 - 5:30 pm at 35 Le Thanh Ton (SEAMEO RETRAC) in District 1. The event will feature 24 American universities and institutions of higher learning who are visiting Vietnam. We'll also have a session on American student visas. The event is free and open to the public.

Maybe American-English speakers think with their stomachs, because they often express themselves in the language of cooking. Good friends who like the same things are â€œlike two peas in a pod.â€ Any bad situation that gets worse moves â€œout of the frying pan and into the fire.â€ Something really easy is â€œa piece of cake.â€
Check out more phrases at https://share.america.gov/food-talk-big-americas-melting-pot/

The American Center will be closed tomorrow, Tuesday, November 11 in observance of the American Veterans Day holiday.  Normal hours will be resumed on Wednesday.

November 11 is Veterans Day in the United States, and parades, ceremonies and tributes to veterans are planned in small towns and large cities throughout the country to honor those who have served in the U.S. military.

Read more: http://iipdigital.usembassy.gov/st/english/article/2007/11/20071109124825emohkcabhplar0.2962.html#ixzz3IftbKkdH

American Spaces provide welcoming and library-like environments in more than 800 locations across 169 countries. Visitors to American Spaces - 16 million and counting - can learn about U.S. policies, culture and values, practice their English and get information about studying in the U.S. American Spaces exemplify a core tenet of democracy: everyoneâ€™s right to free access to information. https://share.america.gov/books-over-burgers-importance-libraries-2/

Midterm Elections in the United States
Time: Wednesday, November 5, 2:00 p.m.
Speaker: Robert Crotty, Consulate Officer
Midterm elections, so-called because they occur in even-numbered years at the halfway point of a presidential term, determine which political party will control the two chambers of the U.S. Congress for the upcoming two years. Join Mr. Robert Crotty for an informative program to learn more about U.S. Elections Procedures.

Speaker: Garrett, Harkin, Consulate Officer
Garrett Harkins will speak on the American non- profit sector; both the general environment and the different types of organizations. He will then give an overview of the process of registering an NGO in the United States and how it differs from the experience of starting a for profit company.

Good evening American Center fans! The American Center is pleased to announce its first English Discussion Club. The club is open to members who love to practice English and improve speaking skills. Each month, consulate officers or guest speakers will lead a discussion on a specific topic related to American culture or global issues. This month, the discussion topic is Global Food Security. It is scheduled in 3 sessions and led by a guest speaker Sarah Piccini. Mark your calendar and come join us. Registration is not required for this club. DOUBLE GOOD NEWS for those who want to go to grad schools in the U.S:

1. TEXAS CHRISTIAN UNIVERSITY SCHOLARSHIPS

Texas Christian University's MBA Program is announcing November 1, 2014 as the first deadline for priority scholarship and admission consideration. All applications meeting this first deadline will be considered for scholarships, which range from $28,987 to full scholarship with stipend at $56,400 per year.
For more information, please visit: http://bit.ly/QXJjlo

2. HOW ADULT & PROFESSIONAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS WORK IN THE U.S.

Director of International Recruitment of University of Redlands, Brian Jauregui will present a talk on "How adult and professional education programs work in the U.S." at the American Center, Diamond Plaza, the coming Tuesday, Oct 28 at 2pm. Please RSVP here: http://www.eventbrite.com/e/how-adult-and-professional-education-programs-work-in-the-us-tickets-13844010809?aff=eorg

Hey movie fans! Itâ€™s Audience Choice month at the American Classics Film Series tomorrow, Thursday, October 23. Vote now on your favorite genre and come at 4:30 tomorrow to watch a classic American film from the genre that gets the most votes. All votes due by noon tomorrow.
1. Romance
2. Comedy
3. Musical Theater
4. Drama
5. Horror/Suspense

Be a professional fellow in the United States! The YSEALI Professional Fellows Program is an exchange program for the best and brightest community leaders from ASEAN countries. Successful participants get a month-long fellowship at U.S.-based non-profit or other organizations, government offices or legislative bodies. Find out more today! (The application deadline is December 1.)

http://exchanges.state.gov/non-us/program/yseali-professional-fellows-program

1) Writing your solution for ending poverty on a piece of paper,
2) Adding #EndPoverty and

What do you think is the best way to end poverty?

message: Today, October 16th, is World Food Day â€“ a day of action to eradicate hunger in our lifetime. According to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) one in nine people worldwide live with chronic hunger, and almost 5 million children under the age of 5 die of malnutrition-related causes every year. What are some ways to help reduce hunger and malnutrition around the world? Learn more at http://www.fao.org/world-food-day/en/

Fellowships in the United States. Check it out!  Deadline for submission: October 27th.

The Community Solutions Program is accepting applications for fellowships in the United States! If you are aged 25-38 and are currently working in a community engagement initiative, this program will help you gain experience alongside a U.S. community-based non-profit or other organization, government office or legislative body. Specific areas of focus are: Environmental Issues, Tolerance and Conflict Resolution, Transparency and Accountability, and Women and Gender Issues.  The deadline is Oct 27. Please see the website for the application and further details! http://exchanges.state.gov/non-us/program/community-solutions

UMass Amherst is proud to consider qualified international students for academic-based merit scholarships of up to $12,000 USD per academic year. No separate application is required, as students are automatically considered once admitted to the university. The merit scholarships were established to recognize the high level of academic achievement of students coming to our university from around the world. Available to undergraduate students only, these scholarships are based upon a studentâ€™s high school GPA and standardized test score, such as SAT or ACT.

UNIVERSITY OF THE PEOPLE HP WOMENS SCHOLARSHIP FUND
The HP Womenâ€™s Scholarship Fund offers two-year scholarships to female students at University of the People (UoPeople), enabling them to pursue an associate degree in a program of their choice. 

Students who are awarded a scholarship also have access to mentoring support from HP employees. These HP mentors provide UoPeople students with invaluable guidance and support, enriching their academic learning experience and playing a pivotal role in preparing them for employment after graduation. message:
The time has come for our final, grand prize AC Road Trip clue! Our journey has come to an end in the capital of the United States, Washington, DC! 

It's been so fun driving across  the U.S. "with" all of our friends from Vietnam. Special congratulations to our 12 clue winners, pictured on our map. 

For the final, grand prize, can you answer these questions:
1. What U.S. road trip destination did we miss that you would most like to visit?
2. How far do you think we drove on this trip? Make sure to specify if your guess is in miles or kilometers!

Good luck ğŸš—ğŸš•ğŸš™ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸

Wow! You guys gave great advice for American students who might be interested in studying in Vietnam. We think there should be multiple winners, but we have to pick just one: congratulations Ngn Anh Thu!
Everybody stay tuned for our final destination and grand prize question.

NORTHERN STATE UNIVERSITY (SD) ADVANCED ESL SCHOLARSHIPS
A limited number of $1,500 first-year scholarships are available to international students who place in the advanced ESL program at Northern State University. To qualify, you must achieve at least an IELTS 5.0 or TOEFL 51 score. If you do not have a test score, you can take a placement test on campus.

This first-year scholarship will be applied to your tuition bill over the first two semesters of your degree program. Applications are now being accepted for the spring 2015 (January) intake.
For more information, please visit: http://bit.ly/1bDLS4r
#Scholarship #Undergrad

Summer is ending, and so must our Road Trip! This is our last mini-clue before the grand prize.  

We stopped in Williamsburg, Virginia, home of the beautiful College of William & Mary.  At most U.S. universities, the Center for International Studies helps to support international students studying in the United States, as well as American students who want to study abroad.

SO, the question for you is: What advice would you give to an American student interested in a study exchange to Vietnam?

A Day Without Space
Time: Thursday, September 4, 2:00 p.m. - 4:00 p.m.
Speaker: Elma Hajric, U.S. Consulate Summer Intern 

Expanding your galaxy... come and join us for a view 2,000 km above the Earth. You will learn more about the importance of space in our daily lives as well as the outer space activities of the region in general and how Vietnam plays a significant part in these activities.

Welcome back after the long holiday! Are you ready for a week full of exciting events at the AC? Starting today with the info session on "Law Programs in the US and the Application Process". This workshop will give attorney-hopefuls a chance to gain insights from the expert, Ms. Sarah Gonzales from Pepperdine University School of Law, about program selection and application guidelines for international students. See you at 2:00pm!

In Little Rock, Arkansas, we stopped at the Clinton Presidential Center, which houses thousands of books, records and other pieces of information about President Clinton's two terms in office, from 1993 - 2001.

Animals are important members of lots of families! The Clinton White House had two First Pets. What were their names? And, can you guess how many letters and e-mails they received from fans (especially children!) over the years of the Clinton Presidency? Answer below - the closest to the right answer will be notified next week that they've won this prize!

The American Center Ho Chi Minh City will be closed on Monday, September 1st and Tuesday, September 2nd in observance of America's Labor Day and Vietnam's National Day.

Unlike other U.S. holidays, Labor Day does not pay tribute to a person or memorialize a historic event. It gives voice to the American worker.

Read more: http://iipdigital.usembassy.gov/st/english/pamphlet/2012/08/20120829135247.html#ixzz3ByIhjler

AC Road Trip Clue 9!
Hey everyone, we're about halfway there! You still have a good chance to be a prize winner... 

Clue 9 is from the state of Oklahoma! We stopped to visit Sequoyah's Cabin, the original one room log cabin where this famous Native American lived from 1829 - 1843. Who is Sequoyah and what is he famous for? Tell us in your own words below to win the next prize!

(P.S. Thanks to those who posted creative answers to Clue 8 - we'll post all the updates winners after the long weekend!)

Have plan for tonight yet?  Join the Google Hangout on NASAâ€™s GREEN CHEMISTRY CHALLENGE today, August 28, at 9:00 pm Vietnam time to discuss worldwide Green Chemistry Challenge. The Hangout link is: http://conx.state.gov/brazil. The hangout will be in English.

The Department of State, NASA, NIKE, and the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), have partnered to sponsor LAUNCH, an open innovation platform, to identify and foster breakthrough ideas for a more sustainable world. LAUNCHâ€™s 2014 challenge seeks innovative â€œgreen chemistryâ€ proposals from around the world that leverage or advance â€œgreen chemistryâ€ to transform the system of materials and manufacturing to one that advances global economic growth, drives human prosperity and replenishes the planetâ€™s resources. The deadline for submitting proposals is September 24th,1 2014. Proposals must be submitted in English. More info: Green Chemistry Challenge at http://goo.gl/dMpTAi

August 26th is Womenâ€™s Equality Day in the United States, celebrating the day women received the right to vote. However, equality is more than just a law. In the United States, 66 percent of 4th grade girls say they like science and math, but only 18 percent of all college engineering majors are female. Check out this powerful commercial that might offer an explanation.http://goo.gl/YgCbzM

We were impressed with your concise and informative travel writing and hope you enjoyed learning about this National Park. And now, the winning answer is "Actually, the Petrified Forest National Park was once a verdant area some 225 million years ago. Underwent climatic and geological changes, the forest is now an arid land but also a wonderful geopark showing magic fossils and spectacular landscape in northeastern Arizona. It is where people can experience the natural remains of yore." Congratulations to Minh PhÆ°á»£ng!

Happy International Day of the World's Indigenous Peoples! The United Nations originally began this day of observance to highlight and protect the rights of indigenous peoples.This year's theme is "Bridging the gap: implementing the rights of indigenous peoples," and you can read more about it here! http://www.un.org/en/events/indigenousday/
How will you celebrate International Day of the World's Indigenous Peoples?

The Great American (Center) Road Trip 2014 has begun! We begin our trip at the highest peak in the Cascade Mountains, an active volcano that last erupted around 150 years ago. WHERE ARE WE? Answer in the comments below - one random correct answer wins a prize!

Tomorrow, we're all going on a road trip! The Great American (Center) Road Trip 2014 will kick off with your friends Anna & Sean. They are no longer in Vietnam, but they are driving across the United States and taking AC fans with them. Be sure to watch this page for pictures, videos, clues about their stops, and chances to win prizes!

Message from U.S. Ambassador to Vietnam David Shear

Táº¡m biá»‡t Viá»‡t Nam

It has been three years since you welcomed me to your country as the U.S. Ambassador. These have been three exciting, busy, and important years for both me and my wife Barbara and we thank you. Vietnam and its people will always hold a special place in our hearts.

More importantly, these three years have been a time of strengthened cooperation between the American and Vietnamese governments, as well as strengthened ties between our two peoples. The United States and Vietnam are charting a clear path for the future of our bilateral relationship and I strongly believe that the future holds many positive things for us both.

I may have to leave Vietnam now to take up my new duties as Assistant Secretary of Defense for Asia, but I will continue to work for the same goals that I have always worked for: a strong, prosperous and independent Vietnam.

#YSEALI Seeds for the Future grant competition deadline has been extended to August 10! This means you have extra time to build your team and submit a project proposal. Thanks to the teams that have already submitted! 

For more information about YSEALI, please go to https://youngsoutheastasianleaders.state.gov/

The #US university admissions process can be confusing. Check out this four-week free #MOOC on â€˜Applying to U.S. Universitiesâ€™ that will make it less so: http://goo.gl/gI1ZOY. Course commences today, Sunday, August 3rd!

Writing Tips and Techniques
Time: Tuesday, August 5, 10:00 a.m.
Speaker: Elma Hajric, Consulate Summer Intern
Come to the American Center to get tips on writing a strong paper! By the end of the presentation, students will gain new skills in writing an exciting thesis, supporting paragraphs, and conclusions to produce a variety of impressive essays. This lecture comes just in time to get last-minute pointers for ACâ€™s "Discover America" Essay Competition! See rules and submit your writing here: http://goo.gl/Mhkw90.

Writing a Statement of Purpose for Admission to Graduate School in the United States
Time: Tuesday, August 5, 2:30 p.m. â€“ 4:30 p.m.

Come join us in a unique session entitled â€œWriting a Statement of Purpose for Admission to Graduate School in the United Statesâ€ where you can meet Dr. J. Scott Angle, University of Georgia, Dr. Gisele Therese Muller-Parker, U.S. National Science Foundation (NSF), and Dr. Keith Alan Teague, Oklahoma State University. These professors will share their advice, insights, and guidance on how to prepare a statement of purpose that meets the requirements and attracts the special attention of the U.S. graduate admission committee. 

Book Club Activities
Time: Tuesday, August 5, 5:00 - 6:30 p.m.
Speaker: Pilar Quigua, Consulate Officer
Come discuss "The Man from the South" by Roald Dahl with Ms. Pilar Quigua.  Read here: http://www.classicshorts.com/stories/south.html

Soft Skills Series: Career Development - Session 3: Time Management Strategies
Date: Wednesday, August 6, 5:00 p.m. - 6:30 p.m.
Speaker: Chris Helmkamp, Consulate Officer
In the digital age, we are bombarded with information - emails, texts, tweets - that can disrupt our work and family lives and make it difficult to finish projects on time. Come learn some strategies for managing your time wisely in the digital age. Those who attend 5 of 6 sessions will be invited to participate in a special â€œSoft Skills Final Examâ€ activity to receive a certificate of completion. Registration is required for this program http://www.eventbrite.com/e/soft-skills-series-career-development-session-3-time-management-strategies-tickets-12328616223?aff=efbevent

Student Life in the U.S.
Time: Thursday, August 7, 2:00 p.m. â€“ 4:00 p.m.
Speaker: William Hale, Consulate Summer Intern
William Hale, PAS summer intern, will give a presentation on what it is like to experience student life in the United States. He will talk about the basics of living on campus and what to expect from this new exciting experience. He will share some of his personal experience along with giving helpful advice about how to be successful in this new and exciting environment.

National Football League
Time: Friday, August 8, 2:00 p.m.
Venue: 8th Floor, Diamond Plaza, 34 Le Duan Blvd., District 1, HCMC
Speaker: Jeffrey Itell, Guest Speaker
Are you a football fan?  Football may be the world's sport but in America, American Football reigns supreme, from high school games on Friday, college football on Saturday, and the National Football League on Sunday and Monday. Get ready for the new Fall season by watching highlights, learning the game, and seeing why football is the most popular game in the USA.

Share this cool news with your friends and encourage them to come join us. The library is open to the public free of charge. If you would like to check out books and DVDs, please register to become a member: http://goo.gl/r0PNz6

Soft Skills Series - Cross-culture communication: Tips for Success in the International Workplace 
Time: Wednesday, July 23, 10:00 a.m.
Speaker: Anna Dupont, Cultural Affairs Officer

This is the first session in the new American Center Soft Skills Series on Career Development. More and more, Vietnamese students are graduating with great foreign language skills, and a desire to get experience in an international working environment. Success in the international workplace means getting the most benefit out of the diversity of your employees, colleagues, and customers. And that means being able to communicate and work effectively with people who may have different cultural perspectives than you. Anna has years of experience working with people, partners, and clients from dozens of countries around the world. Before she leaves Vietnam for her next international workplace, she will share information, activities, and tips on how to make sure you are an asset in a multicultural work environment. Don't miss it!

The State of New Jersey
Time: Wednesday, July 23, 2:00 p.m. â€“ 4:00 p.m.
Speaker: Elma Hajric, U.S. Consulate Summer Intern

What do boardwalks, Bon Jovi, and the worldâ€™s tallest roller coaster have in common? They are all from the great state of New Jersey, one of the original thirteen colonies! From its beautiful coastal towns to its rich history, the Garden State has inspired many classic Hollywood films and American rock stars. Come learn more about its breaking records, beauty, and prime role as one of Americaâ€™s best states on July 23rd at 2:00pm. 

The Golden State: Californiaâ€™s beauty, resources, and keeping it gorgeous for the next 100 years
Time: Wednesday, July 23, 5:00 p.m.
Speaker: Danit Kaya, Consulate Officer

This will be an opportunity to learn about my home state of California, the most beautiful and historic cities and sites and the strong culture of environmental protection and historical preservation that will preserve Californiaâ€™s charm for years to come.

The American Center is pleased to announce a summer Soft Skills Series: Career Development starting July 23 to August 27. The Series consists of six sessions on different topics designed to help you improve your interpersonal communication for career success. Participants who attend five of six Soft Skills sessions will be invited to participate in a special â€œSoft Skills Final Examâ€ activity to receive a certificate of completion and prizes.

The first session "Cross-culture communication: Tips for Success in the International Workplace" will be on Wednesday, July 23, 10:00 a.m. Sign up now http://softskillsseries1.eventbrite.com!

Soft Skills Series - Cross-culture communication: Tips for Success in the International Workplace 
Time: Wednesday, July 23, 10:00 a.m.
Speaker: Anna Dupont, Cultural Affairs Officer

This is the first session in the new American Center Soft Skills Series on Career Development.  More and more, Vietnamese students are graduating with great foreign language skills, and a desire to get experience in an international working environment.  Success in the international workplace means getting the most benefit out of the diversity of your employees, colleagues, and customers. And that means being able to communicate and work effectively with people who may have different cultural perspectives than you.  Anna has years of experience working with people, partners, and clients from dozens of countries around the world. Before she leaves Vietnam for her next international workplace, she will share information, activities, and tips on how to make sure you are an asset in a multicultural work environment. Don't miss it!

The State of New Jersey
Time: Wednesday, July 23, 2:00 p.m. â€“ 4:00 p.m.
Speaker: Elma Hajric, U.S. Consulate Summer Intern

What do boardwalks, Bon Jovi, and the worldâ€™s tallest roller coaster have in common? They are all from the great state of New Jersey, one of the original thirteen colonies! From its beautiful coastal towns to its rich history, the Garden State has inspired many classic Hollywood films and American rock stars. Come learn more about its breaking records, beauty, and prime role as one of Americaâ€™s best states on July 23rd at 2:00pm. 

The Golden State: Californiaâ€™s beauty, resources, and keeping it gorgeous for the next 100 years

Speaker: Danit Kaya, Consulate Officer

This will be an opportunity to learn about my home state of California, the most beautiful and historic cities and sites and the strong culture of environmental protection and historical preservation that will preserve Californiaâ€™s charm for years to come.

The 1940s to 1960s were the golden age of American musical theater, as hundreds of Broadway hits made their way to the big screen in towns and cities all over America. Join us as we screen and discuss one of Americaâ€™s greatest musicals from this golden age.

Returning to Vietnam with a U.S. Degree â€“ An Alumni Round-Table Discussion
Time: Friday, July 25, 2:00 p.m. â€“ 4:00 p.m.
Speakers: Alumni Group

Are you interested in what it's really like to be a Vietnamese student in the United States? Are you a Vietnamese alum of U.S. study who wants to meet people with similar experiences? Do you like networking with interesting people? If you answered "yes" to any of these questions, this event if for you. We will host a roundtable discussion with Vietnamese alumni of U.S. study, where alumni have a chance to network, discuss advantages and challenges of returning to their home country, and potential initiative to pay forward their experience to the community.

Sign up now for the free distance learning course entitled "Developing Innovative Ideas for New Companies: The First Step in Entrepreneurship" that will begin on July 21, 2014 to explore how to identity and develop great ideas into great companies. 
While you complete the course requirements on your own time, Mr. Ted Nguyen will facilitate weekly discussions at The American Center - Ho Chi Minh City to help you understand and apply the course material in Vietnam. 
By completing the online course requirements and attending all of the discussions, you will receive a certificate of completion from Coursera and a certificate of participation from the U.S. Consulate Ho Chi Minh City.

How To Be Successful Studying at a Community College in the U.S..
Thursday, July 17, 2014, 2:00 PM
Many international students who do well academically in home country struggle in U.S. schools due to cultural differences and lack of understanding of the American learning environment. Christina Nguyen, an Associate Director from Bellevue College will be giving a presentation on how to succeed in U.S. community colleges. She will give an overview on the important things to consider in order to choose the right school, how to achieve academic success at a community college and prepare for university transfer. She will use real life examples to highlight how you can overcome the many challenges outside the classroom.

One of the most familiar symbols of the United States are Native Americans. However, they are often seen in stereotypes or as part of history. Time: Friday, July 11, 2:00 p.m.
Speaker: Sean Thompson, Consulate Officer

Grandmaster Flash. The Beastie Boys. Public Enemy. NWA. Tupac. Nas. Jay-Z. Kanye West. Do any of these names sound familiar to you? Of course they do â€“ they are all famous hip hop artists! Come to the American Center on Friday, July 11 at 2:00 p.m. to hear Sean Thompson talk about the evolution of hip hop music in America. 

We will learn how the hip hop genre began in urban America, was used as a form of political expression, and then gained mass market appeal. We will also look at the lyrics of one of the best rap songs of all time together. Hope to see you there!

Time: Monday, June 9, 1:30 â€“ 4:45 p.m.

The session will provide helpful tips and guidance on how to best to prepare for fellowship/grant interviews, especially the VEF Fellowship and the VEF Visiting Scholar Program.

Ballet and Art Education in the United States
Time: Tuesday, June 10, 2:00 p.m.
Speakers: Stephen Mills, Choreographer and Artistic Director of Ballet Austin, and Dr. Brent Hasty, mindPOP solutions.

Join dancer Stephen Mills, Choreographer and Artistic Director of Ballet Austin, and Dr. Brent Hasty from mindPOP solutions (mindpop.org), to learn about ballet, the arts, and arts education in the United States.

Making Use Of The Other People's Ideas In Your Writing
Time: Wednesday, June 11, 2:00 â€“ 4:00 p.m.
Speaker: Dr. Lawry Finsen, University of Redlands; co-author of "The Persuasive Pen: An Integrated Approach to Reasoning and Writing"

Dr. Finsen will talk about how to effectively and appropriately incorporate the ideas and words of others in writing. He will also discuss some issues in critical thinking and effective writing. Main topics include:

- Understanding plagiarism and how to avoid it
- When to quote, when to paraphrase
- Dealing with sources that agree or disagree with you - why include one or the other?
- How all this relates to making the best case for your thesis

Discover America Summer Programs Kick-off
Time: Friday, June 13, 2:00 p.m.
Speaker: Chris Helmkamp, Consulate Officer

Excited about summer programs? Join us for a kick-off event to find out what American Center brings you this summer. Don't miss it!

Do you love the ocean? Help us show the world how important it is to protect it by sharing a photo that represents your love for our ocean. http://goo.gl/vw2bwO

We want to see photos of your day at the beach, waterway clean-up, surfing escapade, fishing expedition, or anything that captures what the ocean means to you. Snap a new moment or share a favorite memory!

Post your photo to your favorite social media platform using the hashtag #OurOcean2014 or add it to the OurOcean2014 group on Flickr.  We will be keeping an eye out for photos using the hashtag and will choose photos to be featured at the Our Ocean conference in Washington on June 16-17.

No matter where we live, we all depend on our ocean for the food we eat and the air we breathe.  Learn more about what you can do to protect our ocean at www.state.gov/ourocean and join our Thunderclap today to make your voice heard!

The 2014 Tony Awards Preview and Musical Theater at the AC
Time: Friday, June 6, 5:00 p.m.
Speaker: Deema Salem, Guest Speaker

Deema Salem received a Bachelor's degree in Musical Theater from New York University (NYU), and a Master's of Fine Arts in Acting from Pace University. She lives and works in New York City where she is a member of the Actor's Studio.  

Come join her in an exciting program to learn about the Tony Awards, learn how to warm up your voice like a professional actor, and learn scenes and choreography from a major Broadway musical.

Whether you live on the coast or hours from the closest beach, we all depend on the ocean. The ocean is critical to maintaining life on Earth, contributing to our livelihoods and our well-being. Yet, the ocean is facing significant challenges, such as unsustainable fishing practices, marine pollution, and ocean acidification. The good news is that there are solutions. 
Watch Secretary John Kerry explain what you can do to create a healthier ocean. #OurOcean2014

Conversation Hour with U.S. Students â€“ Utah State University
Time: Tuesday, June 3, 2:00 p.m.
Speakers: Students from Utah State University
 
Come hear from a group of U.S. students about their school and studies, and join them in small group discussions on interesting topics in education, business, and the similarities and differences between Vietnam and the United States. A great chance to practice your American English with native speakers!

LGBT Rights and Policy in the United States
Time: Tuesday, June 3, 5:00 p.m.
Speaker: Dr. Tobias Wolff, Professor of Law, University of Pennsylvania Law School
 
Tobias Barrington Wolff is a professor of law at the University of Pennsylvania Law School, where he teaches classes on sexuality and the law, same sex marriage and human rights. He is well known for his legal advocacy on same sex marriage and other LGBT-related issues, and has served as the chief advisor and spokesperson on LGBT issues for Barrack Obama throughout his 2007-08 presidential campaign.
 
Come join Professor Wolff for a discussion on LGBT Rights and Policy in the United States.
 
Activities in English

Speaker: Chris Helmkamp, Consulate Officer
 
Come practice English with Consulate Officer Chris Helmkamp.
 
Kick off LGBT Pride Month Celebration at the American Center
Time: Friday, June 6, 2:00 p.m.
Speakers: Information and Connecting Sharing (ICS) Group

Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Pride Month (LGBT Pride Month) is currently celebrated each year in the month of June to honor the 1969 Stonewall riots in Manhattan. The Stonewall riots were a tipping point for the Gay Liberation Movement in the United States. In the United States the last Sunday in June was initially celebrated as â€œGay Pride Day,â€ but the actual day was flexible. In major cities across the nation the â€œdayâ€ soon grew to encompass a month-long series of events. Today, celebrations include pride parades, picnics, parties, workshops, symposia and concerts, and LGBT Pride Month events attract millions of participants around the world.
 
Come join the Information Connecting and Sharing (ICS) group in several activities to kick off a month-long program to celebrate LGBT Pride Month at the American Center.

message:
Happy Mother's Day!

Motherâ€™s Day in the United States is celebrated each year on the second Sunday in May. In millions of households, mothers will be honored with flowers, greeting cards, candy, a special cake and, perhaps, breakfast in bed or a special lunch or dinner at a restaurant.

This holiday owes its start to Anna Jarvis, who held a memorial to her mother in 1899. Jarvisâ€™s mother had founded work clubs for women in her home state of West Virginia to improve sanitary and health conditions. Jarvis campaigned to have â€œMotherâ€™s Dayâ€ recognized as a national celebration.

President Woodrow Wilson made Mother's Day official in 1914.

Read more: http://iipdigital.usembassy.gov/st/english/inbrief/2012/05/201205115528.html#ixzz31NKjeTBL

message:
Check out the EJUSA: Earth Day 2014 - Paint the Town Green. http://goo.gl/pcVukS

In this issue, visit a few cities that stand out because of their environmental efforts. During recent years, Chicago city officials and residents planted half a million trees. In 2001, the city pioneered a rooftop garden atop the 11-story City Hall. Today, Chicago boasts 418,000 square meters of high-rise greenery. Rooftop gardens save energy, help control rainwater and ease unnatural temperature spikes in compact urban centers. More than 120 environmentally sustainable buildings, many with green roofs, make Chicago a national leader in green building.

Hi friends!  The American Center is excited to announce â€œTrash to Treasureâ€ â€“ a recycled art competition in celebration of Earth Day 2014!  Take your unused bottles, boxes, and other trash to build works of art that promote green living and Earth Day.
 
Be sure to come to the American Center on Wednesday, April 16 at 2:00 p.m. for our kickoff event and to hear more details about this competition (including the awesome prizes for our winners).
 
Itâ€™s time to get green, Ho Chi Minh City!  See you Wednesday!

April is Jazz Appreciation Month and we are continuing to celebrate with a quiz. Here is quiz question 3:

April 30 is the International Jazz Day (IJD) and there will be an official International Jazz Day celebration in an island nation in Asia! Do you know the name of that country?

Good Saturday morning!  Do you know that the National Cherry Blossom Festival is coming this weekend in Washington, D.C. And the cherry blossom is expected to be in full bloom. What is your favorite festival?

More information is available at http://www.nationalcherryblossomfestival.org/

message: This ESL blog post explains the expression â€œApril showers bring May flowers,â€ a popular rhyme to say and hear around the springtime. The first day of April is known as â€œApril Foolâ€™s Dayâ€ in the United States. Americans mark this day with good-spirited jokes.  This article describes a lesson that can be used to bring humor to the classroom. It explains how the translation of proverbs about fools can be used for a discussion and offers ideas about the teaching of these proverbs, such as exploring themes or looking at the definition of â€œfoolâ€ in each saying.

Time: Wednesday, March 26, 2:00 p.m.

Speaker: Michael Melcher, Next Step Partners 

Michael Melcher is one of Americaâ€™s leading executive coaches and is an expert on leadership, career development and business strategy. This session will identify key factors in career development and career change. Participants who attend three of four sessions will be invited to participate in a special â€œSoft Skills Final Examâ€ activity to receive a certificate of completion.

Good sunday afternoon!  Thanks again for participating in our World Water Day quiz!  The correct answer to question 2 is C. 2.8 billion people around the world live in areas of high water stress.

Here is the last question.  Test your Energy Water Food Nexus Knowledge! What is the biggest user of freshwater on the planet?
A)     Agriculture
B)      Energy and Industry
C)      Municipalities
D)     Recreation

Thanks all for your comments on question 1.  The correct answer is C.  Antarctica has the largest freshwater reserves.

Here is quiz question 2.  Do some research and write your answer in the comments below. Good luck!

World Water Day is Saturday, March 22. How many people around the world live in areas of high water stress?

A) 800 million

Good Saturday afternoon!  Missed the English Language Olympics last month?  Check out this page http://bit.ly/1dYfAo7 for some sports idioms.  Enjoy! 

Sports idioms originate from a specific sport such as basketball. These phrases have come to mean something that can be used in everyday life. You can study these idioms just as you would any other vocabulary. Then, take the quiz and test your knowledge. Also try using them at work, school, and social events. You will sound like a pro! http://bit.ly/1dYfAo7

Freedom of Information Day
Time: Friday, March 14, 2:00 p.m.
Venue: 8th Floor, Diamond Plaza, 34 Le Duan Blvd., District 1, HCMC
Speaker: Jonathan Hwang, Consulate Officer 

Freedom of Information (FOI) Day is an annual event dedicated to raise the profile of the principles of openness and transparency in civil administration.  The day is linked to the birthday of the fourth president of the USA James Madison, who is widely regarded as the Father of the Constitution and as the foremost advocate for openness in government. Come join Mr. Jonathan Hwang in learning how Americans celebrate this day.

Dr. Seuss (1904-1991) was an American writer world famous for his rhyming books for children, such as The Cat in the Hat and How the Grinch Stole Christmas! Because his books are often credited with helping children enjoy reading, Read Across America Day is celebrated on his birthday! http://1.usa.gov/1nVFJ9T

American Film Showcase: Public Film Screening and Discussion with the Filmmakers of "Lives Worth Living" 
Time: Thursday, March 13, 5:00 p.m.
Venue: 8th Floor, Diamond Plaza, 34 Le Duan Blvd., District 1, HCMC
Speaker: Eric Neudel and Allison Gilkey, Filmmakers and Co-directors 

"Lives Worth Living" is the first television history on the struggle of American people with disabilities for equal rights. The film traces the development of equal rights under the law for people with disabilities. Come to the AC for a screening and a discussion with the filmmakers themselves â€“ co-directors Eric Neudel and Allison Gilkey â€“ about the essential message of the film: the power of humanity and human dignity, and what one can accomplish against seemingly insurmountable obstacles. More information about the film can be found at: http://americanfilmshowcase.usc.edu/livesworthlivingmovie

Happy World Read Aloud Day! 

Every year on the first Wednesday of March, World Read Aloud Day calls global attention to the importance of reading aloud and sharing stories. Across the globe nearly 171 million children could be lifted out of poverty if they left school with basic reading and writing skills. World Read Aloud Day motivates children, teens, and adults worldwide to celebrate the power of words, especially those words that are shared from one person to another, and creates a community of readers advocating for every childâ€™s right to a safe education and access to books and technology.

Who are you reading aloud to today?

message: Join us for a live webcast of the 2014 International Women of Courage Award Ceremony tonight, March 4, 2014 at 11:30 PM Vietnam Time. The prestigious annually Secretary of Stateâ€™s Award for International Women of Courage recognizes women around the globe who have shown exceptional courage and leadership in advocating for women's rights and empowerment, often at great personal risk.

â€˜Lives Worth Livingâ€™ is the first television history on the struggle of American people with disabilities for equal rights. Happy Sunday everyone!

What will you be reading this weekend? How's about "Hearts and Crosses" by O. Henry?  The story is about a Texas rancher named Webb who is not content with holding a lower rank than his wife regarding ranch affairs. He leaves to be the master of his own ranch, but is called back by a sign that was used to signal a secret rendezvous when he and his wife were dating. Read here: http://1.usa.gov/1eRRryn.  There are both text and audio! Enjoy your weekend!

Valentine's Day in the United States

Americans celebrate the holiday in a variety of ways, though offering small tokens of affection like flowers and sugary confections is most common. Are you celebrating today? What are some of your favorite traditions for this holiday? 
Read more: http://goo.gl/z4ymRz

A Valentine for Endangered Wildlife

This rare Siberian (Amur) tiger cub is helping raise money to save vanishing wildlife around the world.

Sales of U.S. postage stamps with the tigerâ€™s image support conservation funds dedicated to saving tigers, African and Asian elephants, rhinos, great apes and marine turtles. For every "Save Vanishing Species" stamp sold, 11 cents goes to the conservation funds through a program administered by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.

There are only about 450 Siberian tigers left in the wild, according to the World Wildlife Fund, which notes that â€œpoaching and habitat destruction once again push this tiger close to the edge.â€
This Valentineâ€™s Day, February 14, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service is featuring the stamp on its website with the message â€œBe Our Valentine and Stamp Out Extinction.â€ The stamps can be purchased through the U.S. Postal Service.

Read more: http://iipdigital.usembassy.gov/st/english/inbrief/2012/02/201202141050.html#ixzz2tG35ITff

February: Black History Month

Black History Month celebrates the heritage of African Americans and their contributions to U.S. society.

What links the 1863 Emancipation Proclamation with the 1963 March on Washington? Both supported civil rights, and the march was held during the 100th anniversary year of the proclamation. Take a deeper look at Smithsonianâ€™s exhibition which tracks progress of civil rights in America: http://goo.gl/Hb1Tup

- Water purification and storage
- Storm protection and flood mitigation
- Shoreline stabilization and erosion control
- Groundwater recharge and discharge   
- Retention of nutrients and sediments
- Stabilization of local climates.
- All of the Above

National Mentoring Month 
Time: Thursday, January 16, 2:00 p.m.
Venue: The American Center, 8th Floor, Diamond Plaza, 34 Le Duan Blvd., District 1, HCMC
Speaker: Ryan Conrad, Guest Speaker

In 2002, January became National Mentoring Month in the United States, to focus the national attention on the need for mentors, particularly emphasizing mentoring for young people. Today, 15 million young people need a caring adult mentor in their lives. To be a mentor, one does not need special skills, just an ability to listen and to offer friendship, guidance and encouragement. Come learn about this recent civil society campaign and how various organizations work to promote mentoring in the United States.

State of the Union: The U.S. Constitution
Time: Monday, January 13, 2:00 p.m.
Venue: The American Center, 8th Floor, Diamond Plaza, 34 Le Duan Blvd., District 1, HCMC
Speaker: Michael Turner, Cultural Affairs Officer, U.S. Embassy Hanoi 

 Later this month, President Obama will deliver his annual State of the Union address to the U.S. Congress. Come learn about the three branches of the U.S. government, and why the President is required to report to Congress each year. Weâ€™ll also learn and practice new English vocabulary about this topic, so please join us!

Time: Wednesday, January 15, 5:00 p.m.
Venue: The American Center, 8th Floor, Diamond Plaza, 34 Le Duan Blvd., District 1, HCMC

Come join Mr. Freeman in learning English through film. 

National Mentoring Month 
Time: Thursday, January 16, 2:00 p.m.
Venue: The American Center, 8th Floor, Diamond Plaza, 34 Le Duan Blvd., District 1, HCMC
Speaker: Ryan Conrad, Guest Speaker

In 2002, January became National Mentoring Month in the United States, to focus the national attention on the need for mentors, particularly emphasizing mentoring for young people. Today, 15 million young people need a caring adult mentor in their lives. To be a mentor, one does not need special skills, just an ability to listen and to offer friendship, guidance and encouragement. Come learn about this recent civil society campaign and how various organizations work to promote mentoring in the United States.

The Fulbright Vietnamese Student Program is a competitive, merit-based scholarship program which recruits and nominates young Vietnamese professionals for Masterâ€™s degree programs at U.S. universities. Approximately 20 to 25 fully-funded scholarships are granted on an annual basis. Come learn more about this scholarship opportunity and how to apply! Celebrating Art & Urbanization in the U.S. & Vietnam 
Time: Monday, January 6, 2:00 p.m.
Venue: The American Center, 8th Floor, Diamond Plaza, 34 Le Duan Blvd., District 1, HCMC
Speaker: Professor Annette Kim, Guest Speaker

In 2010, Professor Annette Kim from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) teamed up with a Vietnamese colleague to bring together 4 undergraduate students from MIT and 4 Vietnamese university students to take photos of city life in and around Ho Chi Minh City. Professor Kim will speak about the whole process of developing the art exhibition, Vietnamese-American collaboration, art, and urban planning.

Speaker: James Town, Consulate Officer

In the United States, Thanksgiving is a time for tradition and sharing. People gather with family and friends on the fourth Thursday in November to enjoy a traditional meal and to give thanks for lifeâ€™s many blessings. Come to the American Center and get to know more about this traditional celebration.

Entrepreneurship Panel Discussion 
Time: Thursday, November 21, 5:00 p.m.
Venue: The American Center, 8th Floor, Diamond Plaza, 34 Le Duan Blvd., District 1, HCMC
Speakers: Tran Ngoc Thai Son, CEO, Tiki.vn; Dinh Minh Quan, President, Dinh Vi So Corp.; Phan Nguyen Nguyet Truc Dao, Founder, The Body Food; Hoang Linh, Vice President ,Viet Youth Entrepreneurs.

Come meet a panel of experienced Vietnamese entrepreneurs to discuss tips and best practices for starting your own business in Vietnam.

Sci-fi Short Story Club
Time: Thursday, November 21, 5:00 p.m.
Venue: The American Center, 8th Floor, Diamond Plaza, 34 Le Duan Blvd., District 1, HCMC
Speaker: Jessica Chesbro, Consulate Officer

Join Ms. Jessica Chesbro for a discussion of "Theyâ€™re made out of Meat" by Terry Bisson.  Please read the whole story before joining the discussion.  Get a copy of the story in AC library or here: http://setileague.org/articles/meat.htm

Startup Competition and Award Ceremony 
Time: Friday, November 22, 2:00 p.m.
Venue: The American Center, 8th Floor, Diamond Plaza, 34 Le Duan Blvd., District 1, HCMC
Judges: Consulate Officers and Start up Vietnam Instructors

The American Center, in partnership with Startup Vietnam, will organize its first startup competition in the format of the popular Startup Weekend, a global network of passionate leaders and entrepreneurs on a mission to inspire, educate and empower individuals, teams and communities.  Come cheer on the finalists as they present their startup ideas and as the judges announce a winning team.

Happening in 3 hours.  GIST TechConnect Webcast.  Bring your friends to the SaigonHub, 27B Nguyen Dinh Chieu, District 1 tonight, Monday, November 18th at 8:00 p.m. to join in the live webcast! Register: http://bit.ly/techconnectnetwork

Reminder: To all Startup Competition Applicants. 

Thank you for registering for the Startup Vietnam Competition 2013! Please note that you MUST attend all 3 workshops on Nov 16 and 17 to compete in this event. The workshop schedule is as follows:

Workshop 1: The Surprising Secrets of Successful Entrepreneurs
When: Nov 16, 9am-12noon

Workshop 2: The Five Essential Skills of Successful Entrepreneurs
When: Nov 16, 1pm-4pm

Workshop 3: The 2-Hour Challenge, Learning by Doing
When: Nov 17, 9am-12noon

IMPORTANT: During the workshops, you will form teams, and receive the SVC Rules.  If you can not attend the workshops, then you will not be able to register your team and participate in the competition.  

The workshops will be held in Saigon Hub, 27B Nguyen Dinh Chieu, District 1, HCMC.  Please contact chris@saigonhub.vn or ngan@saigonhub.vn if you have questions.

AC library has a good collection of Entrepreneurship and Startup books.  Stop by when you have a chance!  Have a nice weekend everyone!

INL and the Department of State are making strides against the illicit trade in wildlife products. Today, Secretary Kerry http://goo.gl/eL2Cy5 announced a reward of up to $1 million for information that leads to the dismantling of the Xaysavang Wildlife Trafficking Network. Based in Laos with affiliates in South Africa, Mozambique, Thailand, Malaysia, Vietnam, and China, the Xaysavang Network facilitates the killing of endangered elephants, rhinos, and other species for products such as ivory and rhino horn. Wildlife trafficking is a global threat with estimated profits of $8-10 billion per year.

Today is #UNDay, celebrating the anniversary of the Charter of the United Nations. In honor of today, we are going to celebrate the purposes of the United Nations.

The first is: To Keep Peace Throughout the World.

The second purpose of the United Nations is: To Develop Friendly Relations Among Nations.

Which of the following do you think the United Nations should focus on as its third purpose? Why? 

a.    To help nations work together to improve the lives of poor people
b.    To conquer hunger, disease and illiteracy
c.     To encourage respect for each otherâ€™s rights and freedoms
d.    Tell us your own

message:
Happy World Rivers Day! http://goo.gl/NLX3rF.  World Rivers Day is celebrated on the last Sunday of September. 

World Rivers Day is a celebration of the world's waterways. It highlights the many values of rivers and strives to increase public awareness and encourages the improved stewardship of rivers around the world.

Founder Mark Angelo said, â€œRivers are the arteries of our planet; they are lifelines in the truest sense.â€ What can we do to protect rivers and other waterways, both on the local and international scale?

Today is International Coffee Day! Check out this neat infographic about how coffee changed America: http://bit.ly/19FehVF . 

Which do you prefer, coffee or tea?

message:
Interested in practicing your English conversation skills?  The American Center English Conversation Club, which is limited to 25 participants who have not participated previously, will meet every two weeks on Thursday evenings at 5:00 p.m., starting October 3. If you are interested in joining, please come take an English Placement test on Thursday, September 26, at 5:00 p.m. The list of selected participants will be announced via email on Monday, September 30. No registration is required for this test.  Just show up on time.  

ENGLISH PLACEMENT TEST FOR ENGLISH CONVERSATION CLUB

Time: Thursday, September 26, 5:00 p.m.

Venue: The American Center, 8th Floor, Diamond Plaza, 34 Le Duan Blvd., District 1, HCMC

Happy World Rhino Day! http://goo.gl/C8UNYQ Check out the site for events happening all over the world, such as South Africa, Malaysia, and the United States! Why do you think it is important to celebrate and protect rhinos? How can we protect them through our individual actions?
We hope everyone is feeling tranquil, inquisitive, enamored & ecstatic! Happy Sunday!
story: U.S. Consulate General - Ho Chi Minh City is with Nhi Nguyen and Carrot Garden.

message:
Today is International Day of Peace! We will be highlighting important moments of peace on our page to bring attention to this important day.
 
The Paris Peace Conference in 1919 effectively ended World War I and brought together leaders to set the framework for peace. The League of Nations, the predecessor of the United Nations, was formed as a result of these talks. Learn more: http://goo.gl/tfhwTu
 
Do you think it is important to unite the world under one group, like the U.N.? Why?

Volunteerism: Virtual Q&A discussion with Omowale Ogunrinde and Korvi Rakshand

Thursday, September 12, 7:00PM Vietnam Time
Click here to join: https://conx.state.gov/digital-diplomacy

Interested in volunteerism, local activism and finding out how you can get involved in local and international communities? Join us for a Q&A discussion on volunteerism featuring three esteemed speakers, and share your voice.

Omowale Ogunrinde, Executive Director of Foundation for Skills Development - Omowale Ogunrinde is the Founder and Executive Director of the Foundation for Skills Development, a seven-year old vocational and technical training center that each year serves 5,000 unemployed adults, youth, and physically challenged people. Foundation for Skills Development offers technical training in areas such as catering, fashion design, woodwork, electronics, computers and electrical repairs. Ogunrinde was a delegate at the Presidential Summit on Entrepreneurship in 2010. Ogunrinde earned an MBA (1990) and a PGDE (1998) from the University of Lagos.

Korvi Rakshand, Founder of JAAGO Foundation - After earning his law degree in 2007 at the age of 21, Korvi Rakshand decided to forgo the family business and open a school for children in poverty. Later that year, Rakshand and a group of friends founded JAAGO, starting with a class of 17 students in a small classroom. Today, the project has flourished to 1,200 students spread across three schools. Rakshand grew up in Dhaka, Bangladesh and continues to provide higher education to underprivileged children in the city.

He has just enough fuel to get there - then he finds he has a stowaway, a young girl wanting to be with her brother on the colony

message: A cell phone that facilitates search and rescue efforts for trapped earthquake victims; a machine that converts plastic waste into fuel; and capsule shells that utilize fish fins and scales instead of pig skins and bovine hides. These are a just a few of the 2013 GIST Tech-I entries by the Asian entrepreneurs competing in the GIST Tech-I Competition â€“ and YOU can help them advance to the next round! Visit http://bit.ly/GISTTechIVote to watch all of the entries, and vote for your favorite business pitch.  Anyone can vote! Voting ends August 22.

Please mark your calendar for several exciting events at the American Center next week.  No registration is required for these programs.  See you all there!

The Real New York
Time: Tuesday, August 13, 2:00 p.m.
Speaker: Anna Dupont, Consulate Officer

When you think about New York, what comes to mind? Manhattan, the Empire State building, Times Square, â€œthe Big Appleâ€?  Thereâ€™s a lot more to New York State than that! Come join Anna as she continues the summerâ€™s â€œDiscover Americaâ€ with a trip a little further up the Hudson River, to discover the REAL New York.

We will be reading Isaac Asimovâ€™s short story, â€œThe Last Question.â€ Proclaimed by Asimov himself to be his â€œfavorite storyâ€ of all those he has written, it is a fascinating read that delves into topics such as entropy and the role of computers in our society. What do eco-friendly insecticidal fertilizer, energy efficient stoves, and a health-monitoring computer mouse have in common? All three of these science and tech innovations have become quarter-finalists in the 2013 GIST Tech-I Competition! 90 entrepreneurs have made it this far, but only 30 will make it into the next round! Choose the best Tech-I entry at http://bit.ly/GISTTechIVote by August 22 and help your favorite entrepreneur compete at the Global Entrepreneurship Summit.

Global Tiger Day is today, July 29! Habitat loss, wildlife trafficking, and poaching are threatening to push this magnificent creature into extinction in the wild. The United States works with tiger range countries and international forums like the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora to protect the species.

Can you name the thirteen countries where tigers are found? http://goo.gl/AU4TM9

Sci-fi Short Story Club

The King of the Cold War: or what did Elvis Presley have to do with U.S. Foreign Policy?
Time: Monday, July 8, 2:00 p.m.
Venue: The American Center, 8th Floor, Diamond Plaza, 34 Le Duan Blvd., District 1, HCMC
Speaker: Professor Michael G. Vann, Sacramento State University

Around the world, Elvis Presley is without doubt one of the most iconic images from American popular culture in the era of the Cold War. He is generally associated with domestic developments from the 1950s to the 1970s such as youth culture, sexuality, and African-American influences on white commercial music. But, U.S. scholar Michael Vann has another theory about Elvisâ€™ Hollywood movie roles, and what they might have to say about U.S. foreign policy. Come to the AC to hear Professor Vannâ€™s lively talk about what American popular culture can tell us about American history!

â€œDiscover America: Summer Presentation Contestâ€ - Frequently Asked Questions: 

1. Q: How many people are allowed on a team?
    A: Teams should be two to three people.

2. Q: How many states do I need to include in my tour?
    A: The tour must take place in the United States of America.  Beyond that, there is no minimum number of states to visit.

3. Q: For accommodation, can I arrange a homestay?
    A: Yes!  There are many organizations offering homestays in the US, and provided it is open to the general public, you can include it on your tour.

4. Q: Can I schedule my tour so I stay with relatives, eat meals there, or borrow their car?
    A: No. The contest is on your ability to put together a package tour. You cannot plan for your tourist to accept favors from your friends or relatives.

5. Q: Do I need to include tipping in my budget?
    A: Yes. Tipping in the US is typically 15-20%.  

6. Q: Does the 7 day tour include the time on the flight?
    A: No. The 7 day tour is counted from the moment you arrive in the U.S to the moment you leave the U.S.

7. Q: Does $4,500 include the visa fee?
    A: No. It doesnâ€™t.

message:
Pacific Angel 2013 in Dong Hoi, Quang Binh, Vietnam

The United States and Vietnam conducts humanitarian assistance operations June 10-14 as part of Operation Pacific Angel.

Officially in its sixth year, Operation PACANGEL is a joint and combined humanitarian assistance exercise led by Pacific Air Forces. Operation PACANGEL 2013 includes medical, dental, optometry, and engineering programs as well as various subject-matter expert exchanges.

Approximately 56 U.S. military members, along with local non-governmental organizations and host nation military forces are conducting humanitarian assistance operations in Dong Hoi, Quang Binh Province, Vietnam as part of this operation.

PACANGEL enhances participants' humanitarian assistance and disaster relief capabilities.

'Kinky Boots' Wins Best Musical At 2013 Tony Awards

The feel-good musical "Kinky Boots," with songs by pop star Cyndi Lauper, won the 2013 Tony Award for best musical. 

The Antoinette Perry Award for Excellence in Theatre, more commonly known informally as the Tony Award, recognizes achievement in live Broadway theatre. The awards are presented by the American Theatre Wing and The Broadway League at an annual ceremony in New York City. Read more here: http://www.tonyawards.com/index.html

One of the hands-down greatest things about eating in America is all the hyper-regional specialties.
