Did you know that the first Friday of June is also National Donut Day in the United States? 

But today is about more than the sweet treat! The National Donut Day was created by The Salvation Army in 1938 to honor the women who served doughnuts to soldiers during World War I, and is celebrated on the first Friday of June. The holiday celebrates the doughnut (a.k.a. "donut") â€“ an edible, torus-shaped piece of dough which is deep-fried and sweetened. Many American doughnut stores offer free doughnuts on National Doughnut Day.
Happy World Oceans Day! The two-year theme for 2013 and 2014 is â€œtogether we have the power to protect the ocean!â€ How do you protect the ocean? http://goo.gl/Et23L (Photo: infocentral.state.gov)

Book Club Activities this afternoon, 5:00 p.m.

An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge by Ambrose Bierce

Short story by Ambrose Bierce, published in 1891 in Tales of Soldiers and Civilians. The narrative concerns the final thoughts of a Southern planter as he is being hanged by Union soldiers. In the brief period between the tightening of the noose and the actual breaking of his neck, the man imagines his escape. 

Don't miss a chance to discuss this story with Ms. Jaclyn Luo this afternoon at 5:00 p.m.  See you all there!

Attention teachers! Want to take your students on a field trip to J.N. â€œDingâ€ Darling National Wildlife Refuge (Official) without ever leaving the classroom? Discovery Education is presenting a virtual field trip live from Sanibel Island, FL. The refuge is part of the largest undeveloped mangrove ecosystem in the U.S., and is famous for its migratory bird populations. http://bit.ly/13Z27q6 (Photo: Harold Wagle)

Happy International Day for Biodiversity May 22! This year's theme is water and biodiversity, which reminds us that water is essential for life and that no living being on planet Earth can survive without it. Did you know that only a tiny amount of the total water on our planet (0.03%) is available as liquid freshwater at or near the land surface? 

For more information, visit: http://goo.gl/Lnla8

Raggedy Ann Stories contains 13 short stories about the classic rag doll and her friends. Download the MP3 or listen online, or download the MOBI or EPUB files for your e-reader.

Happy Mother's Day to all the Moms out there! Motherâ€™s Day in the United States is celebrated each year on the second Sunday in May. In millions of households, mothers will be honored with flowers, greeting cards, candy, a special cake and, perhaps, breakfast in bed or a special lunch or dinner at a restaurant. What do you plan to do to celebrate your mother today?

This holiday owes its start to Anna Jarvis, who held a memorial to her mother in 1899. Jarvisâ€™s mother had founded work clubs for women in her home state of West Virginia to improve sanitary and health conditions. Jarvis campaigned to have â€œMotherâ€™s Dayâ€ recognized as a national celebration.

President Woodrow Wilson made Mother's Day official in 1914. According to the U.S. Census Bureau, there are an estimated 85 million mothers in the United States and the average number of children they have is 2.5. Most American mothers â€” 55 percent â€” are employed outside the home, according to the Census Bureau.

Read more: http://iipdigital.usembassy.gov/st/english/inbrief/2012/05/201205115528.html#ixzz2T2fLqtAB

message: Happy Birthday, Minnesota! On May 11, 1858, Minnesota became the 32nd state in the United States. Minnesota is known as the "Land of 10,000 Lakesâ€ but it actually has 12,000 lakes. message: Five presidents in one photo! After the dedication ceremony attended by five living Presidents on April 25th, the Bush Center, on the campus of Southern Methodist University, will open to the public on May 1, 2013. It is the 13th presidential library or museum run by the U.S. National Archives and Records Administration. The Center will house a vast amount of documents, records and artifacts from George W. Bush's presidency that lasted from 2001 to 2009. Tell us what you would like to see on a visit to the George W. Bush Presidential Center. http://goo.gl/5LtgY

Naval Activity 2013 with Vietnam: USS Chung Hoon arrives in Da Nang (April 21, 2013)

DA NANG, Vietnam (April 21, 2013) The guided-missile destroyer USS Chung Hoon (DDG 93) arrives in Da Nang, Vietnam for a Naval Engagement Activity (NEA). The NEA provides opportunities for U.S. and Vietnamese naval professionals to share best practices and exchange maritime skills. Maritime skill exchanges between the two navies are non-combatant events, such as humanitarian assistance and disaster relief, medical training, fire fighting and damage control, search and rescue, diving and salvage, sports and community service projects. (U.S. Navy photo by Mass Communication Specialist 1st Class Jay C. Pugh/Released)

Itâ€™s World Penguin Day today April 25! The Pew Charitable Trusts has developed a Penguin Personality Quiz â€“ http://bit.ly/11EUK5t. Take this short quiz, and discover what you have in common with your feathered friends of the Antarctic. Enjoy and share with friends!

The Federal Reserve Board on Wednesday announced that the redesigned $100 note will begin circulating on October 8, 2013.

This note, which incorporates new security features such as a blue, 3-D security ribbon, will be easier for the public to authenticate but more difficult for counterfeiters to replicate.

The new design for the $100 note was unveiled in 2010, but its introduction was postponed following an unexpected production delay.

Read more: http://www.newmoney.gov/stakeholder/journalist/release_04242013.htm

On April 22, 2013, more than one billion people around the world will celebrate Earth Day! Join us in Earth Day quiz series to celebrate Earth Day. AC also hosts an Earth Day program a tomorrow, Monday, April 22, at 10:00 a.m. Don't miss it!

Every year Earth day is celebrated on April 22, but do you know when was the first Earth Day celebrated? Was it 

1. April 22, 1969
2. April 22, 1970
3. April 22, 1971
4. April 22, 1972

In the United States, Earth Day is not an official holiday, but it is still celebrated in many ways. Americans of all ages participate in events to increase public awareness of environmental concerns and to celebrate their respect for the environment.

message:
The Light Between Oceans By M.L. Stedman

Tom Sherbourne takes a job as the lighthouse keeper on Janus Rock, nearly half a dayâ€™s journey from the coast. To this isolated island, Tom brings a young, bold, and loving wife, Isabel. Years later, after two miscarriages and one stillbirth, the grieving Isabel hears a babyâ€™s cries on the wind. A boat has washed up onshore carrying a dead man and a living baby. Tom wants to report the man and infant immediately. But Isabel insists the baby is a â€œgift from God,â€ and against Tomâ€™s judgment, they claim her as their own and name her Lucy. When she is two, Tom and Isabel return to the mainland and are reminded that there are other people in the world and how devastating their choice really is.

World Health Day is celebrated on 7 April to mark the anniversary of the founding of WHO in 1948. Each year a theme is selected for World Health Day that highlights a priority area of public health concern in the world. The theme for 2013 is high blood pressure. You know the other name for high or raised blood pressure and what all it can lead to? http://www.who.int/campaigns/world-health-day/2013/en/index.html

April Fools' Day is celebrated in many countries on April 1 every year. April 1 is not a national holiday, but is widely recognized and celebrated as a day when people play practical jokes and hoaxes on each other. Here's from a curator of the greatest practical jokes in history that have been pulled on April Fool's Day. http://www.museumofhoaxes.com/hoax/aprilfool/

It's time for the "Dugong Fact of the Day".  Check out this fact and join American Center "Save the Dugong" Logo Design Contest http://goo.gl/Pxsg4.  Contest End Date: April 12. Nice weekend everyone!

Fact 4: Female Dugongs give birth underwater to a single calf every three to seven years. It can take a mother Dugong fifteen months of pregnancy to have a baby. Birth takes place in shallow water and the baby Dugong is able to swim to the top of the water for its first breath. Baby Dugongs are about 100 to 120cm long and weigh 20 to 30 kg. The calf stays with its mother, drinking milk from her teats and following close by until 18-24 months of age. Dugongs reach adult size between 9 and 17 years of age, and have a lifespan similar to humans,if left alone.

Source: Unique Australian Animal

Fact 3: Dugongs can live as long as seventy years. Dugongs are closely related to manatees.  Dugongs have fluked tails, like whales.  Dugongs are said to be the basis for the legend of the mermaid. The average adult Dugong is about 2.7 meters long and weighs about 300 kilograms.

Webchat: Tales from the Wild: Wildlife Q&A with Animal Ambassador Julie Scardina. 
When: Tuesday, March 12, 2013, 9:00 a.m. Vietnam Time.  Click here to join: https://conx.state.gov/digital-diplomacy 

Learn about wildlife conversation with Julie Scardina, Animal Ambassador for SeaWorld, Busch Gardens, and Discovery Cove! Join Scardina and a representative from the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) to discuss issues of biodiversity and habitat protection, focusing on marine life and habitats. Scardina will also discuss the importance of multilateral agreements like the CITES treaty, as well as the role corporations and organizations can play in combating wildlife trafficking and promoting conservation.

The American Center will be closed in observance of George Washingtonâ€™s birthday on Monday, February 18, 2013. Normal hours will be resumed on Tuesday, February 19, 2013.  Hope everyone enjoyed long Tet holidays.. 

George Washington was the first president of the United States. The observance of George Washington's Birthday is the third Monday in February. Many Americans refer to the holiday as Presidents' Day as a way of honoring all past presidents.

Read more here: http://iipdigital.usembassy.gov/st/english/inbrief/2013/02/20130211142379.html#axzz2KqhA1EZh

Statement by the President on the Lunar New Year:

"Michelle and I send our warmest wishes to all those who will be celebrating the Lunar New Year this Sunday, February 10th.

Here in America and around the world, people of Asian and Pacific Islander descent will welcome the Year of the Snake.

In Chinese tradition, the snake represents wisdom, and a thoughtful approach to tackling the challenges before us â€“ principles that I hope will continue to guide us as we perfect our union and create a more just and equal future for every American.

Our challenges may be great, but our diversity and the traditions that thrive here give us the strength to meet them. To everyone celebrating the Lunar New Year, I wish you peace, prosperity and good health and fortune."

Today Feb. 6 is the 10th anniversary of the International Day of Zero Tolerance to Female Genital Mutilation/Cutting (FGM/C). At 9:30 p.m. tonight, join us in a live webcast of a panel of experts who will discuss successful efforts and solutions to address this issue.  https://conx.state.gov/digital-diplomacy/

An estimated 100 to 145 million women have undergone this brutal procedure, and about 3 million girls are at risk each year.

message: Hi all, due to Tet holidays, there will be no Book Club in February.  The next book club will be on Tuesday, March 5, at 5:00 p.m.  We will discuss "To Build a Fire" by Jack London. Please read before joining the club.  You have plenty of time. http://www.jacklondons.net/buildafire.html

Happy Groundhog Day! Groundhog Day is a day celebrated on February 2. According to folklore, if it is cloudy when a groundhog emerges from its burrow on this day, then spring will come early; if it is sunny, the groundhog will supposedly see its shadow and retreat back into its burrow, and the winter weather will continue for six more weeks.  Find out more about Groundhog Day here http://www.groundhog.org/groundhog-day/about-groundhog-day/

February 2, 2013 is World Wetlands Day! This year's theme is "Wetlands take care of water," which alludes to the important role that wetlands play in issues such as improving water quality and alleviating floods. What does the theme mean to you?

Interactive Thanksgiving

On November 14, 2012, from 8:00-9:15 a.m. EST. please join us for a live, interactive Thanksgiving event featuring award-winning American chefs. This program will take place direct from Blair House, the Presidentâ€™s guest house. Chefs Art Smith, Sam Kass and Richard Hetzler from the National Museum of the American Indian will engage viewers around the world on how to prepare classic American dishes for Thanksgiving. From mouth-watering turkeys, to classic sweet potato pie, audiences will learn about the culinary traditions and food products that go into some of our favorite recipes. Chefs will also provide live commentary about the American tradition of Thanksgiving, including its history and role in our family lives.

Attention university students! Do you speak English, have an interest in protecting the environment, and want a chance to travel and learn in the US next summer? Please apply by for the 2013 SUSI for Student Leaders. All information here:

THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF STATE PROFESSIONAL FELLOWS PROGRAM
â€œVietnam and USA mid-level professionals exchange program: Mutual learning for economic empowerment in the context of business and government partnershipsâ€ 
Center for Public Service 
Mark. O. Hatfield School of Government 
Portland State University 
Portland, OREGON 

For more information, come to: http://hochiminh.usconsulate.gov/professional_fellows_program.html for English, and to: http://photos.state.gov/libraries/vietnam/171343/PDF/Program_Guidelines_CPSPSU-Vietnamese.pdf  for Vietnamese.

message:
Dear All,

The Vietnam Education Foundation (VEF) Fellowship Program, funded by the U.S. Government, brings Vietnamese nationals to the United States for graduate degree programs on the sciences (natural, physical, and environmental), technology (including information technology), engineering, mathematics, and medicine (including public health and health sciences). 

We are pleased to announce a new application cycle of the VEF Fellowship Program for the 2014 Cohort. There will be 45 Master's/Doctorate Fellowships with full financial support through a cost-sharing agreement between VEF and U.S. universities available.
Application form will be available online only at the VEF website at: www.vef.gov from 10:00 a.m., December 10, 2012 to 10:00 a.m., April 10, 2013 (Vietnam time zone).
For further details, please refer to the program announcement at: http://home.vef.gov/news.php?id=292

Announcement on Acâ€™s English Conversation Clubs

The results of last weekâ€™s English Placement Test are in! Due to high demand, we have decided to run two English Conversation Clubs.  The top scorers from the exam are invited to join Conversation Club A, which will meet on Thursdays from 5:00-6:30 pm.  The next tier of top scorers are invited to join Conversation Club B, which will meet on Tuesdays from 5:00-6:30 pm.  Congratulations to everyone who took the test â€“ the results were impressive! Watch the First U.S. Presidential Debate LIVE!  ---- Right NOW!
Thursday, October 4 
8:00-9:30 a.m. Thailand time 
Location: University of Denver, Denver, CO
Moderator:Jim Lehrer, Executive Editor of the PBS NewsHour
Format
The first presidential debate will focus on domestic policy, including economics, healthcare, and government. It will be divided into six segments of approximately 15 minutes each.
The moderator will open each segment with a question, after which each candidate will have two minutes to respond. The moderator will use the balance of the time in the segment for a discussion of the topic.

message: Happy birthday American Center!  Happy birthday AC facebook!  Thanks all who have been with us for the past year. We will see you offline in few hours!

Announcing the 2013 Global Undergraduate Exchange Scholarship Program

The Public Affairs Section of the U.S. Embassy in Hanoi and Consulate General in Ho Chi Minh City are seeking candidates for the 2013 Global Undergraduate Exchange Program (Global UGRAD). First through third year undergraduate students who have demonstrated leadership through academic work, community involvement and extracurricular activities and with a good command of English are invited to apply for the program. The application deadline is 5 p.m. on November 26, 2012.

The American Center HCMC is pleased to announce that we are accepting applications for our newly launched â€œYouth and Volunteerismâ€ program.  If selected, students will have the opportunity to attend a two day workshop on September 4 and 5, to learn about volunteerism in HCMC and visit local Non-governmental Organizations who are making a difference in the city.  In addition, students will be able to meet with volunteer minded individuals from the US Consulate General as well as members of the Vietnamese State Alumni Network and learn about opportunities for US exchanges.  Applications are due August 19.  See attached documents for more information and the application form.

This weekâ€™s American English idioms relate to track and field events.  In these sports, the â€œhomestretchâ€ is the last part of a race.  Runners see the finish line, but still have to work hard to get there.  Use todayâ€™s idiom, â€œin the homestretch,â€ to describe situations where you are close to completing a challenging task, goal, or project.    

- Almaz knew she was in the homestretch when she began writing the conclusion to her research paper.   
- I saw the final mile marker in the marathon and knew I was IN THE HOMESTRETCH.

Are you in the homestretch of finishing any projects or goals?

We hope you are enjoying the 2012 Olympics and that you â€œhad a ballâ€ with this weekâ€™s American English idioms!
 
Letâ€™s review. Which idiom could you use these situations?
1.  You need to order food for a party, but arenâ€™t 100% sure how many people will attend
2.  You are trying to reach a difficult goal 
3.  Your boss asked you to do something that you are very good at 
4.  You want to buy a house and you have offered a price to the seller   

Idioms:
A. keep your eye on the ball
B. the ball is in your court
C. ballpark estimate (ballpark figure, ballpark number)
D. slam dunk

[Note: â€œhave a ballâ€ = enjoy, have fun]

International Youth Day 2012

Calling all young world changers! August 12 is International Youth Day!  To mark this event and launch its new Facebook page, the Office of Global Youth Issues is invited young people from around the world to share with them a challenge young people in their country face and what they are doing to help solve the problem.  If you want to help represent Vietnam in this project, make a 30-90 second video telling us who you are, where you are from, a problem you see in your community and what youth are doing to help solve that problem. Submit your videos to ACHCMC@state.gov by Friday August 10 and weâ€™ll submit them to the Office of Global Youth Issuesâ€™ Youtube channel.

Todayâ€™s American English idiom is â€œslam dunk.â€ Off the basketball court, you will hear this phrase used to describe situations where a successful outcome is expected.

Examples:

- Janet has strong grades and test scores, so getting into a good university will be a slam dunk.

- Swimmer Michael Phelps holds many world records, so winning another Olympic medal should be a slam dunk.

Will winning a medal in the Olympics be a slam dunk for your favorite team or athlete? In which sport?

Idiom for today: When you are not 100% certain and need to give approximate information, use today's American English idiom: â€œballpark estimate.â€  Two similar phrases are â€œballpark numberâ€ and â€˜ballpark figure.â€ 

Examples:

- Can you give me a ballpark estimate on how long it will take to finish the construction? 

- As a ballpark number, Iâ€™d guess 10,000 people attended the soccer match.

Have you ever given or asked for a ballpark estimate?  What was the situation?

Today's American English idiom relates to tennis. If you are negotiating, telling people â€œthe ball is in your courtâ€ lets them know it is their turn to act or make a decision.    

Examples:

- I told my son he could go to the movies if he cleans up his room first.  The ball is in his court.

- Katie offered us a good price for the car we want to sell, so the ball is in our court.

Can you think of another phrase in English or your language that has the same meaning?

message: It's Harry Potter's birthday! In America, he made a big difference in children's literacy. Did Harry Potter have an effect on your reading habits?

Letâ€™s â€œplay ballâ€ with this weekâ€™s American English idioms! Use the phrase "keep your eye on the ball" to talk about staying focused on a goal and paying attention to details.

Examples:

- If you want to succeed in this competitive industry, you have to keep your eye on the ball.

- If he wants to go a good university, Frank needs to keep his eye on the ball and study more.

When do you need to keep your eye on the ball?

(Photo credit: Richard Paul Kane / Shutterstock.com)

Today is Global Tiger Day! Did you know that the Siberian, or Amur, tiger is one of the most critically endangered of all tiger subspecies? Approximately 350-400 Siberian tigers remain in the Russian Far East. Although numbers have gone up slightly in recent years, Siberian tigers remain threatened by poaching, habitat destruction, and disease. Learn more at: http://www.fs.fed.us/global/globe/europe/russia.htm#5

The 2012 Olympics are almost here!  This weekâ€™s American English idioms are related to boxing. Todayâ€™s idiom is â€œlow blow,â€ which is an unfair or unsportsmanlike act. This phrase and another boxing idiom, â€œhit below the belt,â€ relate to rules that state a boxer canâ€™t hit an opponent below the waist. 
Examples:

- My sister told my friends that I didn't get the new job. What a low blow!

- You donâ€™t want to get in an argument with her!  She says hurtful things that really hit below the belt. 

What qualities make something a â€œlow blowâ€?  When could you use this expression?

50 states in 50 days - Utah - Dinosaur National Monument sits on both sides of the Utah-Colorado border, with 800 km2 of some of the roughest and most beautiful canyons and mountains in the Western U.S.  The "Dinosaur Wall," a single rock face 60 meters long, holds more than 1,500 bones of dinosaurs that lived 150 million years ago. Learn more about Utah here.

Congratulations to the members of the 20 teams selected to compete in Presenting: Great States!  

Hereâ€™s a little reminder of the competition rules:

â€¢ Presentations must be 5 minutes long. Once your five minutes are over, we will move on to the next group even if your presentation is not finished.
â€¢ You may have all members of your group speak, or only a few.  Itâ€™s up to you!
â€¢ You must present only on your assigned state.
â€¢ You should tell us about tourism, geography, culture, or anything else interesting about your state.
â€¢ Your must use Microsoft PowerPoint for your presentation.
â€¢ You must submit your PowerPoint file to achcmc@state.gov by 5:00PM on July 19th, 2012.
â€¢ Groups will present in the order listed in the attachment, beginning at 2:00PM on July 20th, 2012.
â€¢ At the end of the presentations, the audience will vote for their five favorite presentations.
â€¢ The top five presentations will be uploaded to Facebook to compete for the grand prize
â€¢ The three teams with the most votes on Facebook will be awarded prizes at the ceremony on Friday, July 27th at 2:00PM.

Please see the list of 20 selected teams here:

Happy Fourth of July! In 1776 U.S. Founding Father John Adams famously predicted that Independence Day would be celebrated "with pomp and parade, with shows, games, sports, guns, bells, bonfires, and illuminations, from this time forward forever more."

Hi all, our next stop on July 4 is Washington, D.C. â€” The U.S. congress designated Washington, D.C., the capital of the United States when it signed the Residence Act on July 16, 1790.

Watch live video of the July 4 Fireworks in Washington DC at 20:00 EDT (Midnight July 5, GMT)

Learn about visiting Washington, D.C.at http://goo.gl/Ha4s7
50 States in 50 Days: Youâ€™ve heard of Silicon Valley, but have you heard of the Silicon Forest? This high tech area lies just outside of Portland, Oregon.

The U.S. Consulate HCMC is co-sponsoring a conference on technology and entrepreneurship from  July 4-7th.  Strategic Alliance Vietnamese Ventures Inc. (SAVVi) designed the Technology, Entrepreneurship, and Creative Mix (TECx) to examine how technology is transforming our lives.   The four main themes of the conference are media, healthcare, biotech/agriculture, and education.  Click here for more information on this opportunity to network with industry leaders:  http://savvi.bz/savvi/index.php?page=tbc

50 States in 50 Days. North Carolina is home to one of Americaâ€™s greatest mysteries, Roanoke Island. A group of about 120 British immigrants established a settlement on Roanoke Island, in North Carolinaâ€™s fabled Outer Banks. The colony not only failed, but disappeared. Many settlers came to the U.S. for economic and religious reasons.

50 States in 50 Days - Virginiaâ€™s Luray Caverns combines music and nature with the worldâ€™s largest organ.  While The Great Stalacpipe Organ is played from a regular-sized organ, the pipes are actually stalactites that spread over three-and-a-half acres underground!  In Virginia, you can also visit the home of George Washington, Mount Vernon! George Washington, Americaâ€™s first president, built most of Mount Vernon by hand.

South Carolina is known for its beaches and golf courses, and it has both in abundance. From the busy Myrtle Beach area to the seclusion of Hilton Head Island, the coastline of South Carolina offers sand, surf and recreationâ€”including more than 350 championship golf courses across the state. The welcoming city of Charleston has some of the countryâ€™s best restaurants, where â€Ÿlowcountryâ€ cuisine and fresh seafood shine, plus lovely antebellum (pre-Civil War) homes (many of which are open to visitors). It is also a jumping off point for the Civil War landmark Fort Sumter. http://www.discoveramerica.com/usa/states/south-carolina.aspx

message: Let's go to Maryland today.  Home to Vice President Spiro Agnew, home-run hitter Babe Ruth and antislavery activist Harriet Tubman, Maryland was the seventh state to join the union on April 28, 1788. Learn more about the state that inspired â€œThe Star-Spangled Banner.

For Vietnamese, this New Year greeting evokes wonderful memories of sharing Tet holidays with family and friends, honoring ancestors, and enjoying ancient traditions.  It also elicits hope, optimism and anticipation for a prosperous year ahead.  As Americans of Vietnamese descent, my wife, Chi Tam, and I grew up with these same traditions.  After years of celebrating Tet with family and Vietnamese communities abroad, it is a special honor and privilege for us to be able to share this, our second Tet as U.S. Consul General in Ho Chi Minh City, with you all. 
 
On behalf of all of my colleagues at the U.S. Consulate General in Ho Chi Minh City, I wish everyone happiness, prosperity and health in 2012- the Year of the Dragon.

The American Center Poetry and English Conversation Clubs 

The American Center is pleased to announce a Poetry Club and an English Conversation Club starting in February. Both clubs will run for ten weeks, then be opened to new members. 

Participants are requested to take a basic English test to become members of these two clubs. The test schedule is: 

English Test for Poetry Club: Tuesday, January 17, at 5:00 p.m. 

English Test for English Conversation Club: Tuesday, January 17, at 5:30 p.m. 

Everyone is welcome to take both tests. Selected candidates will be notified by email. 

Donâ€™t miss this chance to test your English ability and become AC club members.
http://goo.gl/VqU80

Hi AC friends, dont forget to attend AC English test to become members of the Poetry Club and English Conversation Club.  Tuesday, Jan. 17, 5:00 p.m.: test for poetry club, 5:30 p.m.: Test for English Conversation Club. No registration is required.  See you all there.
